trial_title: A Multicenter, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled, Phase III Study of ARN-509 in Men With Non-Metastatic (M0) Castration-Resistant Prostate Cancer
inclusion_criteria: Histologically or cytologically confirmed prostate adenocarcinoma without neuroendocrine or small cell features | High risk for metastasis defined as PSA doubling time <= 10 months during continuous ADT | Castration-resistant prostate cancer on continuous ADT with 3 PSA rises >= 1 week apart and last PSA > 2 ng/mL | Maintain castrate levels of testosterone within 4 weeks prior to randomization and throughout the study | Bone-sparing agents allowed if on stable doses for >= 4 weeks prior to randomization | Washout from first-generation anti-androgen (e.g., bicalutamide, flutamide, nilutamide) for >= 4 weeks with PSA progression after washout | >= 4 weeks since 5-alpha reductase inhibitors, estrogens, and any other anti-cancer therapy prior to randomization | >= 4 weeks since major surgery or radiation therapy prior to randomization | ECOG performance status 0 or 1 | Resolution of acute toxicities from prior therapy or surgery to Grade <= 1 or baseline before randomization | Adequate organ function per protocol-defined criteria | No growth factors or blood transfusions within 4 weeks before hematology labs for eligibility
exclusion_criteria: Confirmed distant metastases, including CNS, vertebral, or meningeal involvement | Symptomatic local or regional disease requiring medical intervention | Prior treatment with second-generation anti-androgens | Prior treatment with CYP17 inhibitors | Prior treatment with radiopharmaceutical agents or any other investigational agent for non-metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer | Prior chemotherapy for prostate cancer except if given in the adjuvant or neoadjuvant setting | History of seizure or condition predisposing to seizure | Concurrent therapy with protocol-defined excluded medications | Any prior malignancy within 5 years except adequately treated basal cell or squamous cell skin cancer, superficial bladder cancer, or cancer in situ in complete remission | Severe or unstable angina within 6 months prior to randomization | Myocardial infarction within 6 months prior to randomization | Symptomatic congestive heart failure within 6 months prior to randomization | Arterial or venous thromboembolic events within 6 months prior to randomization | Clinically significant ventricular arrhythmias within 6 months prior to randomization | Uncontrolled hypertension | Gastrointestinal disorder affecting absorption | Active infection | Any other condition that would impair the patient's ability to comply with study procedures
prior_therapies: Continuous ADT required; Washout from first-generation anti-androgens >= 4 weeks with PSA progression after washout; >= 4 weeks since 5-alpha reductase inhibitors or estrogens; >= 4 weeks since any other anti-cancer therapy; >= 4 weeks since major surgery; >= 4 weeks since radiation therapy; Bone-sparing agents allowed if stable for >= 4 weeks
reasoning: The trial is for non-metastatic (M0) CRPC and explicitly excludes patients with confirmed distant metastases; this patient has metastatic disease (liver and bone). It also excludes prior treatment with second-generation anti-androgens and CYP17 inhibitors, which the patient has received (enzalutamide and abiraterone).
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 66 years; Male; Castration-resistant prostate cancer; Metastatic disease; PSMA PET avid disease; Liver metastases; Bone metastases; Progression on enzalutamide; Prior abiraterone (Zytiga); Prior leuprolide (Lupron)
judge_comment: The trial explicitly excludes patients with confirmed distant metastases and prior second-generation anti-androgen or CYP17 inhibitor therapy; the patient has metastatic disease and received enzalutamide and abiraterone. These are hard exclusions, so F is correct.

question_text: A 55-year-old female has severe, seropositive rheumatoid arthritis refractory to methotrexate and two prior biologic agents (adalimumab and tocilizumab). She has active disease with a DAS28 score of 5.5. Critically, she has a history of treated Hepatitis B (HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive) and moderate chronic kidney disease with an eGFR of 45 mL/min/1.73m². What are trial options for her?
trial_title: A Phase II Study of Reduced Intensity Conditioning in Pediatric Patients and Young Adults ≤55 Years of Age With Non-Malignant Disorders Undergoing Umbilical Cord Blood, Bone Marrow, or Peripheral Blood Stem Cell Transplantation
diseases_targeted: Primary Immunodeficiency; Congenital Bone Marrow Failure Syndrome; Inherited Metabolic Disorder; Hereditary Anemia; Crohn's Disease; Inflammatory Bowel Disease; Juvenile Rheumatoid Arthritis; Systemic Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis
inclusion_criteria: Availability of a suitable graft: 4/6–6/6 HLA matched related or unrelated UCB unit with total nucleated cells >= 3 x 10^7/kg (or double units each >= 2 x 10^7/kg) or 8/8 or 7/8 HLA allele-matched unrelated donor bone marrow or peripheral blood progenitor graft | Serum creatinine <= 2.0 mg/dL | Creatinine clearance >= 50 mL/min | ALT <= 4 x ULN | AST <= 4 x ULN | Cardiac function adequate: shortening fraction > 26% or ejection fraction > 40% or > 80% of normal for age | Pulmonary function: FEV1/FVC >= 50% predicted for age | Pulmonary function: DLCO (hemoglobin-corrected) >= 50% predicted (adults, if obtainable) | Resting pulse oximetry >= 92% on room air | HIV negative | Negative pregnancy test if pubertal and/or menstruating | Non-malignant disorder amenable to HSCT, including primary immunodeficiency syndromes (e.g., SCID with NK activity, Omenn, BLS, CID, CVID, Wiskott-Aldrich, leukocyte adhesion deficiency, CGD, X-linked hyper IgM, IPEX, Chediak-Higashi, ALPS, HLH, lymphocyte signaling defects) | Congenital bone marrow failure syndromes (e.g., dyskeratosis congenita, congenital amegakaryocytic thrombocytopenia, osteopetrosis) | Inherited metabolic disorders (e.g., mucopolysaccharidoses [Hurler, Hunter], leukodystrophies [Krabbe, metachromatic leukodystrophy, X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy, HDLS], alpha mannosidosis, Gaucher disease) | Hereditary anemias (e.g., thalassemia major, sickle cell disease with qualifying complications, Diamond-Blackfan anemia, other congenital transfusion-dependent anemias) | Inflammatory conditions (e.g., Crohn's disease/Inflammatory Bowel Disease)
exclusion_criteria: Allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant within the previous 6 months | Active malignancy or myelodysplastic syndrome | Severe acquired aplastic anemia | Uncontrolled bacterial, viral, or fungal infection with progression of clinical symptoms despite therapy | Pregnancy or nursing | Poorly controlled pulmonary hypertension | Any condition that precludes serial follow-up
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets juvenile rheumatoid arthritis/systemic JIA and other non-malignant disorders, not adult rheumatoid arthritis. Additionally, the trial requires creatinine clearance ≥50 mL/min, and the patient’s eGFR of 45 suggests this renal criterion would not be met.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Seropositive rheumatoid arthritis; Active disease with DAS28 score of 5.5; History of treated Hepatitis B (HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive); Moderate chronic kidney disease (eGFR 45 mL/min/1.73 m^2)
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to methotrexate; Prior adalimumab; Prior tocilizumab; Failed two prior biologic agents
judge_comment: Disease mismatch is a hard exclusion: the trial targets juvenile RA/systemic JIA and other non-malignant disorders, not adult rheumatoid arthritis. That alone warrants F. The noted renal function shortfall (CrCl ≥50 vs eGFR 45) further supports ineligibility but isn’t needed for the hard exclusion decision.

question_text: What are trial options for a 66 year old male with hx hypertension, afib, T2DM and mCRPC, now progressing on enzalutamide? He has been on Lupron+Zytiga for 3 years, with new liver and bone metastases which are all PSMA PET avid. He’s tolerated therapy well overall except for grade 2 fatigue.
trial_title: PROSPER: A MULTINATIONAL, PHASE 3, RANDOMIZED, DOUBLE-BLIND, PLACEBO-CONTROLLED, EFFICACY AND SAFETY STUDY OF ENZALUTAMIDE IN PATIENTS WITH NONMETASTATIC CASTRATION-RESISTANT PROSTATE CANCER
inclusion_criteria: Histologically or cytologically confirmed prostate adenocarcinoma without neuroendocrine, signet cell, or small cell features | Ongoing androgen deprivation therapy with GnRH agonist/antagonist or prior bilateral orchiectomy | Testosterone <= 50 ng/dL at screening | Progressive disease on androgen deprivation therapy at enrollment | PSA >= 2 ng/mL (central) | PSA doubling time <= 10 months | No prior or present evidence of metastatic disease | Asymptomatic prostate cancer | ECOG performance status 0–1 | Estimated life expectancy >= 12 months
exclusion_criteria: Prior cytotoxic chemotherapy | Hormonal therapy or biologic therapy for prostate cancer (other than approved bone-targeting agents and GnRH therapy) within 4 weeks of randomization | Investigational agent within 4 weeks of randomization | Known or suspected brain metastasis or active leptomeningeal disease | History of another invasive cancer within 3 years of randomization | Absolute neutrophil count < 1000/µL | Platelet count < 100,000/µL | Hemoglobin < 10 g/dL | Total bilirubin >= 1.5 x ULN | Creatinine > 2 mg/dL | Albumin < 3.0 g/dL | History of seizure or condition predisposing to seizure | Clinically significant cardiovascular disease | Gastrointestinal disorder affecting absorption | Major surgery within 4 weeks of randomization | Hypersensitivity to enzalutamide or capsule components (including Labrasol, butylated hydroxyanisole, butylated hydroxytoluene) | Any concurrent disease, infection, or comorbidity that interferes with participation or data interpretation
prior_therapies: Ongoing androgen deprivation therapy with GnRH agonist/antagonist or prior bilateral orchiectomy required; Washout >= 4 weeks since hormonal/biologic therapy for prostate cancer or any investigational agent
reasoning: The trial requires nonmetastatic CRPC with no evidence of metastatic disease, while the patient has metastatic CRPC with liver and bone metastases—an explicit setting mismatch.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 66 years; Male; Castration-resistant prostate cancer; Metastatic disease; PSMA PET avid disease; Liver metastases; Bone metastases; Progression on enzalutamide; Prior abiraterone (Zytiga); Prior leuprolide (Lupron)
judge_comment: Trial explicitly requires nonmetastatic CRPC (no evidence of metastases); patient has metastatic CRPC with liver/bone mets. This is a required stage/setting mismatch, which is a hard exclusion per rubric → F. The grader’s reasoning aligns with this.

question_text: What are trial options for a 66 year old male with hx hypertension, afib, T2DM and mCRPC, now progressing on enzalutamide? He has been on Lupron+Zytiga for 3 years, with new liver and bone metastases which are all PSMA PET avid. He’s tolerated therapy well overall except for grade 2 fatigue.
trial_title: A Phase 2 Study Combining Ipilimumab, Degarelix, and Radical Prostatectomy in Men With Newly Diagnosed Metastatic Castration Sensitive Prostate Cancer or Ipilimumab and Degarelix in Men With Biochemically Recurrent Castration Sensitive Prostate Cancer After Radical Prostatectomy
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Histologically confirmed adenocarcinoma of the prostate | Newly diagnosed metastatic prostate cancer (Cohort A) | Castration-sensitive disease | <= 10 bony metastatic lesions allowed (biopsy-proven lesions without clear bone imaging permitted) | Distant metastatic lymph nodes allowed; regional pelvic lymph nodes count as metastasis if > 1.5 cm short axis | Medically fit for radical prostatectomy (Cohort A) | Karnofsky performance status 80-100 | WBC >= 2000/µL | ANC >= 1000/µL | Platelets >= 75000/µL | Creatinine <= 2.0 x ULN | AST <= 2.5 x ULN | ALT <= 2.5 x ULN | Bilirubin <= 1.5 x ULN (Gilbert's syndrome allowed if total bilirubin < 3.0 mg/dL) | Negative HIV, Hepatitis B, and Hepatitis C screening tests | No more than 5 months of prior androgen deprivation therapy; no prior primary local therapy (radiation or surgery) to the prostate (Cohort A) | Biochemical recurrence after radical prostatectomy with progressive disease defined by rising PSA (>= 50% increase to >= 1 ng/mL based on >= 3 determinations >= 1 week apart) or PSA doubling time <= 12 months (Cohort B) | Prior prostate radiotherapy allowed (Cohort B)
exclusion_criteria: Other malignancy within 5 years (except adequately treated basal/squamous cell skin cancer or superficial bladder cancer) | Major surgery within 4 weeks of enrollment | Prior radiation therapy to the prostate (Cohort A); prior palliative radiation to metastatic sites allowed | > 5 months of prior hormonal therapy for prostate cancer | Use of megestrol acetate or anti-androgen within 2 weeks of enrollment | Use of 5-alpha reductase inhibitor within 2 weeks of enrollment | Prior ketoconazole, abiraterone, or enzalutamide for prostate cancer | Current or prior investigational therapies for prostate cancer | Prior chemotherapy administered with intent to treat prostate cancer | Concomitant therapy with any other experimental drug | Autoimmune disease (e.g., inflammatory bowel disease, rheumatoid arthritis, scleroderma, systemic lupus erythematosus, autoimmune vasculitis) | Motor neuropathy of autoimmune origin (e.g., Guillain-Barre syndrome, myasthenia gravis) | Medical or psychiatric condition that would make ipilimumab hazardous or obscure adverse event interpretation (e.g., frequent diarrhea) | Underlying heart conditions rendering patient ineligible for surgery (Cohort A) | Non-oncology vaccine therapy within 1 month before or after any dose of ipilimumab (inactivated vaccines allowed) | Prior treatment with ipilimumab, CTLA-4 inhibitor/agonist, or CD137 agonist | Concomitant or prior IL-2, interferon, or other non-study immunotherapy regimens | Immunosuppressive agents or chronic systemic corticosteroids within 6 weeks of study entry | Visceral metastatic disease (Cohort B) | > 3 cycles of intermittent androgen deprivation therapy (Cohort B) | History of acute diverticulitis, intra-abdominal abscess, gastrointestinal obstruction, or abdominal carcinomatosis
prior_therapies: <= 5 months of prior androgen deprivation therapy allowed (Cohort A); No prior primary local therapy to the prostate (radiation or surgery) required (Cohort A); Prior prostate radiotherapy allowed (Cohort B); <= 3 cycles of intermittent androgen deprivation therapy allowed (Cohort B); No washout required for GnRH analogs; 2-week washout required for megestrol acetate or anti-androgens; 2-week washout required for 5-alpha reductase inhibitors
reasoning: The trial targets castration-sensitive prostate cancer (newly diagnosed metastatic or biochemically recurrent), whereas the patient has metastatic castration-resistant disease. Additionally, the trial explicitly excludes prior abiraterone or enzalutamide, both of which the patient received.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 66 years; Male; Castration-resistant prostate cancer; Metastatic disease; PSMA PET avid disease; Liver metastases; Bone metastases; Progression on enzalutamide; Prior abiraterone (Zytiga); Prior leuprolide (Lupron)
judge_comment: Hard exclusions apply: the trial requires castration-sensitive disease (patient is castration-resistant) and explicitly excludes prior abiraterone or enzalutamide, both of which the patient received. Therefore F is correct.

question_text: 36 female with stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma, who initially received optimal debulking and adjuvant carboplatin+paclitaxel +bevacizumab. After 5 months, she had a new pleural effusion that was cytology positive for ovarian carcinoma. She was found to be BRCA1 positive. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Randomized Phase II/III Study to Assess the Efficacy of Trametinib (GSK 1120212) in Patients With Recurrent or Progressive Low-Grade Serous Ovarian Cancer or Peritoneal Cancer
diseases_targeted: Ovarian Low-Grade Serous Carcinoma (recurrent); Primary Peritoneal Low-Grade Serous Carcinoma (recurrent)
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Recurrent low-grade serous ovarian or peritoneal carcinoma (including invasive micropapillary serous carcinoma or invasive grade I serous carcinomas) after initial diagnosis of low-grade serous disease | Recurrent low-grade serous carcinoma after initial diagnosis of serous borderline ovarian or peritoneal carcinoma | Prospective pathology confirmation of low-grade serous carcinoma prior to study entry | Measurable disease per RECIST 1.1 with required lesion size; imaging within 28 days prior to registration | At least 4 weeks since any major surgery | Progression/recurrence after at least one platinum-based chemotherapy regimen | Unlimited number of prior therapy regimens allowed | Hormonal therapy for malignancy discontinued >= 1 week prior to registration | Chemotherapy and radiation therapy discontinued >= 4 weeks prior to registration | Investigational agents discontinued >= 28 days prior to registration | Women of childbearing potential and men agree to use highly effective contraception during treatment and for 6 months after last dose; negative serum pregnancy test within 14 days prior to randomization; not breastfeeding | Ability to understand and sign informed consent | GOG performance status 0 or 1 | Able to swallow and retain oral medication; no clinically significant GI abnormalities that may alter absorption | All prior treatment-related toxicities <= grade 1 (except alopecia) at randomization | Left ventricular ejection fraction >= lower limit of normal by ECHO or MUGA | Serum creatinine <= 1.5 mg/dL or creatinine clearance >= 50 mL/min | Total bilirubin <= 1.5 x ULN | ALT <= 2.5 x ULN | AST <= 2.5 x ULN | Albumin >= 2.5 g/dL | PT and APTT <= 1.5 x ULN | Absolute neutrophil count >= 1500/µL | Platelet count >= 100000/µL | Hemoglobin >= 9.0 g/dL | If letrozole selected: patient must be postmenopausal (bilateral oophorectomy or >= 5 years after spontaneous menopause, or postmenopausal LH/FSH if within 5 years or hysterectomy without oophorectomy); discontinue HRT before letrozole
exclusion_criteria: Chemotherapy or radiotherapy within 4 weeks prior to entry (6 weeks for nitrosoureas or mitomycin C) or unresolved toxicities from prior therapy > grade 1 | Use of other investigational drugs within 28 days (or five half-lives, whichever shorter; minimum 14 days) before first dose | Index lesion previously irradiated must have progressed post-radiation to be measurable | Prior therapy with MEK, KRAS, or BRAF inhibitors | Concurrent use of other anticancer agents or investigational agents | Concurrent use of herbal supplements (e.g., St. John's wort, kava, ephedra, ginkgo biloba, DHEA, yohimbe, saw palmetto, ginseng) | Known leptomeningeal or brain metastases or spinal cord compression | Bowel obstruction or GI conditions affecting absorption (malabsorption, inability to swallow, major gastric or bowel resection) | History of interstitial lung disease or pneumonitis | Previous or current malignancy at other sites, except curatively treated in-situ cervix or non-melanoma skin cancer, or cancers without relapse for 5 years | Active HBV or HCV infection (chronic or cleared HBV/HCV allowed); HIV-positive patients on antiretroviral therapy not eligible | Hypersensitivity to trametinib, related compounds, excipients, dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), or Cremophor EL (Cremophor exclusion relevant only if paclitaxel is the only available agent and patient randomized to control) | Cardiovascular risk: LVEF < LLN, QTcB >= 480 msec, clinically significant uncontrolled arrhythmias (except controlled AF > 30 days), ACS/MI/unstable angina, coronary angioplasty or stenting within 6 months, NYHA class >= II heart failure, refractory hypertension (SBP > 140 mmHg and/or DBP > 90 mmHg despite therapy), intracardiac defibrillator or permanent pacemaker, known cardiac metastases | History or risk of retinal vein occlusion | Serious/unstable medical or psychiatric disorder that could interfere with safety or compliance | Concomitant medications that prolong QT interval required | Pregnant or nursing
prior_therapies: Progression after at least one platinum-based chemotherapy regimen required; Unlimited prior therapy regimens allowed; Hormonal therapy for malignancy discontinued >= 1 week before registration; Chemotherapy and radiation therapy discontinued >= 4 weeks before registration; Investigational agents discontinued >= 28 days before registration; At least 4 weeks since major surgery before registration
reasoning: The trial is restricted to recurrent low-grade serous ovarian or peritoneal carcinoma, whereas the patient has clear cell ovarian carcinoma. This histology mismatch is a hard disease exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma; BRCA1 positive; Optimal debulking surgery performed; Received adjuvant carboplatin + paclitaxel + bevacizumab; Cytology-positive malignant pleural effusion at 5 months post-adjuvant
patient_prior_therapies: Carboplatin; Paclitaxel; Bevacizumab; Optimal debulking surgery
judge_comment: The trial is specifically for recurrent low-grade serous ovarian or peritoneal carcinoma, while the patient has clear cell ovarian carcinoma. This is a disease/histology mismatch, which is a hard exclusion per the rubric, warranting an F. Other factors are irrelevant once a hard exclusion is present.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: Fecal Microbiota Transplantation in Refractory Clostridium Difficile Colitis
inclusion_criteria: Age >18 years | Three or more episodes of Clostridium difficile colitis within the previous 12 months
exclusion_criteria: Absolute neutrophil count < 500 cells/mm3 | Active infection at other sites requiring ongoing antibacterial therapy (antiviral or antifungal therapy acceptable) | Current or planned cytotoxic chemotherapy within 14 days of fecal transplantation date | Life expectancy < 180 days | Diagnosis of inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis) | Inability to swallow capsules | Indwelling nasogastric, orogastric, gastrostomy, or jejunostomy tube | History of partial or total gastrectomy | Short gut syndrome requiring total parenteral nutrition | Pregnancy | Documented intestinal parasite infection without documentation of appropriate treatment
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets recurrent Clostridium difficile colitis, not fistulizing Crohn's disease, and it explicitly excludes patients with inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's).
patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease; CDAI score 350; Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab; Active perianal fistula with draining seton in place; Recently completed IV antibiotics for perianal abscess
judge_comment: Hard exclusions apply: (1) Disease mismatch (trial targets C. difficile colitis, not Crohn’s); (2) Explicit exclusion of inflammatory bowel disease including Crohn’s. Therefore F is correct.

question_text: I have a 62-year-old male patient diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) 14 months ago. He has limb-onset disease and an ALSFRS-R score of 38. His forced vital capacity (FVC) is stable at 85% of predicted. He is currently taking riluzole. What trial options are available?
trial_title: MT2013-31: Allogeneic Hematopoietic Cell Transplantation for Inherited Metabolic Disorders and Severe Osteopetrosis Following Conditioning With Busulfan (Therapeutic Drug Monitoring), Fludarabine +/- ATG
diseases_targeted: Acyl-CoA Oxidase Deficiency; Adrenoleukodystrophy (cerebral); Alpha-mannosidosis; Alpha-methylacyl-CoA Racemase Deficiency; Aspartylglucosaminuria; D-Bifunctional Enzyme Deficiency; Fucosidosis; Globoid Cell Leukodystrophy; Glycoprotein Metabolic Disorders; Hereditary Leukoencephalopathy With Axonal Spheroids; Hunter Syndrome; Hurler Syndrome; Infantile Refsum Disease; Inherited Metabolic Disorders; Maroteaux Lamy Syndrome; Metachromatic Leukodystrophy; Mitochondrial Neurogastrointestinal Encephalopathy; Mucopolysaccharidosis Disorders; Multifunctional Enzyme Deficiency; Neonatal Adrenoleukodystrophy; Niemann-Pick B; Niemann-Pick C Subtype 2; Peroxisomal Disorders; Recessive Leukodystrophies; Severe Osteopetrosis; Sly Syndrome; Sphingolipidoses; Sphingomyelin Deficiency; Zellweger Syndrome
inclusion_criteria: Age 0–55 years | Adequate graft available | Adequate organ function | MPS IH (Hurler syndrome) | MPS II (Hunter syndrome) with no or minimal symptomatic neurologic disease but expected neurologic phenotype | MPS VI (Maroteaux-Lamy syndrome) | MPS VII (Sly syndrome) | Alpha-mannosidosis | Fucosidosis | Aspartylglucosaminuria | Globoid cell leukodystrophy | Metachromatic leukodystrophy | Niemann-Pick disease type B (sphingomyelin deficiency) | Niemann-Pick C subtype 2 | Adrenoleukodystrophy (cerebral involvement) | Zellweger syndrome | Neonatal adrenoleukodystrophy | Infantile Refsum disease | Acyl-CoA oxidase deficiency | D-bifunctional enzyme deficiency | Multifunctional enzyme deficiency | Alpha-methylacyl-CoA racemase deficiency (AMACRD) | Mitochondrial neurogastrointestinal encephalopathy (MNGIE) | Severe osteopetrosis | Hereditary leukoencephalopathy with axonal spheroids (CSF1R mutation) | Other life-threatening lysosomal, peroxisomal or similar inherited disorders with white matter disease or neurologic manifestations where transplantation is rational (e.g., Wolman disease, GM1 gangliosidosis, I-cell disease, Tay-Sachs disease, Sandhoff disease) | Voluntary written consent
exclusion_criteria: Pregnancy | Prior myeloablative chemotherapy within 4 months of start of conditioning | Uncontrolled bacterial, fungal, or viral infection including HIV | Active Aspergillus or other mold infection within 30 days
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets inherited metabolic disorders/severe osteopetrosis, not ALS. Additionally, the patient is 62 years old, exceeding the trial’s maximum age of 55.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS); Limb-onset disease; ALSFRS-R score 38; Forced vital capacity (FVC) 85% of predicted; Currently taking riluzole; Time since diagnosis 14 months; Age 62 years; Male sex
judge_comment: Hard exclusions apply: the trial diseases do not include ALS (disease mismatch) and the patient is older than the trial’s maximum age (55). Either factor alone yields F. The grader’s reasoning and grade are correct.

question_text: 36 female with stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma, who initially received optimal debulking and adjuvant carboplatin+paclitaxel +bevacizumab. After 5 months, she had a new pleural effusion that was cytology positive for ovarian carcinoma. She was found to be BRCA1 positive. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Phase II Evaluation of Nivolumab, a Fully Human Antibody Against PD-1, in the Treatment of Persistent or Recurrent Cervical Cancer
diseases_targeted: Cervical Adenocarcinoma; Cervical Adenosquamous Carcinoma; Recurrent Cervical Carcinoma; Cervical Cancer (stage IV)
inclusion_criteria: Histologically confirmed squamous cell carcinoma, adenosquamous carcinoma, or adenocarcinoma of the cervix that is persistent, recurrent, or metastatic with documented progression and not amenable to curative therapy. | Measurable disease per RECIST 1.1. | At least one target lesion per RECIST 1.1; lesions in previously irradiated fields are non-target unless progression is documented or biopsy confirms persistence >=90 days after radiation. | Recovery from adverse effects of prior surgery, radiotherapy, or chemotherapy. | Exactly one prior systemic chemotherapy regimen for persistent, recurrent, or metastatic cervical carcinoma. | Performance status 0 or 1. | ANC >= 1,500/µL. | Platelets >= 100,000/µL. | Creatinine <= 1.5 x ULN or creatinine clearance >= 40 mL/min. | Bilirubin <= 1.5 x ULN. | AST <= 3 x ULN. | ALT <= 3 x ULN.
exclusion_criteria: Prior therapy with nivolumab, anti-PD-1, anti-PD-L1, anti-PD-L2, anti-CTLA-4, or other agents targeting T-cell co-stimulation or immune checkpoint pathways. | History of severe hypersensitivity reaction to any monoclonal antibody. | Prior invasive malignancy (except non-melanoma skin cancer) unless disease-free for >=3 years. | Uncontrolled intercurrent illness including active infection, symptomatic congestive heart failure, unstable angina, significant arrhythmia, or psychiatric/social conditions limiting compliance. | Pregnant or breastfeeding. | Known brain or leptomeningeal metastases unless treated with no MRI evidence of progression for >=4 weeks and no requirement for systemic corticosteroids >10 mg/day prednisone equivalents for >=2 weeks. | Known HIV infection or AIDS. | Positive hepatitis B surface antigen or positive hepatitis C RNA indicating acute or chronic infection. | Active autoimmune disease or history of autoimmune disease that might recur, affect vital organ function, or require immunosuppressive treatment (exceptions include vitiligo, type I diabetes, residual hypothyroidism on replacement, psoriasis not requiring systemic treatment, or conditions not expected to recur). | Systemic corticosteroids >10 mg/day prednisone equivalents or other immunosuppressive medications within 14 days prior to study drug (topical, inhaled, ocular, intra-articular, intranasal, and physiologic replacement doses allowed). | Active or recent gastrointestinal conditions including diverticulitis, intra-abdominal abscess, abdominal/pelvic fistula, gastrointestinal perforation, gastrointestinal obstruction, or requirement for parenteral hydration/nutrition.
prior_therapies: Exactly one prior systemic chemotherapy regimen for persistent/recurrent/metastatic cervical cancer is required.; Chemotherapy, biologic/targeted agents, and immunologic agents must be discontinued >=3 weeks before registration.; Investigational agents must be discontinued >=30 days before registration.; Prior radiation therapy must be completed >=4 weeks before registration.; Major surgery must be completed >=4 weeks before registration.
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial enrolls cervical cancer (persistent/recurrent/metastatic), while the patient has recurrent clear cell ovarian carcinoma, which is not included.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma; BRCA1 positive; Optimal debulking surgery performed; Received adjuvant carboplatin + paclitaxel + bevacizumab; Cytology-positive malignant pleural effusion at 5 months post-adjuvant
patient_prior_therapies: Carboplatin; Paclitaxel; Bevacizumab; Optimal debulking surgery
judge_comment: The trial targets cervical cancers only; the patient has recurrent clear cell ovarian carcinoma. This is a hard disease mismatch per rubric, warranting an F. The grader’s reasoning correctly identified the key exclusion.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: The Effect of Therapeutic Fecal Transplant on the Gut Microbiome in Children With Ulcerative Colitis
inclusion_criteria: Age 7-21 years with diagnosed ulcerative colitis | Mild to moderate disease per PUCAI score 10-64 | Clinical need for colonoscopy
exclusion_criteria: Known resistance to steroid therapy, immunomodulators, and biologics | Current steroid dose >0.5 mg/kg/day (maximum 20 mg) | Recent dose change within 4 weeks of biologics, 5-ASA, steroids, or immunomodulators | Allergy or intolerance to mesalamine or 5-ASA products | Evidence of infectious colitis | Concurrent infections requiring antimicrobial therapy | Received probiotic preparations within 4 weeks prior to randomization | Pregnancy or breastfeeding | Significant renal dysfunction | Significant liver dysfunction | Congenital or acquired immunodeficiency | Immunosuppressed due to conditions other than ulcerative colitis (e.g., neoplastic disease or organ transplantation) | Received or receiving chemotherapy | Diagnosed with HIV | Unable to give informed consent/assent
prior_therapies: Stable dosing of biologics, 5-ASA, steroids, or immunomodulators for >= 4 weeks prior to randomization; No probiotic preparations within 4 weeks prior to randomization
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial is for ulcerative colitis, while the patient has fistulizing Crohn's disease. Additionally, the patient is 32 years old, outside the trial's 7–21-year age range.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease; CDAI score 350; Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab; Active perianal fistula with draining seton in place; Recently completed IV antibiotics for perianal abscess
judge_comment: Disease mismatch (Crohn’s vs ulcerative colitis) and age outside the trial’s 7–21 range are hard exclusions. F is correct per rubric.

question_text: I have a 62-year-old male patient diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) 14 months ago. He has limb-onset disease and an ALSFRS-R score of 38. His forced vital capacity (FVC) is stable at 85% of predicted. He is currently taking riluzole. What trial options are available?
trial_title: Intrathecal Autologous Mesenchymal Stem Cell Therapy in Multiple System Atrophy (MSA) - Effect of Dose and Natural History
inclusion_criteria: Age 30-80 years | Diagnosis of multiple system atrophy (MSA) per Gilman 2000 criteria (probable MSA-P or MSA-C) | Autonomic testing supportive of MSA: CASS >=5 or TST% >=25% | Less than 4 years from documented MSA diagnosis | Anticipated survival >=3 years | Able to provide informed consent | Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) >24
exclusion_criteria: Women of childbearing potential not using acceptable contraception | Clinically significant or unstable medical/surgical condition that may affect safety or results | Congestive heart failure | Recent myocardial infarction (<6 months) | Cardiopulmonary disease | Severe, uncontrolled hypertension | Thrombocytopenia (<50,000/µL) | Severe anemia (<8 g/dL) | Immunocompromised state | Liver disease | Kidney disease (creatinine >2.3 mg/dL) | Uncontrolled diabetes mellitus (HbA1c >10%) | Alcoholism | Amyloidosis | Uncontrolled hypothyroidism | History of sympathectomy | Unstable peripheral neuropathies | Concurrent systemic or local infection (including near spinal injection site) | Orthopedic problems compromising mobility or activities of daily living | Cerebrovascular accident | Exposure to neurotoxic or neuroactive drugs | Drug-induced parkinsonism (e.g., neuroleptics, alpha-methyldopa, reserpine, metoclopramide) | Malignant neoplasms | Use of investigational products within 60 days prior to baseline | Medications affecting autonomic function unless withdrawn 48 hours prior (e.g., midodrine, anticholinergics, alpha/beta adrenergic antagonists); fludrocortisone up to 0.2 mg/day permitted | Diseases with features of Parkinson's disease (e.g., diffuse Lewy body disease, progressive supranuclear palsy, essential tremor, hereditary olivopontocerebellar atrophy, postencephalitic parkinsonism) | Dementia (DSM-IV); MMSE must be >24 | History of electroconvulsive therapy | History of brain surgery for Parkinson's disease | Contraindication to MRI (e.g., MRI-incompatible pacemaker)
prior_therapies: No investigational products within 60 days prior to baseline; Hold medications affecting autonomic function (e.g., midodrine, anticholinergics, alpha/beta blockers) 48 hours before autonomic evaluations; fludrocortisone up to 0.2 mg/day permitted
reasoning: The trial is for Multiple System Atrophy and requires an MSA diagnosis, while the patient has amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS); this disease mismatch is a hard exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS); Limb-onset disease; ALSFRS-R score 38; Forced vital capacity (FVC) 85% of predicted; Currently taking riluzole; Time since diagnosis 14 months; Age 62 years; Male sex
judge_comment: Disease mismatch: trial requires Multiple System Atrophy while patient has ALS. This is a hard exclusion per rubric, so F is correct.

question_text: I have a 62-year-old male patient diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) 14 months ago. He has limb-onset disease and an ALSFRS-R score of 38. His forced vital capacity (FVC) is stable at 85% of predicted. He is currently taking riluzole. What trial options are available?
trial_title: A Phase I Study of Intrathecal Administration of scAAV9/JeT-GAN for the Treatment of Giant Axonal Neuropathy
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 3 years | Genetic diagnosis of Giant Axonal Neuropathy with pathogenic variants on both GAN alleles | Willingness to undergo a nerve biopsy at baseline and at 12 months after treatment | Use of barrier contraception post-dose (men for 6 months; women 3–6 months) and urine hCG testing for women of childbearing potential
exclusion_criteria: Pregnant or lactating | Forced vital capacity <= 50% predicted (if age >= 5 years) | Ventilator dependence including daytime assisted ventilation | Current clinically significant infections requiring systemic treatment, including HIV, hepatitis A/B/C, varicella zoster virus, or HTLV-1 | Prior history of bacterial meningitis | Unwilling to undergo lumbar puncture at baseline and during follow-up | Clinically significant echocardiogram abnormality | Clinically significant electrocardiogram abnormality | History of brain or spinal cord disease that would interfere with lumbar puncture procedures, CSF circulation, or safety assessments | Presence of an implanted CSF shunt or implanted CNS catheter | Any prior participation in a study with a gene therapy vector or prior stem cell transplantation | Participation in an IND/IDE or equivalent clinical study within the past 6 months | Chemotherapy, radiotherapy, or other immunosuppressive therapy within the past 30 days | Immunizations of any kind within the month prior to the study | Current use of medications that could increase intracranial pressure (e.g., levothyroxine, vitamin A, oral contraceptives, tetracycline, acetazolamide) | Known sensitivity or adverse reaction to anesthetic medications likely to be used | Giant Axonal Neuropathy without quantifiable weakness or functional loss | Evidence of cardiomyopathy or other cardiac disease that would make participation unsafe | History of diabetes or clinically significant abnormality of glucose tolerance test or fasting blood glucose | Positive purified protein derivative test for tuberculosis | Platelet count < 100,000/µL | Total white blood cell count < 3,000/µL or > 12,000/µL | Hemoglobin < 10 g/dL | Abnormal prothrombin time or partial thromboplastin time | Abnormal liver function tests (> 1.5 x ULN or > 2 x baseline) | Abnormal pancreatic enzymes (> 1.5 x ULN or > 2 x baseline) | Renal impairment: urinary protein concentration >= 0.2 g/L on 2 consecutive tests | Failure to thrive (significant weight percentile decline or weight < 3rd percentile for age/sex) | Anticipated need for major surgery in the next 12–18 months | Ongoing medical condition that would interfere with study conduct or assessments
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial is for Giant Axonal Neuropathy with required genetic confirmation, while the patient has ALS. This triggers a hard exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS); Limb-onset disease; ALSFRS-R score 38; Forced vital capacity (FVC) 85% of predicted; Currently taking riluzole; Time since diagnosis 14 months; Age 62 years; Male sex
judge_comment: Disease mismatch is a hard exclusion. The trial targets Giant Axonal Neuropathy, while the patient has ALS. The grader correctly applied the rubric and assigned F based on disease mismatch.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: A Phase I Study of a p53MVA Vaccine in Combination With Pembrolizumab
diseases_targeted: Non-Small Cell Lung Carcinoma; Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma; Hepatocellular Carcinoma; Renal Cell Carcinoma; Melanoma; Bladder Carcinoma; Soft Tissue Sarcoma; Triple-Negative Breast Carcinoma; Colorectal Carcinoma; Pancreatic Carcinoma
inclusion_criteria: Advanced (unresectable) solid tumors from predefined histologies (NSCLC, head and neck squamous cell carcinoma, hepatocellular carcinoma, renal cell carcinoma, melanoma, bladder carcinoma, soft tissue sarcoma, triple-negative breast cancer, colorectal carcinoma displaying microsatellite instability, or pancreatic cancer) | Failed or intolerant to at least one line of standard therapy or refusal of standard treatment | ECOG performance status <= 2 (Karnofsky >= 60%) | Absolute neutrophil count >= 1500/µL | Platelets >= 100000/µL | Hemoglobin > 9 g/dL | Creatinine clearance >= 50 mL/min or serum creatinine <= 1.6 mg/dL | Total bilirubin <= 1.5 x ULN | AST <= 3 x ULN (<= 5 x ULN with liver metastasis) | ALT <= 3 x ULN (<= 5 x ULN with liver metastasis) | Confirmed TP53 involvement: TP53 overexpression by IHC (>= 10% tumor cells) or TP53 mutation by tumor mutational analysis
exclusion_criteria: Concurrent investigational agents or radiation therapy | Pregnant or breastfeeding | Known brain metastasis | Radiotherapy within 4 weeks prior to study entry | Prior exposure to anti-PD-1 or anti-PD-L1 therapy | History of allergy to egg proteins | Unresolved adverse events from prior therapy > 4 weeks | Concurrent use of systemic corticosteroids (nasal, inhaled, adrenal replacement, and topical allowed) | History of immunodeficiency including organ grafts or HIV infection | Active autoimmune disease or condition requiring systemic corticosteroids (exceptions: vitiligo, type 1 diabetes mellitus) | History of severe immune-mediated adverse reactions with ipilimumab (grade 4 toxicity requiring > 10 mg/day prednisone or equivalent for > 12 weeks) | History of cardiac disease or abnormal screening ECG (excluding 1st degree bundle branch block, sinus bradycardia, sinus tachycardia, or non-specific T wave changes) or serum troponin >= grade 2 | Investigator-assessed inability to comply with safety monitoring
prior_therapies: At least one prior line of standard therapy failed or intolerant, or refusal of standard treatment
reasoning: The trial explicitly excludes patients with known brain metastases, which this patient has. Additionally, required TP53 involvement and prior failure of standard therapy are not documented.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 40 years; Male; Metastatic non-small cell lung cancer; De novo metastatic disease; Bone metastases; Liver metastases; Brain metastases on MRI; EGFR exon 19 deletion; On osimertinib for 2 years; ECOG 0; No significant comorbidities
judge_comment: The trial explicitly excludes patients with known brain metastases, and the patient has brain metastases on MRI, triggering a hard exclusion. Other requirements like TP53 involvement and prior failure are undocumented and should not drive the F, but the brain metastasis exclusion alone warrants F.

question_text: 36 female with stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma, who initially received optimal debulking and adjuvant carboplatin+paclitaxel +bevacizumab. After 5 months, she had a new pleural effusion that was cytology positive for ovarian carcinoma. She was found to be BRCA1 positive. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Phase III Study Comparing Single-Agent Olaparib or the Combination of Cediranib and Olaparib to Standard Platinum-Based Chemotherapy in Women With Recurrent Platinum-Sensitive Ovarian, Fallopian Tube, or Primary Peritoneal Cancer
diseases_targeted: Fallopian Tube Clear Cell Adenocarcinoma; Fallopian Tube Transitional Cell Carcinoma; Fallopian Tube Undifferentiated Carcinoma; Ovarian Clear Cell Adenocarcinoma; Ovarian Endometrioid Tumor; Ovarian Seromucinous Carcinoma; Ovarian Serous Tumor; Ovarian Transitional Cell Carcinoma; Ovarian Undifferentiated Carcinoma; Recurrent Fallopian Tube Carcinoma; Recurrent Ovarian Carcinoma; Recurrent Ovarian Endometrioid Adenocarcinoma; Recurrent Primary Peritoneal Carcinoma
inclusion_criteria: Platinum-sensitive recurrent high-grade serous or high-grade endometrioid ovarian, primary peritoneal, or fallopian tube cancer; other high-risk histologies (clear cell, mixed epithelial, undifferentiated, or transitional cell) allowed if deleterious germline BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation is present | Platinum-sensitive disease: > 6 months since last platinum and complete clinical response to prior platinum; no progression through prior platinum therapy | Measurable disease by RECIST 1.1 OR evaluable disease with CA-125 doubled from nadir and > 2 x ULN | Prior chemotherapy must have included a first-line platinum-based regimen; unlimited prior platinum-based regimens in the recurrent setting allowed | Up to 1 prior non-platinum-based line in the recurrent setting allowed; prior hormonal therapy does not count toward this limit | ECOG performance status 0–2 (Karnofsky >= 60%) | Able to swallow and retain oral medications; no gastrointestinal illness precluding absorption | Blood pressure <= 140/90 mmHg on up to three antihypertensive medications; able and willing to record daily BP | Toxicities from prior therapy resolved to <= grade 1 (except alopecia); long-standing stable grade 2 neuropathy may be allowed (will not receive carboplatin/paclitaxel if randomized to that arm) | Adequately controlled thyroid function; TSH within normal limits without symptoms of thyroid dysfunction | Women of childbearing potential: negative pregnancy test and agreement to use two reliable forms of contraception | Age >= 18 years
exclusion_criteria: Chemotherapy or radiotherapy within 4 weeks (6 weeks for nitrosoureas or mitomycin C) prior to starting treatment, or unresolved toxicities from prior therapy > grade 1 | Hormonal therapy within 2 weeks prior to study entry (except raloxifene for bone health) | Concurrent investigational agents or investigational trial participation within 4 weeks | Medications that may markedly affect renal function (e.g., vancomycin, amphotericin, pentamidine) | Prior treatment affecting the VEGF pathway (e.g., thalidomide, sunitinib, pazopanib, sorafenib, nintedanib) in the recurrent setting; upfront bevacizumab allowed | Prior PARP inhibitor | CA-125–only disease without RECIST 1.1 measurable or otherwise evaluable disease | Untreated or symptomatic brain metastases, spinal cord compression, or leptomeningeal disease; treated brain metastases must be radiographically stable >= 6 months and asymptomatic | Strong CYP3A4 inhibitors or inducers; strong UGT/P-gp modulators should be used with caution | History of gastrointestinal perforation; abdominal fistula unless healed and no evidence for >= 6 months and low risk of recurrence | Intra-abdominal abscess within 3 months | Current signs/symptoms of bowel obstruction or within 3 months prior to starting study drugs | Dependency on IV hydration or total parenteral nutrition | Other invasive malignancy unless meeting specified curatively treated exceptions and disease-free >= 3 years | Myocardial infarction within 6 months, unstable angina, clinically significant ECG abnormalities, or NYHA class III/IV heart failure | Left ventricular ejection fraction below institutional normal or < 55% if no institutional threshold | History of stroke or transient ischemic attack within 6 months | Any prior hypertensive crisis or hypertensive encephalopathy | Clinically significant peripheral or other vascular disease (including aortic aneurysm or dissection) | Major surgery, open biopsy, or significant traumatic injury within 28 days prior to starting cediranib | Uncontrolled intercurrent illness (active infection, symptomatic CHF, unstable angina, significant arrhythmia other than controlled AF, or psychiatric/social conditions limiting compliance) | Pregnancy or breastfeeding | Known HIV-positive status | Use of complementary or alternative medicines (natural herbal products or folk remedies) | Features suggestive of myelodysplastic syndrome or acute myelogenous leukemia on smear or marrow (if evaluated) | Prior allogeneic bone marrow transplant or double umbilical cord blood transplantation
prior_therapies: Required prior first-line platinum-based chemotherapy (with or without IV consolidation); Unlimited prior platinum-based regimens in the recurrent setting allowed; Up to 1 prior non-platinum-based line in the recurrent setting allowed; Prior hormonal therapy allowed and does not count toward non-platinum limit; Washout: chemotherapy or radiotherapy >= 4 weeks (>= 6 weeks for nitrosoureas or mitomycin C) before study treatment; Washout: hormonal therapy >= 2 weeks before study entry
reasoning: The trial requires platinum-sensitive recurrence (>6 months from last platinum), but the patient recurred at 5 months, which fails this mandatory inclusion criterion. While clear cell histology is allowed with deleterious germline BRCA1/2 (germline status not specified), the <6-month platinum-free interval is a hard exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma; BRCA1 positive; Optimal debulking surgery performed; Received adjuvant carboplatin + paclitaxel + bevacizumab; Cytology-positive malignant pleural effusion at 5 months post-adjuvant
patient_prior_therapies: Carboplatin; Paclitaxel; Bevacizumab; Optimal debulking surgery
judge_comment: Trial mandates platinum-sensitive recurrence (>6 months since last platinum). Patient recurred at 5 months, definitively lacking the required setting, which is a hard exclusion per rubric. Germline BRCA status is unknown and should not trigger F, but the platinum-sensitivity requirement alone justifies F.

question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.
trial_title: Repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation for Dementia
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 55 years | Diagnosed with mild cognitive impairment or dementia likely due to Alzheimer's disease | Ability to obtain motor threshold during screening | If on prescription cognition medication, dose stable for >= 4 weeks prior to randomization
exclusion_criteria: Prior exposure to repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation or electroconvulsive therapy | Unable to safely withdraw from medications that substantially increase seizure risk >= 2 weeks before treatment | Cardiac pacemaker or cochlear implant | Implanted deep brain stimulation device or metal in the brain | Current substance abuse (excluding caffeine or nicotine) | Active current suicidal intent or plan | Current or prior seizure disorder | Traumatic brain injury within the last 2 months | Participation in another concurrent interventional clinical trial | Known current psychosis | Current or prior mass lesion, cerebral infarct, or other active CNS disease increasing seizure risk | Not fluent in English or severe hearing impairment impairing comprehension
prior_therapies: Cognition medications allowed if dose stable for >= 4 weeks prior to randomization; Washout of medications that increase seizure risk for >= 2 weeks before treatment
reasoning: The trial enrolls only mild cognitive impairment or dementia likely due to Alzheimer's disease, but the patient's disease is listed as unspecified dementia (not AD/MCI). Age and sex fit, but this disease mismatch is a hard exclusion.
patient_biomarkers: Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 68 years; Male; Progressive cognitive decline for 2 years; MMSE score 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
judge_comment: Disease mismatch is a hard exclusion. The trial enrolls AD or MCI (dementia likely due to AD), while the patient’s listed disease is unspecified dementia with biomarkers arguing against AD. Thus F is appropriate without needing anchor assessment.

question_text: 36 female with stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma, who initially received optimal debulking and adjuvant carboplatin+paclitaxel +bevacizumab. After 5 months, she had a new pleural effusion that was cytology positive for ovarian carcinoma. She was found to be BRCA1 positive. What are trial options?
trial_title: Phase 1 Dose Escalation and Expansion Cohort of Carboplatin and Gemcitabine With or Without M6620 (VX-970) in First or Second Recurrence Platinum-Sensitive Epithelial Ovarian, Peritoneal, and Fallopian Tube Cancer
diseases_targeted: High Grade Serous Ovarian Carcinoma; Endometrioid Ovarian Carcinoma; Primary Peritoneal Carcinoma; Fallopian Tube Carcinoma
inclusion_criteria: Histologically confirmed high grade serous or endometrioid ovarian, primary peritoneal, or fallopian tube malignancy that is metastatic and not curable | Measurable disease by RECIST: >= 20 mm by conventional imaging or >= 10 mm by spiral CT/MRI/clinical calipers | Expansion cohort: archival tumor tissue available and willingness for baseline and on-treatment biopsies | Platinum-sensitive disease in first or second recurrence (recurrence > 6 months after last platinum therapy) | No more than two prior platinum-based regimens | ECOG performance status <=2 (Karnofsky >=60%) | Life expectancy > 6 months | Leukocytes >= 3,000/µL | Absolute neutrophil count >= 1,500/µL | Platelets >= 100,000/µL | Total bilirubin within normal limits | AST/ALT <= 2 x ULN | Creatinine within normal limits or creatinine clearance >= 50 mL/min | Negative serum pregnancy test for females of childbearing potential
exclusion_criteria: Platinum-resistant disease or beyond second platinum-sensitive recurrence | Chemotherapy or radiotherapy within 4 weeks prior to enrollment or unresolved > grade 1 toxicities (except alopecia; peripheral neuropathy <= grade 1 allowed) | Prior exposure to gemcitabine | Concurrent treatment with other investigational agents | Known brain metastases | History of allergic reactions to compounds similar to berzosertib, carboplatin, or gemcitabine | Concomitant use of strong CYP3A4 inhibitors or inducers | Uncontrolled intercurrent illness (e.g., active infection, symptomatic congestive heart failure, unstable angina, cardiac arrhythmia, significant psychiatric illness) | Pregnant or breastfeeding | Li-Fraumeni syndrome | Addition of bevacizumab to study treatment not allowed
prior_therapies: Platinum-sensitive recurrence (first or second) required; No more than two prior platinum-based regimens; Prior PARP inhibitor allowed; Prior bevacizumab allowed; Washout >= 4 weeks since chemotherapy or radiotherapy
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial enrolls high-grade serous or endometrioid ovarian cancers (plus primary peritoneal/fallopian tube), not clear cell ovarian carcinoma. Additionally, the patient’s recurrence at 5 months indicates platinum-resistant disease, while the trial requires platinum-sensitive recurrence.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma; BRCA1 positive; Optimal debulking surgery performed; Received adjuvant carboplatin + paclitaxel + bevacizumab; Cytology-positive malignant pleural effusion at 5 months post-adjuvant
patient_prior_therapies: Carboplatin; Paclitaxel; Bevacizumab; Optimal debulking surgery
judge_comment: Correct: The trial restricts histology to high-grade serous/endometrioid (plus primary peritoneal/fallopian tube), excluding clear cell—disease mismatch is a hard exclusion. Additionally, recurrence at 5 months after platinum indicates platinum-resistant disease, which is explicitly excluded. F is appropriate.

question_text: 36 female with stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma, who initially received optimal debulking and adjuvant carboplatin+paclitaxel +bevacizumab. After 5 months, she had a new pleural effusion that was cytology positive for ovarian carcinoma. She was found to be BRCA1 positive. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Pilot Study of Wee1 Inhibition Induction Prior to Tumor Reductive Surgery in Ovarian Cancer
diseases_targeted: Ovarian High Grade Serous Carcinoma; Fallopian Tube High Grade Serous Carcinoma; Primary Peritoneal High Grade Serous Carcinoma
inclusion_criteria: Presumed advanced-stage high grade serous ovarian, fallopian tube, or primary peritoneal carcinoma | Medically able to undergo primary cytoreductive surgery 13-28 days after starting study drug | No prior therapy for high-grade serous ovarian, fallopian tube, or primary peritoneal carcinoma | Able to swallow and tolerate oral medications; no GI illness precluding absorption | Absolute neutrophil count >= 1,500/µL | Hemoglobin >= 9 g/dL | Platelets >= 100,000/µL | Total bilirubin <= 1.5 x ULN | AST <= 2.5 x ULN | ALT <= 2.5 x ULN | Creatinine clearance > 50 mL/min | Creatinine < 1.5 x ULN | ECOG performance status 0-1
exclusion_criteria: Prior treatment for ovarian, fallopian tube, or primary peritoneal cancer | Current receipt of other investigational agents or additional anti-cancer agents | Active CNS disease other than neurologically stable, treated brain metastases | Other active cancers (exceptions: certain stage I, in-situ, or prior non-melanoma skin cancers) | Major surgery within 28 days or minor surgery within 7 days before starting treatment | Significant symptom burden including large volume ascites, pain requiring narcotics, or dyspnea on exertion | Myocardial infarction within 6 months, symptomatic CHF (NYHA > class II), unstable angina, or unstable arrhythmia | QTc > 470 msec or congenital long QT syndrome | Use of moderate to strong CYP3A4 inhibitors/inducers or sensitive/narrow therapeutic index CYP3A4 substrates that cannot be discontinued (including aprepitant/fosaprepitant) | Herbal preparations prohibited (e.g., St. John's wort, kava, ephedra, ginkgo, DHEA, yohimbe, saw palmetto, ginseng) and avoidance of grapefruit/exotic citrus during study | Known hypersensitivity to study treatment components | Pregnant or breast-feeding | Severe or uncontrolled systemic diseases (e.g., severe hepatic impairment, interstitial lung disease, uncontrolled chronic renal disease), serious active infection, uncontrolled hypertension (>= 140/90), active bleeding diathesis, or active infection including hepatitis B, hepatitis C, or HIV | Investigator deems patient unsuitable or unlikely to comply | Statin use (e.g., atorvastatin) prohibited due to BCRP inhibition
prior_therapies: No prior therapy for high-grade serous ovarian, fallopian tube, or primary peritoneal carcinoma
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial enrolls only high-grade serous ovarian/fallopian tube/primary peritoneal carcinoma, while the patient has clear cell ovarian carcinoma. Additionally, the trial requires no prior therapy, but the patient has received carboplatin, paclitaxel, and bevacizumab.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma; BRCA1 positive; Optimal debulking surgery performed; Received adjuvant carboplatin + paclitaxel + bevacizumab; Cytology-positive malignant pleural effusion at 5 months post-adjuvant
patient_prior_therapies: Carboplatin; Paclitaxel; Bevacizumab; Optimal debulking surgery
judge_comment: Trial restricts to high-grade serous disease while patient has clear cell—hard disease mismatch. Trial also excludes any prior therapy; patient received adjuvant chemo/bevacizumab. Both are hard exclusions, so F is correct.

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: Phase II Single Arm Study of Gemcitabine and Cisplatin Plus Pembrolizumab as Neoadjuvant Therapy Prior to Radical Cystectomy in Patients With Muscle-Invasive Bladder Cancer
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | ECOG performance status 0–1 | Histologically confirmed urothelial carcinoma of the bladder (mixed histology allowed if component of urothelial carcinoma; excludes pure small cell, pure adenocarcinoma, pure squamous) | Clinical stage T2–T4a N0/X M0 urothelial carcinoma | Medically appropriate candidate for radical cystectomy and planning to receive cystectomy | No prior systemic cytotoxic chemotherapy for urothelial carcinoma (prior intravesical chemotherapy permitted) | Adequate organ function per protocol laboratory criteria | Life expectancy > 3 months
exclusion_criteria: Participation in another investigational study or use of an investigational device within 4 weeks prior to first dose | Immunodeficiency or systemic steroid/immunosuppressive therapy within 7 days prior to first dose (except allowed prophylactic antiemetic steroids, inhaled/topical steroids) | Active tuberculosis | Hypersensitivity to pembrolizumab or its excipients | Prior monoclonal antibody therapy within 4 weeks prior to Day 1 or not recovered to <= Grade 1 from prior adverse events | Prior chemotherapy, targeted small molecule therapy, or radiation therapy within 2 weeks prior to Day 1 or not recovered to <= Grade 1 from prior adverse events | Additional malignancy that is progressing or requires active treatment (except certain skin cancers or in situ cervical cancer after curative therapy) | Active autoimmune disease requiring systemic treatment within the past 2 years | Interstitial lung disease or active, non-infectious pneumonitis | Active infection requiring systemic therapy | Pregnant or breastfeeding, or planning conception/fathering during study and for 120 days after last dose | Prior therapy with anti-PD-1, anti-PD-L1, anti-PD-L2, anti-CD137, or anti-CTLA-4 antibodies | Prior radiation therapy to the bladder for urothelial carcinoma | Known HIV infection | Active hepatitis B or hepatitis C infection | Clinically relevant hearing impairment > Grade 2 | Live vaccine within 30 days prior to first dose
prior_therapies: No prior systemic cytotoxic chemotherapy for urothelial carcinoma; No prior checkpoint inhibitor therapy (anti-PD-1/PD-L1/PD-L2, anti-CD137, anti-CTLA-4); Washout >= 4 weeks from prior monoclonal antibody therapy; Washout >= 2 weeks from prior chemotherapy, targeted therapy, or radiation therapy; No prior radiation therapy to the bladder for urothelial carcinoma; No investigational agents/devices within 4 weeks prior to first dose
reasoning: Explicit exclusions apply: the trial prohibits prior PD-1 therapy and prior systemic cytotoxic chemotherapy, while the patient received pembrolizumab and gemcitabine/cisplatin. Additionally, the trial is neoadjuvant for non-metastatic (M0) candidates pre-cystectomy, whereas the patient has metastatic disease post-cystectomy.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial carcinoma; Progressing after second line therapy; Prior neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Prior enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab with progression after 6 cycles; Status post cystectomy with pathologic complete response; Age 55 years; Male; Chronic kidney disease with eGFR 35 mL/min; History of type 2 diabetes mellitus; History of COPD
patient_prior_therapies: Neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin; Cystectomy; Enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab
judge_comment: The trial has explicit exclusions for prior PD-1/PD-L1 therapy and prior systemic cytotoxic chemotherapy, both of which the patient has received (pembrolizumab and gemcitabine/cisplatin). These are hard exclusions per the rubric, warranting an F. The grader correctly identified these and also noted the neoadjuvant M0 setting mismatch, though the hard exclusions alone are sufficient.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 11-year-old boy with Duchenne muscular dystrophy confirmed by a deletion of exons 49-50. He lost ambulation 8 months ago and is now dependent on a power wheelchair. He is on a stable regimen of deflazacort and lisinopril for early cardiomyopathy (LVEF 52%). His Performance of Upper Limb (PUL) score is 18. His parents are interested in trials for non-ambulatory patients.
trial_title: Neurologic Bone Marrow Derived Stem Cell Treatment Study
diseases_targeted: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis; Alzheimer Disease; CADASIL; Cerebral Hemorrhage; Cerebral Infarction; Cerebral Ischemia; Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy; Cognitive Impairment; Dementia; Diabetic Neuropathy; Frontotemporal Dementia; Lewy Body Disease; Lewy Body Variant of Alzheimer Disease; Multiple System Atrophy; Neuropathy; Parkinson Disease; Progressive Supranuclear Palsy; Stroke; Traumatic Brain Injury
inclusion_criteria: Documented functional damage to the central or peripheral nervous system unlikely to improve with current standard of care | >= 6 months since disease onset | If on pharmacologic or surgical therapy, clinically stable and unlikely to have reversal of neurologic damage from that therapy | Investigator assessment that there is potential for improvement with BMSC and minimal risk from the procedure | Age > 18 years | Medically stable and able to be cleared by a primary care practitioner for the procedure
exclusion_criteria: Not medically stable or at significant risk to health from undergoing the procedure | Pregnant at the time of treatment or planning pregnancy within 3 months post-treatment
prior_therapies: Current pharmacologic or surgical therapy allowed if stable
reasoning: The trial does not include Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy among eligible diseases and requires participants to be ≥18 years old, while the patient is 11.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 11 years; Male sex; Duchenne muscular dystrophy confirmed by deletion of exons 49-50; Non-ambulatory (lost ambulation 8 months ago); Power wheelchair dependent; Stable deflazacort regimen; Early cardiomyopathy with LVEF 52%; Performance of Upper Limb (PUL) score 18
judge_comment: Disease mismatch (Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy not among trial diseases) and age below minimum (11 < 18) are hard exclusions, so F is appropriate. The grader correctly identified both issues.

trial_title: A Pilot Pre-Surgical Study Evaluating Anti-PD-L1 Antibody (Durvalumab) Plus Anti-CTLA-4 (Tremelimumab) in Patients With Muscle-Invasive, High-Risk Urothelial Carcinoma Who Are Ineligible for Cisplatin-Based Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy
diseases_targeted: Bladder Urothelial Carcinoma; Infiltrating Bladder Urothelial Carcinoma (micropapillary variant); Infiltrating Bladder Urothelial Carcinoma (plasmacytoid variant); Infiltrating Bladder Urothelial Carcinoma (sarcomatoid variant); Renal Pelvis Urothelial Carcinoma; Infiltrating Renal Pelvis Urothelial Carcinoma (sarcomatoid variant); Ureter Urothelial Carcinoma; Urethral Urothelial Carcinoma
inclusion_criteria: Transurethral resection of bladder tissue (TURBT) performed at MD Anderson Cancer Center | Histologic proof of urothelial cancer (bladder, renal pelvis, ureter, or urethra); upper tract urothelial carcinoma included | Muscle-invasive disease (e.g., cT2-3aN0M0) or tumor not completely removed at TURBT, or requiring cystectomy/applicable surgery | High-risk features not candidates for traditional neoadjuvant chemotherapy: micropapillary, sarcomatoid, or plasmacytoid features | High-risk feature: 3-dimensional mass on exam under anesthesia | High-risk feature: lymphovascular invasion | High-risk feature: hydronephrosis (unless deemed not due to tumor) | High-risk feature: high-grade tumors of the ureter or renal pelvis with radiographic mass on CT or MRI | High-risk feature: direct invasion of prostatic stroma or vaginal wall (cT4a) | Candidates for but refusing conventional chemotherapy may be eligible | No prior exposure to immunotherapy such as anti-CTLA-4, anti-PD-1, or anti-PD-L1 antibodies (vaccines excluded) | ECOG performance status 0–1 | Adequate organ and marrow function without transfusions or growth factor support within 28 days prior to first dose | Hemoglobin >= 9 g/dL | Absolute neutrophil count >= 1,000/µL | Platelet count >= 100,000/µL | Total bilirubin <= 1.5 x ULN (Gilbert's syndrome allowed up to 3.0 mg/dL) | Cisplatin ineligible due to renal dysfunction, hearing impairment, comorbidities, or refusal; examples include GFR < 60 mL/min, CHF NYHA class III or higher, peripheral neuropathy grade >= 2, ECOG PS >= 2, impaired hearing, or patient refusal | Contraception required for females of childbearing potential through 180 days after final dose | Contraception required for nonsterilized males through 90 days after final dose
exclusion_criteria: Concurrent enrollment in another clinical trial (unless in follow-up or observational) | Concurrent chemotherapy, immunotherapy, biologic, or hormonal therapy for cancer | Investigational anticancer therapy within 28 days prior to first dose | Major surgical procedure within 28 days prior to first dose or not recovered from prior surgery | Unresolved toxicities from prior anticancer therapy > grade 1 (except alopecia and specified labs); irreversible toxicities not expected to be exacerbated may be allowed | Known or suspected autoimmune disease including inflammatory bowel disease, rheumatoid arthritis, systemic sclerosis, systemic lupus erythematosus, or autoimmune vasculitis | Systemic corticosteroids > 10 mg prednisone equivalents daily or other immunosuppressive medications within 14 days prior to first dose (inhaled/adrenal replacement allowed) | History of primary immunodeficiency | Prior organ allograft | Active hepatitis B or hepatitis C infection | Known HIV infection or AIDS | Receipt of live attenuated vaccine within 28 days prior to first dose (and not during study or for 180 days after last dose) | Pregnant or lactating | Uncontrolled intercurrent illness including active infection, current pneumonitis, symptomatic congestive heart failure, unstable angina, cardiac arrhythmia, interstitial lung disease, or significant psychiatric/social conditions limiting compliance | Other invasive malignancy within 2 years except certain in situ or non-melanoma skin cancers surgically cured | Evidence of metastatic urothelial carcinoma | Known allergy or hypersensitivity to study drug formulations | Currently on dialysis
