patient_inclusion_criteria: Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial carcinoma; Progressing after second line therapy; Prior neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Prior enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab with progression after 6 cycles; Status post cystectomy with pathologic complete response; Age 55 years; Male; Chronic kidney disease with eGFR 35 mL/min; History of type 2 diabetes mellitus; History of COPD
patient_prior_therapies: Neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin; Cystectomy; Enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab
judge_comment: The trial explicitly excludes patients with metastatic urothelial carcinoma and requires no prior PD-1/PD-L1/CTLA-4 therapy. The patient has metastatic disease and prior pembrolizumab, so hard exclusions apply → F. The grader correctly identified these conflicts.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: Pembrolizumab Prior to Surgery for Stage 1B, 2 or 3A Non-small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC): A Phase II Study
inclusion_criteria: Histologically or cytologically confirmed non-small cell lung cancer | Clinical stage IB (>= 3 cm), stage IIA/IIB, or stage IIIA (N0-2) amenable to surgical resection | Primary tumor >= 3 cm | Deemed a surgical candidate | ECOG performance status 0–1 | No active invasive malignancy in the past 2 years other than non-melanoma skin cancer; in-situ cancers allowed | Age >= 18 years | Negative pregnancy test for females of childbearing potential within 48 hours prior to initial study procedures | Measurable disease per RECIST 1.1 | Post-operative predicted FEV1 > 40% predicted | Post-operative predicted DLCO > 40% predicted | Adequate organ function
exclusion_criteria: Treatment within the last 30 days with an investigational drug or use of an investigational device within 4 weeks of first dose | Known history of active tuberculosis | Hypersensitivity to pembrolizumab or any of its excipients | Concurrent administration of any other anti-tumor therapy | Prior therapy with an anti-PD-1, anti-PD-L1, or anti-PD-L2 agent | Known active hepatitis B or active hepatitis C infection | Active infection requiring antibiotics, antifungal, or antiviral therapy | History of or evidence of active, non-infectious pneumonitis | Known history of HIV infection | Active autoimmune disease requiring systemic treatment in the past 2 years | Autoimmune motor neuropathy (e.g., Guillain-Barre syndrome, myasthenia gravis) | Systemic steroid therapy or other immunosuppressive therapy within 7 days prior to first dose | Known additional invasive malignancy that is progressing or requires active treatment (exceptions for certain skin cancers and in situ cervical cancer) | Pregnant or breastfeeding, or planning to conceive/father children during treatment and for 120 days after last dose | Major surgery (other than definitive lung cancer surgery) within 2 weeks prior to study | Receipt of non-oncology vaccine within 30 days before or after any dose of pembrolizumab (inactivated injectable influenza vaccines allowed; live attenuated intranasal vaccines not allowed) | History of myocardial infarction within 6 months, uncontrolled arrhythmia, symptomatic angina, active ischemia, or uncontrolled heart failure | History of interstitial lung disease | Inability to comply with study procedures | Prisoners or subjects involuntarily detained
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: The trial requires resectable stage IB–IIIA NSCLC for neoadjuvant pembrolizumab, whereas the patient has de novo metastatic (stage IV) disease; this is a definitive required stage/setting mismatch.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 40 years; Male; Metastatic non-small cell lung cancer; De novo metastatic disease; Bone metastases; Liver metastases; Brain metastases on MRI; EGFR exon 19 deletion; On osimertinib for 2 years; ECOG 0; No significant comorbidities
judge_comment: The trial requires resectable stage IB–IIIA NSCLC (neoadjuvant setting), while the patient has de novo metastatic (stage IV) disease. Per rubric, a required stage/setting the patient definitively lacks is a HARD EXCLUSION → F. Age/sex/disease type otherwise match, but the hard exclusion governs. The grader’s reasoning aligns.

question_text: I have a 62-year-old male patient diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) 14 months ago. He has limb-onset disease and an ALSFRS-R score of 38. His forced vital capacity (FVC) is stable at 85% of predicted. He is currently taking riluzole. What trial options are available?
trial_title: International, Multi-center, Open Label, Follow-up Extension Study Assessing the Long-term Safety and Tolerability of PXT3003 in Patients With Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease Type 1A
inclusion_criteria: Female patients agree to use an approved method of birth control during the study
exclusion_criteria: Clinically significant change in health status that would prevent participation or completion | Use of unauthorized concomitant treatments (e.g., baclofen, naltrexone, sorbitol [pharmaceutical form], opioids, levothyroxine, and potentially neurotoxic drugs such as amiodarone, chloroquine, or cancer drugs that can induce peripheral neuropathy)
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease Type 1A, while the patient has amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). This is a hard exclusion regardless of other factors.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS); Limb-onset disease; ALSFRS-R score 38; Forced vital capacity (FVC) 85% of predicted; Currently taking riluzole; Time since diagnosis 14 months; Age 62 years; Male sex
judge_comment: Disease mismatch is a hard exclusion: the trial targets Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease Type 1A, while the patient has ALS. The grader correctly assigned F based on the rubric.

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Phase 3, Open-label, Randomized Study of Nivolumab Combined With Ipilimumab, or With Standard of Care Chemotherapy, Versus Standard of Care Chemotherapy in Participants With Previously Untreated Unresectable or Metastatic Urothelial Cancer
inclusion_criteria: Histological or cytological evidence of metastatic or surgically inoperable transitional cell carcinoma of the urothelium (renal pelvis, ureter, bladder, or urethra) | No prior systemic chemotherapy for metastatic or surgically inoperable urothelial cancer | ECOG performance status 0 or 1
exclusion_criteria: Disease suitable for local therapy with curative intent | Serious or uncontrolled medical disorder that may increase risk or interfere with study participation or interpretation | Prior treatment with anti-PD-1, anti-PD-L1, anti-PD-L2, anti-CD137, or anti-CTLA-4 antibodies, or other agents targeting T-cell co-stimulation or checkpoint pathways
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: The trial excludes participants with prior anti–PD-1/PD-L1 or CTLA-4 therapy, and the patient received pembrolizumab (anti–PD-1) for metastatic disease. The trial also requires no prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease, whereas the patient has progressed after second-line therapy.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial carcinoma; Progressing after second line therapy; Prior neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Prior enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab with progression after 6 cycles; Status post cystectomy with pathologic complete response; Age 55 years; Male; Chronic kidney disease with eGFR 35 mL/min; History of type 2 diabetes mellitus; History of COPD
patient_prior_therapies: Neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin; Cystectomy; Enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab
judge_comment: The trial explicitly excludes prior PD-1/PD-L1/CTLA-4 therapy and requires no prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease. The patient received pembrolizumab (PD-1) and prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease, triggering hard exclusions. The grader correctly assigned F and cited the key reasons.

question_text: 36 female with stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma, who initially received optimal debulking and adjuvant carboplatin+paclitaxel +bevacizumab. After 5 months, she had a new pleural effusion that was cytology positive for ovarian carcinoma. She was found to be BRCA1 positive. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Phase 3 Study of Active Surveillance for Low Risk and a Randomized Trial of Carboplatin vs. Cisplatin for Standard Risk Pediatric and Adult Patients With Germ Cell Tumors
diseases_targeted: Germ Cell Tumor; Malignant Germ Cell Tumor; Extracranial Germ Cell Tumor; Malignant Ovarian Teratoma; Ovarian Embryonal Carcinoma; Ovarian Yolk Sac Tumor; Ovarian Choriocarcinoma; Testicular Seminoma; Testicular Embryonal Carcinoma; Testicular Yolk Sac Tumor; Testicular Choriocarcinoma; Extragonadal Embryonal Carcinoma; Testicular Mixed Choriocarcinoma and Embryonal Carcinoma; Testicular Mixed Choriocarcinoma and Teratoma; Testicular Mixed Choriocarcinoma and Yolk Sac Tumor
inclusion_criteria: Low risk stratum: no age limit | Standard risk 1: age < 11 years at enrollment | Standard risk 2: age >= 11 and < 25 years at enrollment | Low risk arms: newly diagnosed stage I germ cell tumor | Standard risk arms: newly diagnosed malignant germ cell tumor (stage II or higher) | Histologic confirmation of primary extracranial germ cell tumor required unless markedly elevated tumor markers (AFP >= 500 ng/mL or HCG >= 500 IU/L) with imaging consistent with GCT and biopsy not feasible/urgent therapy needed | Low risk ovarian immature teratoma: ovarian site; any stage/grade; pure or mixed immature/mature teratoma; may contain microscopic foci of yolk sac tumor (< 3 mm); AFP <= 1,000 ng/mL; beta-HCG normal; all ages | Low risk stage I non-seminoma MGCT: ovarian, testicular, or extragonadal; must contain yolk sac tumor, embryonal carcinoma, or choriocarcinoma (pure or mixed); all ages | Low risk stage I seminoma MGCT: testicular; histology only seminoma (may contain immature/mature teratoma); all ages | Standard risk 1: ovarian, testicular, or extragonadal; COG stage II–IV or FIGO IC–IV; must contain yolk sac tumor, embryonal carcinoma, or choriocarcinoma; age < 11 years | Standard risk 2 ovarian: COG stage II, III, III-X or FIGO IC–III; must contain yolk sac tumor, embryonal carcinoma, or choriocarcinoma; age >= 11 and < 25 years | Standard risk 2 testicular: COG stage II–IV, AJCC II–III, IGCCC good risk; must contain yolk sac tumor, embryonal carcinoma, or choriocarcinoma; post-op AFP < 1,000 ng/mL, beta-HCG < 5,000 IU/mL, LDH < 3 x ULN; age >= 11 and < 25 years | ECOG performance status 0–3 (Karnofsky for > 16 years; Lansky for <= 16 years) | Organ function requirements apply only to chemotherapy recipients (SR1 and SR2) | Adequate renal function: creatinine clearance or GFR >= 70 mL/min/1.73 m^2 within 7 days prior to enrollment or age/sex-specific serum creatinine threshold | Total bilirubin <= 2 x ULN (unless due to Gilbert's disease, malignant liver involvement, or vanishing bile duct syndrome) | AST and ALT < 3 x ULN (unless due to Gilbert's disease, malignant liver involvement, or vanishing bile duct syndrome) | Absolute neutrophil count >= 750/µL and platelets >= 75,000/µL within 7 days prior to enrollment | Standard risk arms: medically fit for protocol treatment with no contraindications to chemotherapy | AYA-HEARS substudy: age >= 11 and < 25 years; fluent in English; prior cisplatin- or carboplatin-based chemotherapy for any malignancy; followed for care at specified participating institutions
exclusion_criteria: Stage I testicular cancer with prior primary retroperitoneal lymph node dissection | Pure ovarian or extragonadal dysgerminoma/seminoma | Pure mature teratoma | Pure immature teratoma with AFP >= 1000 ng/mL | Poor-risk germ cell tumor (age >= 11 years with COG stage IV ovarian, COG stage II–IV extragonadal, or IGCCC intermediate/poor-risk testicular) | Primary central nervous system germ cell tumor | Germ cell tumor with somatic malignant transformation | Spermatocytic seminoma | Prior systemic therapy for the current cancer diagnosis | Prior radiation therapy (except CNS irradiation for brain metastases in SR1 patients) | Significant pre-existing respiratory disease contraindicating bleomycin (ineligible for standard risk chemotherapy arms) | Pregnancy (for patients receiving chemotherapy) | Lactation with intent to breastfeed (for patients receiving chemotherapy) | Sexually active patients of reproductive potential not agreeing to effective contraception during study participation (for patients receiving chemotherapy)
prior_therapies: No prior systemic therapy for current cancer diagnosis; No prior radiation therapy (except CNS irradiation for brain metastases in SR1 patients); Prior cisplatin- or carboplatin-based chemotherapy for another malignancy required for AYA-HEARS substudy eligibility
reasoning: The trial targets germ cell tumors (e.g., ovarian yolk sac, embryonal, choriocarcinoma), not epithelial clear cell ovarian carcinoma. Additionally, the patient is 36 with prior systemic therapy for the current diagnosis, which conflicts with the trial’s newly diagnosed/age-restricted cohorts.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma; BRCA1 positive; Optimal debulking surgery performed; Received adjuvant carboplatin + paclitaxel + bevacizumab; Cytology-positive malignant pleural effusion at 5 months post-adjuvant
patient_prior_therapies: Carboplatin; Paclitaxel; Bevacizumab; Optimal debulking surgery
judge_comment: Hard exclusion applies: disease mismatch (trial is for germ cell tumors; patient has clear cell ovarian carcinoma). Additionally, the trial explicitly excludes prior systemic therapy for the current diagnosis, which the patient had. F is appropriate.

trial_title: Phase I Trial of Intravenous Administration of Vesicular Stomatitis Virus Genetically Engineered to Express Thyroidal Sodium Iodide Symporter (NIS) and Human Interferon Beta (hIFNb), in Patients With Metastatic or Recurrent Endometrial Cancer

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: Outcome Analysis of Endoluminal Therapies for Gastrointestinal Conditions Compared to Current Treatment Paradigms
diseases_targeted: Achalasia; Gastric Fistula; Gastric Nec; Marginal Ulcer; Stenosis; Weight Gain After Primary Weight Loss Surgery

exclusion_criteria: Adults unable to consent | Does not meet inclusion criteria or does not qualify for endoluminal treatment paradigms
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets conditions like achalasia, GERD, Barrett’s esophagus, and post-bariatric issues, not Crohn’s disease or perianal fistulizing Crohn’s disease. Although age/sex fit, the patient’s disease is not included.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease; CDAI score 350; Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab; Active perianal fistula with draining seton in place; Recently completed IV antibiotics for perianal abscess
judge_comment: Disease mismatch is a hard exclusion. The trial targets achalasia/GERD/post-bariatric and related GI conditions, not Crohn’s disease or perianal fistulizing Crohn’s. Thus F is correct regardless of age/sex fit.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 11-year-old boy with Duchenne muscular dystrophy confirmed by a deletion of exons 49-50. He lost ambulation 8 months ago and is now dependent on a power wheelchair. He is on a stable regimen of deflazacort and lisinopril for early cardiomyopathy (LVEF 52%). His Performance of Upper Limb (PUL) score is 18. His parents are interested in trials for non-ambulatory patients.
trial_title: ASPIRO: A Phase 1/2/3, Randomized, Open-Label, Ascending-Dose, Delayed-Treatment Concurrent Control Clinical Study to Evaluate the Safety and Efficacy of AT132, an AAV8-Delivered Gene Therapy in X-Linked Myotubular Myopathy (XLMTM) Patients
inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of X-Linked Myotubular Myopathy with a genetically confirmed MTM1 mutation | Male | Age < 5 years at dosing | Requires mechanical ventilatory support | Part 1: Requires some mechanical ventilatory support (from full-time invasive to noninvasive CPAP/BiPAP during sleep) | Part 2: Requires invasive mechanical ventilatory support 20–24 hours/day at screening (confirmed by daytime polysomnography) | If requiring invasive mechanical ventilation, fitted with or willing to be fitted with a cuffed tracheostomy tube for some respiratory assessments | Ventilator PEEP < 8 cm H2O at screening | France: Weight >= 4.8 kg
exclusion_criteria: Participation in an interventional study designed to treat X-Linked Myotubular Myopathy | Born < 35 weeks gestation and not term by corrected age | Positive AAV8 neutralizing antibody above protocol-specified titer threshold | Recent surgery (< 3 months before Day 1) or planned surgery that may confound data collection during the first 48 weeks | Clinically important condition other than X-Linked Myotubular Myopathy in the opinion of the investigator | Clinically significant underlying liver disease | Current clinically important respiratory infection or other active infection | Received pyridostigmine or any medication to treat X-Linked Myotubular Myopathy within 3 months before Day 1 | Received immune-modulating agents within 3 months before Day 1 (inhaled corticosteroids allowed); concomitant chronic medications must be stable for at least 4 weeks before dosing | Contraindication to prednisolone | Contraindication to study drug or its ingredients | Previous scoliosis repair surgery/procedure, or planned/expected scoliosis repair in the 12 months following Day 1 (Part 2) | Contractures, scoliosis, or other condition limiting potential to achieve unassisted sitting (Part 2) | Able to sit without assistance for at least 30 seconds at screening (Part 2) | Clinically important condition including CTCAE v4.03 Grade >= 2 anemia (< 10 g/dL hemoglobin) | Contraindication to ursodiol (ursodeoxycholic acid) | France: Prior diagnosis or history of cardiac arrhythmias, myocarditis, or any other cardiac disease | France: Contraindication to general anesthesia and to muscle biopsy procedures
prior_therapies: Washout >= 3 months for pyridostigmine or any XLMTM-targeted medication before Day 1; Washout >= 3 months for immune-modulating agents before Day 1 (inhaled corticosteroids allowed); Concomitant chronic medications stable for >= 4 weeks before dosing
reasoning: The trial targets X-linked myotubular myopathy with a required MTM1 mutation and age <5 years, while the patient has Duchenne muscular dystrophy with a DMD exon 49-50 deletion and is 11 years old. This constitutes a disease mismatch and age/biomarker requirement conflicts, which are hard exclusions.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 11 years; Male sex; Duchenne muscular dystrophy confirmed by deletion of exons 49-50; Non-ambulatory (lost ambulation 8 months ago); Power wheelchair dependent; Stable deflazacort regimen; Early cardiomyopathy with LVEF 52%; Performance of Upper Limb (PUL) score 18
judge_comment: Disease mismatch (Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy vs XLMTM) is a hard exclusion per rubric, and patient is also over the trial’s age limit (<5 years). The grader correctly assigned F and identified the key hard exclusions.

trial_title: A Randomized, Phase 2 Trial to Evaluate the Safety and Efficacy of Eribulin Mesylate in Combination With Atezolizumab Compared to Atezolizumab Alone in Subjects With Locally Advanced or Metastatic Transitional Cell Urothelial Cancer Where Cisplatin-Based Treatment is Not an Option
diseases_targeted: Urothelial Carcinoma of Bladder; Urothelial Carcinoma of Renal Pelvis; Urothelial Carcinoma of Ureter; Urothelial Carcinoma of Urethra
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Histologically or cytologically confirmed locally advanced/unresectable and/or metastatic transitional cell urothelial carcinoma of the renal pelvis, ureter, urinary bladder, or urethra | Measurable disease per RECIST 1.1 | Post-radiotherapy lesions must show progression to be targetable | Archival or newly obtained invasive tumor tissue available for biomarker analysis; sequential biopsies at baseline and 6 weeks if safe | PD-L1 status determined centrally (SP142) available before randomization | New, progressive or recurrent disease during or within 12 months of platinum therapy, or first-line cisplatin-ineligible due to creatinine clearance < 60 mL/min, grade >= 2 hearing loss, and/or ECOG 2 | Up to two prior lines of chemotherapy for advanced disease allowed | Adequate recovery from prior anti-neoplastic treatment toxicities (generally <= grade 1; exceptions: any grade alopecia, grade 2 neuropathy, any grade hearing loss) | Brain metastases allowed if treated or stable, asymptomatic, and off steroids >= 28 days | Life expectancy >= 12 weeks | ECOG performance status 0-2 (Karnofsky >= 60%) | HIV-positive allowed if on stable HAART without CYP3A4 inducers/inhibitors, no need for opportunistic infection prophylaxis, CD4 > 250 cells/µL, and undetectable HIV viral load
exclusion_criteria: Prior allogeneic bone marrow transplantation or prior solid organ transplantation | Chemotherapy within 3 weeks prior to cycle 1 day 1 | Radiotherapy or targeted therapy within 2 weeks prior to cycle 1 day 1 (6 weeks for nitrosoureas or mitomycin C) | Not recovered from prior therapy adverse events beyond allowable exceptions | Prior treatment with anti-PD-1 or anti-PD-L1 agents or prior eribulin | Prior anti-CTLA-4 unless >= 12 weeks from first dose, > 6 weeks from last dose, and no history of severe immune-related adverse events | Investigational agent within 4 weeks prior to cycle 1 day 1 | Systemic immunostimulatory agents (e.g., IFN-alpha, IL-2) within 6 weeks prior to cycle 1 day 1 | Systemic immunosuppressive medications within 2 weeks prior to cycle 1 day 1 (exceptions for acute low-dose use, inhaled steroids, mineralocorticoids) | Bisphosphonate therapy for symptomatic hypercalcemia | Requirement for RANKL inhibitor (e.g., denosumab) that cannot be discontinued before atezolizumab | Primary CNS malignancy or symptomatic CNS metastases | Hypersensitivity to Chinese hamster ovary cell products, humanized antibodies, fusion proteins, or eribulin | Additional malignancy that is progressing or requires active treatment (exceptions: certain skin cancers or in situ cancers in remission >= 2 years) | Congestive heart failure > NYHA class III | Unstable angina or myocardial infarction within 6 months | Serious cardiac arrhythmia | QTcF > 450 ms or risk factors/medications predisposing to torsade de pointes | Autoimmune disease requiring systemic treatment in past 2 years | Clinically significant illness requiring medical treatment within 8 weeks or clinically significant infection within 4 weeks of dosing | History of organ allograft | Active hepatitis B (HBsAg positive) or active hepatitis C infection (PCR positive) | Clinically significant liver disease (active hepatitis, cirrhosis, fatty liver, inherited liver disease) | History or risk of autoimmune diseases (e.g., SLE, RA, IBD, vasculitis, multiple sclerosis) unless meeting specified exceptions | Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, pneumonitis (including drug-induced), organizing pneumonia, or active pneumonitis on screening CT | Active tuberculosis | Severe infections within 4 weeks prior to cycle 1 day 1 | Signs or symptoms of infection within 2 weeks prior to cycle 1 day 1 | Oral or IV antibiotics within 2 weeks prior to cycle 1 day 1 (except prophylactic use) | Major surgery within 28 days prior to cycle 1 day 1 or anticipated during the study | Live attenuated vaccine within 4 weeks before cycle 1 day 1 or planned during treatment and up to 5 months after last atezolizumab dose | Uncontrolled intercurrent illness that would limit compliance | Pregnant or breastfeeding
prior_therapies: Progression during or within 12 months of platinum-based therapy or first-line cisplatin-ineligible status; Up to two prior lines of chemotherapy for advanced disease allowed; No chemotherapy within 3 weeks before cycle 1 day 1; No radiotherapy or targeted therapy within 2 weeks before cycle 1 day 1 (6 weeks for nitrosoureas or mitomycin C); No investigational agents within 4 weeks before cycle 1 day 1; No systemic immunostimulatory agents within 6 weeks before cycle 1 day 1; No systemic immunosuppressive medications within 2 weeks before cycle 1 day 1 (with specified exceptions); Prior anti-CTLA-4 allowed with washout (>= 12 weeks from first dose and > 6 weeks from last dose) and no severe immune-related adverse events
reasoning: Explicit exclusion: the trial excludes any prior anti-PD-1/PD-L1 therapy, and the patient received pembrolizumab. Although the disease and setting match, this prior exposure makes the patient ineligible.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial carcinoma; Progressing after second line therapy; Prior neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Prior enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab with progression after 6 cycles; Status post cystectomy with pathologic complete response; Age 55 years; Male; Chronic kidney disease with eGFR 35 mL/min; History of type 2 diabetes mellitus; History of COPD
patient_prior_therapies: Neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin; Cystectomy; Enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab
judge_comment: The trial explicitly excludes patients with prior anti-PD-1/PD-L1 therapy, and the patient received pembrolizumab. This is a hard exclusion, so grade F is correct despite disease and setting alignment.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: Abdominal Wall Transplantation for the Reconstruction of Abdominal Wall Defects as Adjunct to Abdominal Solid Organ Transplantation
diseases_targeted: Abdominal Wall Defect; Abdominal Wall Fistula; Abdominal Wall Hernia; Abdominal Wall Injury; Bowel Transplant Failure; Liver Transplant Failure; Kidney Transplant Failure
inclusion_criteria: Age 18-65 years | Able and willing to provide informed consent | For combined procedures: eligible for the non-vascularized composite allograft organ transplant at the center | Negative serum pregnancy test within 48 hours prior to transplant (women of childbearing potential)
exclusion_criteria: Active malignancy or history of malignancy that precludes transplantation | Pregnancy | Medical contraindications to general anesthesia | Ongoing substance abuse or history of untreated substance abuse
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets abdominal wall defects/fistulas in the context of abdominal wall/solid organ transplantation, not fistulizing Crohn's disease or perianal fistulas. Therefore, the patient's condition is not included in the trial's disease scope.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease; CDAI score 350; Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab; Active perianal fistula with draining seton in place; Recently completed IV antibiotics for perianal abscess
judge_comment: Disease mismatch applies: the trial targets abdominal wall defects/fistulas and transplant-related conditions, not Crohn’s disease or perianal fistulas. This triggers a hard exclusion → F. The grader’s reasoning aligns with the rubric.

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Phase 1b-2 Study to Evaluate Safety, Efficacy, Pharmacokinetics, and Pharmacodynamics of Various Regimens of Erdafitinib in Subjects With Metastatic or Locally Advanced Urothelial Cancer
inclusion_criteria: Histologic urothelial carcinoma (transitional cell); variant histologies allowed (glandular, squamous, sarcomatoid, micropapillary) | Metastatic or locally advanced disease | Measurable disease by RECIST v1.1 at baseline | Phase 1b erdafitinib + cetrelimab cohort: any number of prior therapy lines for metastatic disease allowed | Phase 1b erdafitinib + cetrelimab + platinum cohort: no prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease | Renal function to receive platinum: creatinine clearance >30 mL/min for carboplatin eligibility and >60 mL/min for cisplatin eligibility (Cockcroft-Gault) | Phase 2: no prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease and cisplatin-ineligible (ECOG 0-1 with at least one: CrCl <60 mL/min, grade >=2 neuropathy, grade >=2 hearing loss; or ECOG 2) | ECOG performance status as follows: Phase 1b erdafitinib + cetrelimab cohort ECOG 0-2; Phase 1b platinum cohort ECOG 0-1 for cisplatin and 0-2 for carboplatin; Phase 2 ECOG 0-2
exclusion_criteria: Investigational agent or therapeutic clinical study participation within 30 days prior to Cycle 1 Day 1 | Phase 1b: prior nitrosoureas or mitomycin C within 6 weeks | Phase 1b erdafitinib + cetrelimab cohort: chemotherapy within 3 weeks of Cycle 1 Day 1 | Phase 1b platinum cohort and Phase 2: prior neoadjuvant/adjuvant chemotherapy allowed only if last dose >12 months before recurrence and no discontinuation due to drug-related toxicity | Prior PD-1, PD-L1, or PD-L2 therapy (exceptions: neoadjuvant/adjuvant >12 months without toxicity leading to discontinuation; PD-1 for non–muscle-invasive bladder cancer allowed) | Active malignancy requiring concurrent therapy other than urothelial cancer | Symptomatic central nervous system metastases
prior_therapies: Phase 1b erdafitinib + cetrelimab cohort: any number of prior systemic therapy lines allowed for metastatic disease; Phase 1b erdafitinib + cetrelimab + platinum cohort: no prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease; Phase 2: no prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease (cisplatin-ineligible); Prior neoadjuvant/adjuvant chemotherapy allowed if last dose >12 months before recurrent disease and no discontinuation due to drug-related toxicity; Washout: investigational agents within 30 days prohibited; Washout: nitrosoureas or mitomycin C within 6 weeks prohibited (Phase 1b); Washout: chemotherapy within 3 weeks prohibited (Phase 1b erdafitinib + cetrelimab cohort)
reasoning: Explicit exclusion: the trial disallows prior PD-1/PD-L1 therapy (except limited adjuvant/NMIBC), and the patient received pembrolizumab for metastatic disease. Despite disease and stage matching, this prior exposure makes the patient ineligible.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial carcinoma; Progressing after second line therapy; Prior neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Prior enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab with progression after 6 cycles; Status post cystectomy with pathologic complete response; Age 55 years; Male; Chronic kidney disease with eGFR 35 mL/min; History of type 2 diabetes mellitus; History of COPD
patient_prior_therapies: Neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin; Cystectomy; Enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab
judge_comment: The trial’s exclusion criteria explicitly disallow prior PD-1/PD-L1 therapy except limited adjuvant/NMIBC contexts. The patient received pembrolizumab for metastatic disease, triggering a hard exclusion. Disease, age, and sex otherwise match, but the explicit exclusion mandates grade F. The grader’s reasoning aligns with the rubric.

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: An Open-Label, Randomized Phase 3 Study to Evaluate Enfortumab Vedotin vs Chemotherapy in Subjects With Previously Treated Locally Advanced or Metastatic Urothelial Cancer (EV-301)
inclusion_criteria: Histologically or cytologically confirmed urothelial carcinoma of the bladder, renal pelvis, ureter, or urethra (including squamous differentiation or mixed types). | Radiographic progression or relapse during or after PD-1/PD-L1 checkpoint inhibitor for locally advanced or metastatic disease (progression after discontinuation due to toxicity allowed). | Received a platinum-containing regimen (cisplatin or carboplatin) in metastatic/locally advanced, neoadjuvant, or adjuvant setting; if adjuvant/neoadjuvant, progression within 12 months of completion. | Radiologically documented metastatic or locally advanced disease at baseline not amenable to curative resection. | ECOG 0–1. | ANC >= 1500/µL. | Platelet count >= 100000/µL. | Hemoglobin >= 9 g/dL. | Total bilirubin <= 1.5 x ULN (<= 3 x ULN with Gilbert's disease). | ALT <= 2.5 x ULN. | AST <= 2.5 x ULN. | Creatinine clearance >= 30 mL/min.
exclusion_criteria: Preexisting sensory or motor neuropathy grade >= 2. | Active central nervous system metastases (allowed if treated and clinically stable >= 6 weeks, no new or enlarged lesions, no leptomeningeal disease, and on <= 20 mg/day prednisone equivalent if steroids required). | Ongoing clinically significant toxicity grade >= 2 from prior therapy (except alopecia; <= grade 2 hypothyroidism or panhypopituitarism on replacement allowed). | Ongoing immunotherapy-related colitis, uveitis, or pneumonitis, or requirement for high-dose steroids > 20 mg/day prednisone equivalent. | Prior treatment with enfortumab vedotin or other MMAE-based antibody-drug conjugates. | Prior chemotherapy for urothelial cancer including all available control-arm agents (docetaxel and paclitaxel ± vinflunine depending on region). | More than 1 prior chemotherapy regimen for locally advanced or metastatic urothelial cancer (including adjuvant or neoadjuvant if recurrence within 12 months). | History of another malignancy within 3 years (exceptions include nonmelanoma skin cancer, certain localized prostate cancer, and carcinoma in situ completely resected). | Active systemic infection requiring antimicrobial therapy. | Active hepatitis B or active hepatitis C infection. | Known HIV infection. | Cerebrovascular event (stroke or TIA), unstable angina, myocardial infarction, or NYHA class III–IV heart failure within 6 months. | Radiotherapy or major surgery within 4 weeks before first dose. | Chemotherapy, biologics, investigational agents, or immunotherapy not completed >= 2 weeks before first dose. | Hypersensitivity to enfortumab vedotin or to biopharmaceuticals produced in CHO cells. | Hypersensitivity to docetaxel (including polysorbate 80), paclitaxel (including macrogolglycerol ricinoleate 35), or vinflunine (including other vinca alkaloids). | Active keratitis or corneal ulceration. | Other underlying medical condition that would impair ability to receive or tolerate treatment and follow-up. | Uncontrolled diabetes mellitus within 3 months (HbA1c >= 8% or HbA1c 7% to < 8% with polyuria or polydipsia).
prior_therapies: Prior PD-1/PD-L1 checkpoint inhibitor required for locally advanced or metastatic disease.; Prior platinum-containing regimen (cisplatin or carboplatin) required in metastatic/locally advanced, neoadjuvant, or adjuvant setting.; No more than 1 prior chemotherapy regimen for locally advanced or metastatic urothelial cancer.; Washout: radiotherapy or major surgery completed >= 4 weeks before first dose.; Washout: chemotherapy, biologics, investigational agents, or immunotherapy completed >= 2 weeks before first dose.
reasoning: The trial explicitly excludes prior treatment with enfortumab vedotin, which the patient has received. Therefore the patient is ineligible.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial carcinoma; Progressing after second line therapy; Prior neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Prior enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab with progression after 6 cycles; Status post cystectomy with pathologic complete response; Age 55 years; Male; Chronic kidney disease with eGFR 35 mL/min; History of type 2 diabetes mellitus; History of COPD
patient_prior_therapies: Neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin; Cystectomy; Enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab

question_text: A 55-year-old female has severe, seropositive rheumatoid arthritis refractory to methotrexate and two prior biologic agents (adalimumab and tocilizumab). She has active disease with a DAS28 score of 5.5. Critically, she has a history of treated Hepatitis B (HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive) and moderate chronic kidney disease with an eGFR of 45 mL/min/1.73m². What are trial options for her?
trial_title: Low Dose Naltrexone to Improve Physical Health in Patients With Vasculitis
diseases_targeted: Giant Cell Arteritis; Takayasu Arteritis; Polyarteritis Nodosa; Granulomatosis With Polyangiitis; Microscopic Polyangiitis; Eosinophilic Granulomatosis With Polyangiitis
inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of giant cell arteritis, Takayasu arteritis, polyarteritis nodosa, granulomatosis with polyangiitis, microscopic polyangiitis, or eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis per specified criteria | PROMIS Global Physical Health normalized score <= 40 at baseline | Vasculitis in remission or very low disease activity (Physician Global Assessment 0–1) for >= 12 weeks | Stable immunosuppressive therapy (including prednisone) related to vasculitis for >= 12 weeks | No change in medications in the past 12 weeks made with the expectation of improving pain, fatigue, or mood | No plan to change medication or non-pharmacologic treatment regimen likely to affect pain, fatigue, mood, or vasculitis activity during the next 12 weeks | Age >= 18 years
exclusion_criteria: Change in any medication related to control of vasculitis, pain, fatigue, or mood within the past 12 weeks | Use of another investigational agent within 30 days of enrollment | Current use of any opioid agonist including tramadol or buprenorphine/naloxone | Change in vasculitis activity in the past 12 weeks (change in Physician Global Assessment > 1) | Baseline PROMIS Global Physical Health normalized score > 40 | New major medical problem or surgery in the past 12 weeks | Pregnancy or breastfeeding | Schizophrenia or bipolar disorder | Poorly controlled depression or anxiety (PHQ-9 >= 20) | Liver cirrhosis | Significant kidney disease (GFR < 30 mL/min)

reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets specific vasculitides (e.g., GCA, GPA, MPA), while the patient has rheumatoid arthritis.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Seropositive rheumatoid arthritis; Active disease with DAS28 score of 5.5; History of treated Hepatitis B (HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive); Moderate chronic kidney disease (eGFR 45 mL/min/1.73 m^2)
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to methotrexate; Prior adalimumab; Prior tocilizumab; Failed two prior biologic agents
judge_comment: Correct: The patient has rheumatoid arthritis, while the trial includes only specific vasculitides. This is a hard disease mismatch per the rubric, warranting an immediate F.

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Pilot Study to Evaluate the Safety of Neoadjuvant Nivolumab Alone or in Combination With Ipilimumab for Cisplatin-Ineligible Patients With Muscle Invasive Bladder Cancer (CA209-9DJ)
diseases_targeted: Bladder Cancer (urothelial, muscle-invasive); Upper Tract Urothelial Carcinoma
inclusion_criteria: Histologically confirmed urothelial carcinoma of the bladder; variant histology allowed if predominantly urothelial. | Muscle-invasive bladder cancer (Cohorts 1–3): cT2–T4a cN0 cM0 by cystoscopy and imaging; cT4a with prostatic stromal invasion eligible without cystoscopic muscle invasion. | Upper tract urothelial carcinoma (Cohort U): High-grade urothelial carcinoma of ureter or renal pelvis with T2–T4a N0/x M0 and positive selective urinary cytology; hydronephrosis associated with tumor considered invasive; variant histology allowed if predominantly urothelial. | Cisplatin-ineligible: Creatinine clearance >= 30 mL/min and < 60 mL/min, or grade >= 2 hearing loss, or grade >= 2 peripheral neuropathy. | Availability of tumor block or 30 unstained slides from diagnosis of muscle-invasive disease (fewer allowed per PI discretion). | Karnofsky performance status >= 70%. | Medically appropriate candidate for radical cystectomy. | Age >= 18 years. | Baseline laboratory values meet protocol thresholds.
exclusion_criteria: Prior systemic chemotherapy for urothelial cancer. | Prior immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy for non–muscle-invasive bladder cancer. | Prior bladder-directed radiotherapy (Cohorts 1–3). | Active autoimmune disease excluding permitted conditions (e.g., type 1 diabetes, residual hypothyroidism on replacement, certain skin disorders not requiring systemic therapy, asymptomatic autoantibodies, or conditions not expected to recur). | Systemic corticosteroids > 10 mg/day prednisone equivalent or other immunosuppressive medications within 14 days of first dose (except inhaled/topical/adrenal replacement). | Unstable angina. | NYHA class II or greater congestive heart failure. | Myocardial infarction within 6 months. | Stroke within 6 months. | Bleeding diathesis or coagulopathy (therapeutic anticoagulation allowed if on stable dose). | Major surgical procedure within 28 days prior to study (TURBT permitted). | Serious, non-healing wound, ulcer, or bone fracture. | Another active malignancy within 2 years, except definitively treated early-stage cancers with negligible risk of recurrence. | Prior therapy targeting T-cell co-stimulation/checkpoint pathways (e.g., anti–PD-1, anti–PD-L1, anti–PD-L2, anti–CTLA-4, anti–CD137); prior IL-2 permitted. | Intravesical BCG within 6 weeks of treatment. | Positive hepatitis B surface antigen or positive hepatitis C RNA/antibody indicating infection. | Known HIV infection or AIDS. | History of severe hypersensitivity to monoclonal antibodies or study drug components. | Pregnant or breastfeeding. | Women of childbearing potential not using acceptable contraception during treatment and for at least 23 weeks after last dose. | Male subjects unwilling to use contraception during treatment and for at least 31 weeks after last dose.
prior_therapies: Intravesical BCG allowed with washout >= 6 weeks
reasoning: Ineligible: the trial is a neoadjuvant study for non-metastatic muscle-invasive bladder cancer, while the patient has metastatic disease after second-line therapy. Additionally, the protocol explicitly excludes prior systemic chemotherapy and prior PD-1/PD-L1 therapy, both of which the patient has received (gemcitabine/cisplatin and pembrolizumab).
patient_inclusion_criteria: Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial carcinoma; Progressing after second line therapy; Prior neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Prior enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab with progression after 6 cycles; Status post cystectomy with pathologic complete response; Age 55 years; Male; Chronic kidney disease with eGFR 35 mL/min; History of type 2 diabetes mellitus; History of COPD
patient_prior_therapies: Neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin; Cystectomy; Enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab
judge_comment: Correct F. The trial requires non-metastatic, neoadjuvant setting (cT2–T4a N0 M0, cystectomy candidate), which the patient definitively lacks (metastatic post–second-line). Additionally, explicit exclusions of prior systemic chemotherapy and prior PD-1 therapy apply. Multiple hard exclusions → F per rubric.

question_text: I have a 62-year-old male patient diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) 14 months ago. He has limb-onset disease and an ALSFRS-R score of 38. His forced vital capacity (FVC) is stable at 85% of predicted. He is currently taking riluzole. What trial options are available?
trial_title: Phase I/IIa Trial Evaluating scAAV1.tMCK.NTF3 for Treatment of Charcot-Marie-Tooth Neuropathy Type 1A (CMT1A)
inclusion_criteria: Age 18–35 years | Diagnosis of Charcot-Marie-Tooth Neuropathy Type 1A | 1.5 Mb duplication at 17p11.2 inclusive of the PMP22 gene | Weakness of ankle dorsiflexion muscle with full ROM against gravity and able to stand on heels >=3 seconds | Abnormal nerve conduction velocities
exclusion_criteria: Active viral infection (HIV, Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, herpesvirus, or adenovirus) | Ongoing immunosuppressive therapy or immunosuppressive therapy within 6 months (e.g., corticosteroids, cyclosporine, tacrolimus, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, intravenous immunoglobulin) | Persistent leukopenia or leukocytosis (WBC <=3.5 K/µL or >=15 K/µL) | Absolute neutrophil count <1.5 K/µL | AAV1 binding antibody titer >=1:50 | Circulating anti-NT-3 antibody titer >=1:50 | Investigational medication within 30 days before study drug | GGT >3 x ULN | Total bilirubin >=3.0 mg/dL | Creatinine >=1.8 mg/dL | Hemoglobin <8 g/dL or >18 g/dL | Ankle contractures or prior surgeries preventing proper muscle strength testing | Pregnancy or lactation | Limb surgery within the past 6 months | Severe infection (e.g., pneumonia, pyelonephritis, meningitis) within 4 weeks before gene transfer | Concomitant illness or chronic drug treatment that creates unnecessary risks for gene transfer, per investigator judgment
prior_therapies: No investigational medication within 30 days before study drug
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets Charcot-Marie-Tooth neuropathy type 1A (with PMP22 duplication), while the patient has ALS. Additionally, the patient is 62 years old, exceeding the trial’s 18–35 age window.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS); Limb-onset disease; ALSFRS-R score 38; Forced vital capacity (FVC) 85% of predicted; Currently taking riluzole; Time since diagnosis 14 months; Age 62 years; Male sex
judge_comment: Correct: Disease mismatch (ALS vs CMT1A) is a hard exclusion; additionally, the patient’s age (62) is outside the trial’s 18–35 window—another hard exclusion. Either triggers an F.

question_text: I have a 62-year-old male patient diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) 14 months ago. He has limb-onset disease and an ALSFRS-R score of 38. His forced vital capacity (FVC) is stable at 85% of predicted. He is currently taking riluzole. What trial options are available?

question_text: 36 female with stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma, who initially received optimal debulking and adjuvant carboplatin+paclitaxel +bevacizumab. After 5 months, she had a new pleural effusion that was cytology positive for ovarian carcinoma. She was found to be BRCA1 positive. What are trial options?

diseases_targeted: Low-Grade Serous Ovarian Carcinoma; Primary Peritoneal Carcinoma; Fallopian Tube Carcinoma
inclusion_criteria: Stage III or IV low-grade serous ovarian, primary peritoneal, or fallopian tube carcinoma deemed unlikely to be optimally cytoreduced and recommended for neoadjuvant therapy | Histologic diagnosis confirmed by surgical or core biopsy | Measurable disease by RECIST v1.1 | Women aged >= 18 years | ECOG performance status 0–1 | Resolution of acute toxic effects of prior therapy or surgery to CTCAE v4.03 grade <= 1 | Pre/perimenopausal women amenable to treatment with goserelin
exclusion_criteria: Pregnant or breastfeeding | Serious preexisting medical conditions precluding participation (e.g., interstitial lung disease, severe dyspnea at rest or requiring oxygen therapy, history of major gastric or small bowel resection, Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis, or baseline grade >= 2 diarrhea) | Current use of potent CYP3A4 inhibitors or inducers | Current use of drugs known to prolong the QT interval | Another malignancy within 3 years except adequately treated basal or squamous cell skin cancer or carcinoma in situ of the cervix | Previous chemotherapy or hormonal therapy for ovarian cancer | Known hepatitis B, hepatitis C, or HIV infection | Inability or unwillingness to swallow pills | Active infection requiring IV antibiotics or other uncontrolled intercurrent illness requiring hospitalization | History of syncope of cardiovascular etiology, ventricular arrhythmia, or sudden cardiac arrest | Prior hematopoietic stem cell or bone marrow transplantation | Coagulation abnormalities or anticoagulant therapy precluding intramuscular injections | Hypersensitivity to fulvestrant or abemaciclib or their excipients | Pre/perimenopausal women with hypersensitivity to GnRH agonists
prior_therapies: Resolution of prior therapy or surgical toxicities to CTCAE v4.03 grade <=1

patient_inclusion_criteria: Stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma; BRCA1 positive; Optimal debulking surgery performed; Received adjuvant carboplatin + paclitaxel + bevacizumab; Cytology-positive malignant pleural effusion at 5 months post-adjuvant
patient_prior_therapies: Carboplatin; Paclitaxel; Bevacizumab; Optimal debulking surgery
judge_comment: Hard exclusion applies: disease mismatch (clear cell vs low‑grade serous) and explicit exclusion of any prior ovarian chemotherapy, which the patient has received. The grader correctly assigned F and cited appropriate reasons.

prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: The trial explicitly excludes individuals with a history of dementia, which the patient has. This is a hard exclusion regardless of other factors.
patient_biomarkers: Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau

question_text: I have a 62-year-old male patient diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) 14 months ago. He has limb-onset disease and an ALSFRS-R score of 38. His forced vital capacity (FVC) is stable at 85% of predicted. He is currently taking riluzole. What trial options are available?
trial_title: A Prospective Open-label Study to Assess Efficacy and Safety of RT001 in Subjects With Infantile Neuroaxonal Dystrophy
inclusion_criteria: Age 18 months to 10 years | Medical history consistent with classic infantile neuroaxonal dystrophy (onset of symptoms between 6 months and 3 years) | Homozygous for PLA2G6 deficiency (variant alleles may be mixed heterozygotes) | Impairment in at least 2 assessed categories at baseline
exclusion_criteria: Received treatment with other experimental therapies within the last 30 days prior to the first dose | Requiring mechanical ventilation, other than positive air pressure support for sleep apnea | Life expectancy < 1 year | Diagnosis of atypical neuroaxonal dystrophy (ANAD)
prior_therapies: Washout >= 30 days from other experimental therapies before first dose
reasoning: Hard exclusion: the trial targets infantile neuroaxonal dystrophy (not ALS) and restricts age to 18 months–10 years, while the patient is 62.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS); Limb-onset disease; ALSFRS-R score 38; Forced vital capacity (FVC) 85% of predicted; Currently taking riluzole; Time since diagnosis 14 months; Age 62 years; Male sex
judge_comment: Disease mismatch (ALS vs Infantile Neuroaxonal Dystrophy) and age window conflict (62 years vs 18 months–10 years) are both hard exclusions. Grade F is correct and reasoning is appropriate.

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: Phase Ib Trial of Pembrolizumab (MK-3475) With Platinum-Based Chemotherapy in Small Cell/Neuroendocrine Cancers of Urothelium and Prostate
diseases_targeted: Small Cell Bladder Carcinoma; Small Cell Urethral Carcinoma; Small Cell Ureter Carcinoma; Small Cell Prostate Carcinoma; Prostate Neuroendocrine Neoplasm
inclusion_criteria: Histologically confirmed locally advanced or metastatic small cell cancer of the bladder, urethra, or upper urinary tract, or primary small cell/neuroendocrine prostate cancer | Measurable disease per RECIST 1.1 | Archival or newly obtained tumor tissue available (FFPE preferred) | ECOG performance status 0–1 | Adequate hematologic and organ function per protocol labs
exclusion_criteria: Disease suitable for curative local therapy | Prior therapy with anti-PD-1, anti-PD-L1, anti-PD-L2, or other T-cell co-regulatory agents (e.g., CTLA-4, OX40, CD137) | Prior systemic anticancer therapy within 4 weeks before first dose or unresolved toxicities > grade 1 (except <= grade 2 neuropathy) | Major surgery without adequate recovery prior to study treatment | Radiotherapy within 2 weeks before start of study treatment (1-week washout allowed for palliative <= 2 weeks non-CNS radiation) | Live vaccine within 30 days before first dose | Participation in another investigational study or use of an investigational device within 4 weeks before first dose | Immunodeficiency or chronic systemic steroids > 10 mg prednisone equivalent daily or other immunosuppressive therapy within 7 days before first dose | Another active malignancy requiring treatment within the past 3 years (except certain skin cancers or carcinoma in situ) | Active CNS metastases or carcinomatous meningitis (previously treated stable brain metastases allowed without steroids) | Severe hypersensitivity to pembrolizumab | Active autoimmune disease requiring systemic treatment within the past 2 years | History of pneumonitis requiring steroids or current pneumonitis | Active infection requiring systemic therapy | Known HIV infection | Active hepatitis B or active hepatitis C infection | Active tuberculosis | Pregnant or breastfeeding
prior_therapies: Cohort 1: No prior systemic chemotherapy for locally advanced/metastatic urothelial carcinoma; prior platinum-based chemotherapy allowed if recurrence > 12 months after completion; Cohort 2: No prior systemic chemotherapy for primary small cell prostate cancer; prior platinum-based chemotherapy allowed if recurrence > 12 months after completion; Cohort 2: Prior mCRPC treatments allowed, including up to 2 prior chemotherapy agents if > 6 months since last dose (docetaxel used twice counts as 1 therapy); Cohort 2: Ongoing androgen deprivation therapy with up to 2 second-generation hormonal agents (e.g., abiraterone, enzalutamide) permitted; Cohort 2: Ongoing bone-targeted therapy (denosumab or zoledronic acid) permitted; Cohort 2: Prior sipuleucel-T allowed if completed > 4 weeks before enrollment; Washout: No systemic anticancer therapy (including investigational agents) within 4 weeks before first dose; Washout: No radiotherapy within 2 weeks before start (1-week washout allowed for palliative <= 2 weeks non-CNS)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial requires small cell/neuroendocrine bladder/urothelial/prostate cancer, while the patient has metastatic urothelial carcinoma without small cell histology. Additionally, the trial excludes prior PD-1 therapy and the patient received pembrolizumab.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial carcinoma; Progressing after second line therapy; Prior neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Prior enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab with progression after 6 cycles; Status post cystectomy with pathologic complete response; Age 55 years; Male; Chronic kidney disease with eGFR 35 mL/min; History of type 2 diabetes mellitus; History of COPD
patient_prior_therapies: Neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin; Cystectomy; Enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab
judge_comment: Correct: Hard exclusions apply. The trial targets small cell/neuroendocrine variants (disease mismatch with metastatic urothelial carcinoma) and explicitly excludes prior PD-1 therapy; the patient received pembrolizumab. Either alone warrants an F.

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: Phase II Study of Radiation Therapy and Anti-PD-L1 Checkpoint Inhibitor (Durvalumab) With or Without Anti-CTLA-4 Inhibition (Tremelimumab) in Patients With Unresectable, Locally Advanced, or Metastatic Urothelial Bladder Cancer That Are Ineligible or Refusing Chemotherapy
inclusion_criteria: cT2–T4 or metastatic (N+ or M+) urothelial bladder cancer; mixed histology allowed if predominantly urothelial. | Localized disease: patient refuses cystectomy or is not an ideal cystectomy candidate. | If metastatic: intact, symptomatic bladder tumor appropriate for palliative bladder RT. | Measurable metastatic disease per RECIST v1.1 (>=1 non-irradiated lesion; longest diameter >=10 mm or lymph node short axis >=15 mm). | ECOG performance status 0–1. | Life expectancy >= 12 weeks. | Ineligible for or refusal of cisplatin-based chemotherapy (CrCl < 60 mL/min, CTCAE grade >=2 hearing loss, CTCAE grade >=2 peripheral neuropathy, NYHA class III heart failure, or other investigator-determined reason). | Provision of archived tumor tissue within 12 months or willingness to undergo pre-treatment fresh tumor biopsy; additional older archival tissue requested if available. | Hemoglobin >= 9.0 g/dL. | ANC >= 1500/µL. | Platelets >= 100000/µL. | Total bilirubin <= 1.5 x ULN (Gilbert syndrome allowed per physician). | AST/ALT <= 2.5 x ULN (<= 5 x ULN if liver metastases). | Creatinine clearance > 30 mL/min (Cockcroft-Gault or 24-hour collection). | Women of childbearing potential: negative pregnancy test; or non-reproductive potential as defined.
exclusion_criteria: ECOG performance status >=2. | Prior cystectomy or definitive radiotherapy to the bladder. | Active or prior autoimmune or inflammatory disorders (e.g., myasthenia gravis, autoimmune hepatitis, SLE, rheumatoid arthritis, IBD, sarcoidosis, vasculitis, multiple sclerosis) with specified exceptions. | HIV infection, active hepatitis B or active hepatitis C (exceptions for resolved/past HBV and HCV RNA-negative). | History of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, organizing pneumonia, drug-induced or idiopathic pneumonitis, or active pneumonitis on screening imaging. | Prior radiation therapy to the abdomen or pelvis, including bladder, prostate, or rectum. | Concurrent systemic chemotherapy, biologic, or hormonal therapy for cancer treatment (non-cancer hormonal therapy allowed). | Major surgery within 28 days before first dose (biopsy and TURBT allowed). | Another primary malignancy not meeting allowed exceptions. | QTcF >= 470 ms or clinically significant ECG abnormalities. | Current or prior immunosuppressive medication within 14 days before first dose (with specified corticosteroid exceptions). | History of primary immunodeficiency. | History of allogeneic organ transplant. | Hypersensitivity to durvalumab, tremelimumab, or their combination/excipients. | Uncontrolled intercurrent illness (e.g., infection, CHF, uncontrolled hypertension, unstable angina, arrhythmia, active PUD/gastritis, bleeding diathesis, psychiatric/social conditions limiting compliance). | Active infection including tuberculosis. | History of leptomeningeal carcinomatosis. | Receipt of live attenuated vaccine within 30 days before study entry or within 30 days of receiving study drugs. | Brain metastases or spinal cord compression unless stable, asymptomatic, and off steroids for >=14 days prior to treatment. | Uncontrolled seizures. | Pregnant or breastfeeding; unwilling to use effective contraception for the required period.
prior_therapies: Prior systemic therapies allowed with washout >= 45 days
reasoning: The trial explicitly excludes patients with prior cystectomy, and this patient underwent cystectomy. Additionally, the metastatic cohort requires an intact symptomatic bladder tumor for palliative RT, which the patient lacks.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial carcinoma; Progressing after second line therapy; Prior neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Prior enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab with progression after 6 cycles; Status post cystectomy with pathologic complete response; Age 55 years; Male; Chronic kidney disease with eGFR 35 mL/min; History of type 2 diabetes mellitus; History of COPD
patient_prior_therapies: Neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin; Cystectomy; Enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab
judge_comment: Correct F: The trial’s exclusion criteria list prior cystectomy, which the patient has—a hard exclusion. Additionally, the metastatic cohort requires an intact symptomatic bladder tumor for palliative RT, which the patient lacks. Either point warrants F per rubric.

question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. trial_title: Phase II RCT of High-dose Vitamin D Supplements in Older Adults
diseases_targeted: Mild Cognitive Impairment; Alzheimer Disease (mild); Vitamin D Deficiency
inclusion_criteria: Age 65-90 years | Serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D < 20 ng/mL at screening | Fluent in English or Spanish | Willingness to be randomized to high-dose vs standard-dose vitamin D | Education-adjusted Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MOCA) score 12-30 at baseline | Consensus clinical diagnosis of No Cognitive Impairment, Mild Cognitive Impairment, or mild Alzheimer disease dementia | No Cognitive Impairment subgroup: MOCA >= 23 if education > 12 years or MOCA > 20 if education < 12 years | No Cognitive Impairment subgroup: CDR global usually 0; CDR may be 0.5 if Petersen MCI criteria not met and CDR-Sum of Boxes < 1.0 | Mild Cognitive Impairment subgroup: Amnestic MCI (single- or multiple-domain) with standardized memory scores > 1.5 SDs below average | Mild Cognitive Impairment subgroup: Global CDR = 0.5 | Mild Cognitive Impairment subgroup: MOCA > 20 if education > 12 years or MOCA > 17 if education < 12 years | Mild Alzheimer disease dementia subgroup: Probable or possible Alzheimer disease | Mild Alzheimer disease dementia subgroup: Global CDR = 1 | Mild Alzheimer disease dementia subgroup: MOCA > 15 if education > 12 years or MOCA > 12 if education < 12 years | Stable doses (> 6 weeks) of Alzheimer disease therapies (e.g., donepezil, memantine) permitted with no planned dose changes during the trial
exclusion_criteria: Inadequate vision, hearing, or literacy to complete psychometric testing | Albumin < 3.3 g/dL | Alanine aminotransferase > 2 x ULN | Bilirubin > 2 x ULN | Aspartate aminotransferase > 3 x ULN | Serum creatinine > 1.7 mg/dL | Glomerular filtration rate < 40 mL/min/1.73 m2 | Hypercalcemia | Current serious or unstable medical illness that could interfere with safe participation or life expectancy < 4 years | History of recurrent renal stones | Unable to undergo MRI scanning | History of osteoporosis with screening 25-hydroxyvitamin D < 12 ng/mL | History of chronic psychiatric illness (e.g., schizophrenia, bipolar disorder) | Major depression within the last 2 years or current GDS > 6 | Recent suicide attempt or suicidal ideation | Serious infectious disease affecting the brain within 5 years | Head trauma within 5 years with > 10 minutes loss of consciousness or persistent cognitive deficit | Chronic alcohol or drug abuse/dependence within the past 5 years | Primary or recurrent malignant disease within the last 5 years (except resected cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma in situ, basal cell carcinoma, cervical carcinoma in situ, or non-metastatic prostate cancer with normal PSA post-treatment) | Poor venous access precluding multiple blood draws | Regular use of benzodiazepines | Regular use of antipsychotics | Regular use of narcotics | Regular use of cholinesterase inhibitors (non-stable dosing) | Regular use of memantine (non-stable dosing) | Regular use of anti-epileptic drugs | Planned changes in doses of CNS-active medications during the trial | Plans to change dosage of any vitamin supplement during the study (unless to treat a documented deficiency) | Current participation in a clinical trial involving experimental Alzheimer disease therapies | Pregnancy or planning pregnancy during the trial | Inability to swallow oral capsules | History of multiple strokes | More than two incidental infarcts on structural MRI
prior_therapies: Stable acetylcholinesterase inhibitor therapy >= 6 weeks allowed; Stable memantine therapy >= 6 weeks allowed; Stable SSRI or SNRI antidepressant doses allowed
reasoning: The trial only includes participants with no impairment, MCI, or mild Alzheimer disease dementia, whereas the patient has moderate-stage dementia (MMSE 19), a required stage mismatch. The trial also requires vitamin D deficiency (<20 ng/mL), which is not documented.
patient_biomarkers: Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 68 years; Male; Progressive cognitive decline for 2 years; MMSE score 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
judge_comment: F is appropriate due to hard disease/cohort mismatch: the trial only enrolls no impairment/MCI/mild Alzheimer’s dementia, while the patient has moderate dementia—no trial cohort fits. Age/sex are fine; vitamin D deficiency is required but unknown and should not drive F. The grader’s rationale correctly focused on the stage/cohort exclusion, yielding F.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 11-year-old boy with Duchenne muscular dystrophy confirmed by a deletion of exons 49-50. exclusion_criteria: Clinical history of bleeding or abnormal PT/PTT | Hepatic insufficiency with LFTs > 2 x ULN | Renal insufficiency requiring dialysis | Concurrent inborn error of metabolism (other than TK2 deficiency) | Severe end-organ hypoperfusion secondary to cardiac failure resulting in lactic acidosis
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: This study enrolls patients with genetically confirmed TK2 deficiency, while the patient has Duchenne muscular dystrophy with a DMD exon 49-50 deletion. Therefore, there is a disease mismatch (hard exclusion).
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 11 years; Male sex; Duchenne muscular dystrophy confirmed by deletion of exons 49-50; Non-ambulatory (lost ambulation 8 months ago); Power wheelchair dependent; Stable deflazacort regimen; Early cardiomyopathy with LVEF 52%; Performance of Upper Limb (PUL) score 18

exclusion_criteria: Concurrent significant injuries to other bones or organs | Local infection | Minors or vulnerable subjects | Allergy to glucocorticoids | Daily use of glucocorticoids | Chronic opioid use prior to injury | Severe heart disease (NYHA 2) | Renal failure | Liver dysfunction | Active peptic ulcer disease | Diabetic neuropathy | Rheumatoid arthritis | Neurological diseases potentially influencing pain perception | Psychiatric diseases potentially influencing pain perception | Pregnancy | Pre-existing immunosuppression | Non-compliance risk per investigator judgment

patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to methotrexate; Prior adalimumab; Prior tocilizumab; Failed two prior biologic agents

patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to methotrexate; Prior adalimumab; Prior tocilizumab; Failed two prior biologic agents
judge_comment: Correct: There is a hard disease mismatch (RA vs JIA) and a hard age exclusion (trial 2–17 years; patient 55). Either triggers F.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: A Multi-Center Randomized Trial of Transanastomotic Tube for Proximal Esophageal Atresia With Distal Tracheoesophageal Fistula Repair
inclusion_criteria: Infants diagnosed with type C esophageal atresia (proximal esophageal atresia with distal tracheoesophageal fistula) | Primary repair of the esophageal atresia within the first 6 months of life
exclusion_criteria: Other types of esophageal atresia without esophageal anastomosis creation | Major anomaly that influences likelihood of developing the primary outcome or affects surgical treatment considerations
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets infants with esophageal atresia/tracheoesophageal fistula, not Crohn's disease. Additionally, the trial age range is up to 6 months, while the patient is 32 years old.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease; CDAI score 350; Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab; Active perianal fistula with draining seton in place; Recently completed IV antibiotics for perianal abscess
judge_comment: Correct: There is a hard disease mismatch (trial targets esophageal atresia/TEF, not Crohn’s) and an age hard exclusion (trial <=6 months; patient is 32 years). Either triggers F. Reasoning appropriately identifies these factors.

question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.
trial_title: The Brain Health Champion Study: Promoting Non-pharmacological Interventions in Cognitive Disorders and Those at Risk
diseases_targeted: Mild Cognitive Impairment; Mild Dementia; Subjective Cognitive Decline
inclusion_criteria: Age 60–79 years | Neurology participants: Diagnosis of Subjective Cognitive Disorder; Mild Cognitive Impairment due to Alzheimer disease, cerebrovascular disease, or mixed AD/CVD; or mild dementia due to AD, CVD, or mixed AD/CVD. | Primary care participants: CAIDE dementia risk score >= 6, or CAIDE = 5 plus a first-degree relative with ADRD, or type 2 diabetes or prediabetes (A1C >= 5.7).
exclusion_criteria: Enrolled in another health behavior or non-pharmacologic intervention for a neurocognitive disorder. | Unable or unwilling to carry out regular physical exercise multiple times weekly. | Not recommended to participate by their Internist/Primary Care Provider due to health-related concerns.
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: The trial restricts neurology participants to mild dementia/MCI/SCD, and the patient has moderate-stage dementia (MMSE 19), which is a required stage mismatch. Although age and sex fit, the disease stage is outside the trial’s included cohorts.
patient_biomarkers: Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 68 years; Male; Progressive cognitive decline for 2 years; MMSE score 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
judge_comment: Trial explicitly requires mild dementia/MCI/SCD (or risk cohort), while patient has moderate dementia, a required stage mismatch constituting a hard exclusion. Age/sex fit, but stage requirement is not met, so F is correct.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 11-year-old boy with Duchenne muscular dystrophy confirmed by a deletion of exons 49-50. He lost ambulation 8 months ago and is now dependent on a power wheelchair. He is on a stable regimen of deflazacort and lisinopril for early cardiomyopathy (LVEF 52%). His Performance of Upper Limb (PUL) score is 18. His parents are interested in trials for non-ambulatory patients.
trial_title: An Open-Label Study of Risdiplam in Infants With Genetically Diagnosed and Presymptomatic Spinal Muscular Atrophy
inclusion_criteria: Age from birth to 6 weeks at first dose | Gestational age 37-42 weeks for singletons or 34-42 weeks for twins | Body weight >= 3rd percentile for age | Genetic diagnosis of 5q-autosomal recessive SMA with SMN1 homozygous deletion or compound heterozygosity predictive of loss of function | No clinical signs or symptoms of SMA at screening or baseline | Adequate nutrition and hydration at screening | Adequately recovered from any acute illness at baseline
exclusion_criteria: Prior or concomitant participation in any investigational drug or device study | Prior or concomitant SMN2-targeting antisense oligonucleotide, SMN2-splicing modifier, or gene therapy | Significant concurrent syndromes or diseases | Inadequate venous or capillary blood access for study procedures | Requirement for invasive ventilation, tracheostomy, or awake non-invasive ventilation | Awake hypoxemia (SaO2 < 95%) | Multiple or fixed contractures and/or hip subluxation or dislocation at birth | Clinically significant systolic or diastolic blood pressure or heart rate abnormalities | Clinically relevant ECG abnormalities; QTc (Bazett) > 460 ms; personal or first-degree family history of congenital long QT syndrome | Use of CYP3A4 inhibitors within 2 weeks, CYP3A4 inducers within 4 weeks, OCT2 or MATE substrates within 2 weeks, or known FMO1/FMO3 inhibitors or substrates (including maternal exposure if breastfeeding) | Clinically significant abnormal laboratory test results | Hypersensitivity to risdiplam or its excipients | Treatment with oral salbutamol or other oral beta-2 adrenergic agonists for SMA (inhaled beta-2 agonists allowed) | Exposure during pregnancy/lactation to drugs with known retinal toxicity or anticipated need for retinal-toxic drugs during the study | Diagnosis of ophthalmic diseases
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets presymptomatic 5q spinal muscular atrophy, while the patient has Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Also, the age window is birth to 6 weeks, and the patient is 11 years old.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 11 years; Male sex; Duchenne muscular dystrophy confirmed by deletion of exons 49-50; Non-ambulatory (lost ambulation 8 months ago); Power wheelchair dependent; Stable deflazacort regimen; Early cardiomyopathy with LVEF 52%; Performance of Upper Limb (PUL) score 18
judge_comment: Disease mismatch (DMD vs SMA) and strict age window mismatch (birth–6 weeks vs 11 years) are hard exclusions, so F is correct. The grader correctly identified these factors.
