question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.
trial_title: A Placebo-Controlled, Double-Blind, Parallel-Group, 18-Month Study With an Open-Label Extension Phase to Confirm Safety and Efficacy of BAN2401 in Subjects With Early Alzheimer's Disease
inclusion_criteria: MCI due to Alzheimer's disease meeting NIA-AA core clinical criteria (intermediate likelihood) | Global CDR = 0.5 and CDR Memory Box >= 0.5 at Screening and Baseline (for MCI cohort) | Probable Alzheimer's disease dementia (mild) meeting NIA-AA core clinical criteria | Global CDR 0.5–1.0 and CDR Memory Box >= 0.5 at Screening and Baseline (for mild AD dementia cohort) | Objective episodic memory impairment: WMS-IV Logical Memory II at least 1 SD below age-adjusted mean | Positive biomarker for brain amyloid pathology | Age >= 50 and <= 90 years | MMSE score >= 22 and <= 30 at Screening and Baseline | BMI > 17 and < 35 at Screening | If on acetylcholinesterase inhibitor or memantine, must be on a stable dose for >= 12 weeks prior to Baseline
exclusion_criteria: Any neurological condition contributing to cognitive impairment beyond Alzheimer's disease | History of transient ischemic attack, stroke, or seizures within 12 months of Screening | Psychiatric diagnosis or symptoms that could interfere with study procedures (e.g., hallucinations, major depression, delusions) | Geriatric Depression Scale score >= 8 at Screening | Contraindications to MRI scanning (e.g., pacemaker/defibrillator, ferromagnetic implants not approved for MRI) | Clinically significant brain MRI lesions suggesting non-AD dementia | More than 4 microhemorrhages (<= 10 mm), a single macrohemorrhage > 10 mm, superficial siderosis, vasogenic edema on MRI | Evidence on MRI of cerebral contusion, encephalomalacia, aneurysm, vascular malformation, infective lesion, multiple lacunar infarcts, major territorial stroke, severe small vessel disease, severe white matter disease, space-occupying lesion, or brain tumor (except meningioma or arachnoid cyst < 1 cm) | Immunological disease not adequately controlled or requiring treatment with immunoglobulins, systemic monoclonal antibodies (or derivatives), systemic immunosuppressants, or plasmapheresis during the study | Bleeding disorder not adequately controlled, including platelet count < 50,000/µL or INR > 1.5 if not on anticoagulant treatment | Other significant uncontrolled medical conditions (cardiac, respiratory, gastrointestinal, renal) that could affect safety or assessments | Participation in a clinical study with any therapeutic monoclonal antibody, antibody-derived protein, immunoglobulin therapy, or vaccine within 6 months before Screening unless randomized to placebo | Participation in a clinical study with any anti-amyloid therapy (including monoclonal antibodies or BACE inhibitors) unless only placebo was received | Any known prior exposure to lecanemab | Participation in a clinical study with any new chemical entity for Alzheimer's disease within 6 months prior to Screening unless in a placebo arm | Hypersensitivity to lecanemab (BAN2401) or any monoclonal antibody treatment | Malignant neoplasms not stably and adequately controlled (except basal/squamous cell carcinoma in situ of skin or localized prostate cancer) | Severe visual or hearing impairment preventing accurate psychometric testing
prior_therapies: Stable dose of acetylcholinesterase inhibitor and/or memantine for >= 12 weeks prior to Baseline (treatment-naive also allowed); For autoinjector substudy: at least 6 months prior exposure to lecanemab 10 mg/kg IV biweekly or lecanemab Dose 1 subcutaneous weekly; For subcutaneous Dose 3 autoinjector substudy: prior lecanemab (IV and/or SC) and completion of Extension Week 79 or later

question_text: What are trial options for a 66 year old male with hx hypertension, afib, T2DM and mCRPC, now progressing on enzalutamide? trial_title: A Single-Arm, Open-Label, Phase II Study of Systemic and Tumor Directed Therapy for Recurrent Oligometastatic M1 Prostate Cancer
diseases_targeted: Metastatic Prostate Adenocarcinoma; Prostate Adenocarcinoma With Focal Neuroendocrine Differentiation; Recurrent Prostate Carcinoma; Prostate Cancer (Stage IVB)
inclusion_criteria: Histologically confirmed prostate adenocarcinoma after radical prostatectomy (adenocarcinoma with neuroendocrine differentiation allowed; primary small cell not allowed) | 1–5 visible metastases by PSMA PET-CT | At least one metastasis M1a–M1b | No visceral metastases | Any number of pelvic nodal metastases allowed if largest < 2 cm | Metastases amenable to SBRT | Biopsy of one metastasis attempted unless unsafe | Fit to undergo SBRT to all visible sites and ADT | Total testosterone > 150 ng/dL prior to ADT | ECOG 0–1 | Hemoglobin >= 9.0 g/dL (independent of transfusion/growth factors within 3 months) | Platelet count >= 100,000/µL (independent of transfusion/growth factors within 3 months) | Serum albumin >= 3.0 g/dL | Glomerular filtration rate >= 45 mL/min | Serum potassium >= 3.5 mmol/L | Total bilirubin <= 1.5 x ULN (Gilbert syndrome exception allowed if direct bilirubin <= 1.5 x ULN) | AST or ALT <= 2.5 x ULN | Medications that lower seizure threshold discontinued or substituted >= 4 weeks prior to study entry
exclusion_criteria: Evidence of spinal cord compression (radiologic or clinical) | Prior pelvic malignancy | Prior pelvic radiation aside from salvage prostate radiation | Concurrent malignancy aside from superficial skin cancers or superficial bladder tumors | Inability to undergo radiotherapy or ADT | Primary small cell carcinoma of the prostate | Inflammatory bowel disease or active collagen vascular disease | History of seizure or condition predisposing to seizure | Prior stroke within 1 year prior to randomization | Brain arteriovenous malformation, Schwannoma, meningioma, or other benign CNS/meningeal disease which may require surgery or radiotherapy | Severe or unstable angina within 6 months prior to randomization | Myocardial infarction within 6 months prior to randomization | Symptomatic congestive heart failure within 6 months prior to randomization | Arterial or venous thromboembolic events within 6 months prior to randomization | Clinically significant ventricular arrhythmias within 6 months prior to randomization | Uncontrolled hypertension | Gastrointestinal disorder affecting absorption | Active infection including HIV or viral hepatitis | Chronic corticosteroid requirement > 10 mg prednisone/prednisolone once daily | Concomitant strong CYP3A4 inducers | Treatment with CYP2D6 substrates with a narrow therapeutic index (unless an alternative or dose reduction is used) | Baseline moderate or severe hepatic impairment (Child-Pugh Class B or C) | Presence of visceral metastases (M1c)
prior_therapies: Discontinue or substitute medications that lower the seizure threshold >= 4 weeks before study entry
reasoning: The trial explicitly excludes patients with visceral metastases (M1c), and the patient has liver metastases. Therefore, they fail a hard exclusion criterion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 66 years; Male; Castration-resistant prostate cancer; Metastatic disease; PSMA PET avid disease; Liver metastases; Bone metastases; Progression on enzalutamide; Prior abiraterone (Zytiga); Prior leuprolide (Lupron)
judge_comment: The trial explicitly excludes patients with visceral metastases (M1c). The patient has liver metastases, a visceral site, triggering a hard exclusion. The grader correctly assigned F with appropriate reasoning.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. Are there any trial options?

inclusion_criteria: Histologically confirmed non-small cell lung cancer, Stage IV | BRAF V600 mutation in tumor (V600E; V600K/D allowed) | Treatment-naive or one prior line of systemic therapy for advanced/metastatic disease | Measurable disease per RECIST v1.1 | ECOG performance status 0–1 | Adequate bone marrow, hepatic, and renal function
exclusion_criteria: EGFR mutation, ALK fusion, or ROS1 rearrangement | More than one prior line of systemic therapy in the advanced/metastatic setting | Prior treatment with any BRAF inhibitor | Prior treatment with any MEK inhibitor | Impaired cardiovascular function or clinically significant cardiovascular disease | Thromboembolic or cerebrovascular events within 12 weeks prior to first dose | History or current evidence of retinal vein occlusion or risk factors for RVO | History of retinal degenerative disease | Concurrent neuromuscular disorder associated with elevated CK | Symptomatic brain metastases, leptomeningeal disease, or other active CNS metastases
prior_therapies: Treatment-naive allowed; One prior line with platinum-based chemotherapy allowed; One prior line with PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitor allowed
reasoning: The trial explicitly excludes patients with EGFR mutations, and this patient has an EGFR exon 19 deletion. It also requires a BRAF V600 mutation, which is not documented for this patient.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 40 years; Male; Metastatic non-small cell lung cancer; De novo metastatic disease; Bone metastases; Liver metastases; Brain metastases on MRI; EGFR exon 19 deletion; On osimertinib for 2 years; ECOG 0; No significant comorbidities
judge_comment: Correct: Trial explicitly excludes EGFR-mutant NSCLC, and the patient has an EGFR exon 19 deletion. That is a hard exclusion, warranting grade F. The note about required BRAF V600 (unknown for patient) is ancillary and not needed for F.

question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 68 years; Male; Progressive cognitive decline for 2 years; MMSE score 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. inclusion_criteria: Histologically or cytologically confirmed nonsquamous non-small cell lung cancer | Stage IV nonsquamous non-small cell lung cancer | EGFR/ALK/ROS1-directed therapy not indicated | Measurable disease per RECIST 1.1 | Archival or newly obtained tumor tissue available; adequate sample confirmation by central lab | Life expectancy >= 3 months | ECOG performance status 0 or 1 | No prior systemic treatment for advanced/metastatic NSCLC | Adequate organ function

patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 40 years; Male; Metastatic non-small cell lung cancer; De novo metastatic disease; Bone metastases; Liver metastases; Brain metastases on MRI; EGFR exon 19 deletion; On osimertinib for 2 years; ECOG 0; No significant comorbidities

judge_comment: Correct: The trial explicitly requires no prior systemic therapy for advanced/metastatic NSCLC, while the patient has received osimertinib for metastatic disease—this is a hard exclusion, yielding F. The squamous histology requirement is unknown for the patient and would not alone trigger F, but the prior-therapy conflict already does.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: Fecal Microbiota Transplantation (FMT) for Immune-Checkpoint Inhibitor Induced-Diarrhea/Colitis in Genitourinary Cancer Patients
diseases_targeted: Breast Cancer; Cervical Cancer; Colitis; Diarrhea; Lung Cancer; Malignant Genitourinary System Neoplasm; Melanoma; Ovarian Cancer; Uterine Cancer
inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of malignancy in genitourinary, melanoma, non-melanoma skin, lung, head and neck, sarcoma/lymphoma, gastrointestinal (luminal GI, hepatobiliary, pancreas), gynecologic (ovarian, uterine, cervical), or breast cancer | Treatment with any immune checkpoint inhibitor (ICPI) agent(s) | New onset of >= grade 2 ICPI-induced diarrhea and/or colitis within 45 days prior to FMT, without involvement of non-GI toxicity | Prior steroid use allowed if last dose > 30 days before FMT or treatment duration < 7 days beyond one week prior to FMT | Prior immunosuppressant (e.g., infliximab, vedolizumab) use allowed if last dose >= 3 months prior when used for conditions other than ICI-induced GI toxicities | No active concomitant GI infection at initiation of protocol therapy as confirmed by stool tests or treating physician assessment | Cleared for enrollment by Infectious Diseases consultant or treating physician if positive infection workup or screening tests prior to therapy | Life expectancy > 6 months
exclusion_criteria: Age < 18 years | Persistent GI infection with positive stool test(s) despite completing 5 days of antibiotics before protocol therapy | History of inflammatory bowel disease or radiation enteritis/colitis with active disease at treatment initiation | Pregnant or breastfeeding | Positive urine or serum pregnancy test or refusal to test unless clearly peri- or post-menopausal or objective evidence of no pregnancy within 30 days prior to treatment | Immunosuppressive treatment at onset of ICPI-induced diarrhea/colitis | Medical conditions high risk for colonoscopy (e.g., severe heart failure, brain hemorrhage, septic shock) | Concurrent non-GI toxicity at time of study treatment | Donors at risk for monkeypox infection or exposure
prior_therapies: Prior treatment with any ICPI agent(s) required; Prior corticosteroids permitted with washout/restrictions as specified; Prior immunosuppressants (e.g., infliximab, vedolizumab) permitted if last dose >= 3 months and used for non-ICI GI indications
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets ICPI-induced diarrhea/colitis in cancer patients, not fistulizing Crohn's disease. Additionally, the trial excludes patients with active inflammatory bowel disease.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease; CDAI score 350; Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab; Active perianal fistula with draining seton in place; Recently completed IV antibiotics for perianal abscess
judge_comment: Hard exclusion applies: disease mismatch (trial is for ICPI-induced colitis in cancer patients; patient has Crohn’s disease and no cancer/ICPI exposure). Additionally, the trial explicitly excludes active inflammatory bowel disease. Thus F is correct.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 11-year-old boy with Duchenne muscular dystrophy confirmed by a deletion of exons 49-50. He lost ambulation 8 months ago and is now dependent on a power wheelchair. He is on a stable regimen of deflazacort and lisinopril for early cardiomyopathy (LVEF 52%). His Performance of Upper Limb (PUL) score is 18. His parents are interested in trials for non-ambulatory patients.

inclusion_criteria: Spinal muscular atrophy with prior treatment with onasemnogene abeparvovec in a Novartis Gene Therapies-sponsored clinical study
prior_therapies: Prior treatment with onasemnogene abeparvovec in a Novartis Gene Therapies-sponsored clinical study
reasoning: The trial targets spinal muscular atrophy patients previously treated with onasemnogene abeparvovec in a Novartis-sponsored study. The patient has Duchenne muscular dystrophy and lacks the required prior therapy, constituting a disease mismatch and failure of key inclusion criteria.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 11 years; Male sex; Duchenne muscular dystrophy confirmed by deletion of exons 49-50; Non-ambulatory (lost ambulation 8 months ago); Power wheelchair dependent; Stable deflazacort regimen; Early cardiomyopathy with LVEF 52%; Performance of Upper Limb (PUL) score 18
judge_comment: Hard exclusion: disease mismatch (patient has Duchenne muscular dystrophy; trial is for spinal muscular atrophy). Additionally, the trial requires prior onasemnogene abeparvovec exposure, which the patient lacks. F is correct.

question_text: I have a 62-year-old male patient diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) 14 months ago. He has limb-onset disease and an ALSFRS-R score of 38. His forced vital capacity (FVC) is stable at 85% of predicted. He is currently taking riluzole. What trial options are available?

inclusion_criteria: Spinal muscular atrophy with prior treatment with onasemnogene abeparvovec in a Novartis Gene Therapies-sponsored clinical study
prior_therapies: Prior treatment with onasemnogene abeparvovec in a Novartis Gene Therapies-sponsored clinical study
reasoning: Hard exclusion: the trial targets spinal muscular atrophy (Types I–III), whereas the patient has amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), which is not included. Additionally, the trial requires prior onasemnogene abeparvovec exposure in a Novartis study, which is not indicated for this patient.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS); Limb-onset disease; ALSFRS-R score 38; Forced vital capacity (FVC) 85% of predicted; Currently taking riluzole; Time since diagnosis 14 months; Age 62 years; Male sex
judge_comment: Correct: Hard exclusion due to disease mismatch (ALS vs SMA). The trial’s requirement of prior onasemnogene abeparvovec also wouldn’t be met, but the disease mismatch alone warrants F.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. inclusion_criteria: Collagenous colitis or lymphocytic colitis diagnosed on colon biopsies reviewed by 2 pathologists | CC defined histologically by subepithelial collagen band thickness >10 micrometer, lamina propria lymphoplasmacytic inflammation, lack of crypt architectural distortion, and regenerative epithelial changes | LC defined histologically by >20 intraepithelial lymphocytes per 100 epithelial cells in the area of highest density, lamina propria lymphoplasmacytic inflammation, and regenerative epithelial changes | Active flare: >3 watery/loose stools per day on >4 of 7 days over >4 weeks in the past 3 months

judge_comment: Correctly identified a hard exclusion: the trial targets microscopic colitis (collagenous or lymphocytic), while the patient has fistulizing Crohn’s disease. Age/sex fit are irrelevant once disease mismatch is present. Grade F is appropriate.

question_text: 36 female with stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma, who initially received optimal debulking and adjuvant carboplatin+paclitaxel +bevacizumab. After 5 months, she had a new pleural effusion that was cytology positive for ovarian carcinoma. She was found to be BRCA1 positive. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Randomized Phase III, Two-Arm Trial of Paclitaxel/Carboplatin/Maintenance Letrozole Versus Letrozole Monotherapy in Patients With Stage II-IV, Primary Low-Grade Serous Carcinoma of the Ovary or Peritoneum
diseases_targeted: Ovarian Low Grade Serous Carcinoma; Fallopian Tube Low Grade Serous Carcinoma; Primary Peritoneal Low Grade Serous Carcinoma
inclusion_criteria: Newly diagnosed stage II–IV low-grade serous ovarian cancer (ovarian, fallopian tube, or primary peritoneal) | Prior history of serous borderline tumor allowed | p53 immunohistochemistry nonaberrant (consistent with TP53 wildtype) | Age >= 18 years | Attempt at maximal upfront cytoreductive surgery (optimal or suboptimal residual allowed) | Bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy performed | ECOG performance status 0–2 | Able to take oral medications | ANC >= 1500/µL | Platelets >= 100000/µL | Creatinine <= 1.5 x ULN | Bilirubin <= 1.5 x ULN | AST <= 3 x ULN | ALT <= 3 x ULN | Prior or concurrent malignancy allowed if not interfering with safety or efficacy assessment | HIV-infected patients on effective antiretroviral therapy with undetectable viral load within 6 months are eligible
exclusion_criteria: Prior neoadjuvant or adjuvant chemotherapy for this disease | Prior radiotherapy for this disease | Previous hormonal therapy for this disease | Hypersensitivity to letrozole or intolerance/hypersensitivity to carboplatin/paclitaxel | Myocardial infarction or unstable angina within 6 months | New York Heart Association class II or greater congestive heart failure | Known central nervous system metastases | Active or uncontrolled systemic infection (except uncomplicated urinary tract infection) | Baseline neuropathy grade >= 2 | Aberrant p53 expression on IHC (consistent with TP53 mutation/high-grade serous ovarian cancer)
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Hard exclusion: The trial is for newly diagnosed low-grade serous ovarian/peritoneal carcinoma, but the patient has recurrent clear cell ovarian carcinoma. Additionally, the trial excludes patients with prior adjuvant chemotherapy, which this patient received.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma; BRCA1 positive; Optimal debulking surgery performed; Received adjuvant carboplatin + paclitaxel + bevacizumab; Cytology-positive malignant pleural effusion at 5 months post-adjuvant
patient_prior_therapies: Carboplatin; Paclitaxel; Bevacizumab; Optimal debulking surgery
judge_comment: Hard exclusion applies: the trial is for low-grade serous ovarian/peritoneal carcinoma, while the patient has recurrent clear cell ovarian carcinoma. This disease mismatch triggers an automatic F. The noted prior adjuvant chemotherapy is an additional exclusion but not necessary for the F decision.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?

inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | At least one episode of diverticulitis confirmed by CT scan (or pending confirmation) | Colonoscopy completed or scheduled to rule out other colon pathology per screening guidelines | History of recurrent uncomplicated diverticulitis without current symptoms (AUD in remission) OR persistent signs/symptoms related to diverticular disease >= 3 months after recovery from an episode of AUD (excluding IBS and other conditions)

judge_comment: Correctly applied hard exclusion: disease mismatch (trial is for diverticulitis, patient has fistulizing Crohn’s disease). That alone mandates F. Additional mention of IBD medication exclusion is unnecessary but does not affect the correct F grade.

question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.
trial_title: Atherosclerosis Intervention With Novel Tissue Selective Estrogen Complex Therapy
inclusion_criteria: Women 45-59 years old | <6 years postmenopausal | Serum estradiol <30 pg/mL | Cessation of regular menses >6 months
exclusion_criteria: Hysterectomy | Clinical signs, symptoms, or personal history of cardiovascular disease | Diabetes mellitus or fasting serum glucose >126 mg/dL | Life-threatening illness with prognosis <5 years | Cirrhosis or liver disease | History of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism | History of breast cancer | Current use of postmenopausal hormone replacement therapy within 1 month of randomization | Uncontrolled hypertension (>180/>110 mmHg) | Plasma triglycerides >500 mg/dL | Serum creatinine >2.0 mg/dL
prior_therapies: Discontinue postmenopausal hormone replacement therapy >=1 month before randomization
reasoning: The trial restricts enrollment to females aged 45–59, whereas the patient is a 68-year-old male. Additionally, the trial's disease focus (atherosclerosis/cognitive decline) does not explicitly include dementia.
patient_biomarkers: Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 68 years; Male; Progressive cognitive decline for 2 years; MMSE score 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
judge_comment: Multiple hard exclusions apply: trial restricts to females (patient is male), age 45–59 (patient is 68), and disease mismatch (trial lists atherosclerosis/cognitive decline, not dementia). Therefore F is correct and the grader’s reasoning aligns with the rubric.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: Randomized, Open-label, Phase 3 Study of SAR408701 Versus Docetaxel in Previously Treated, Metastatic Nonsquamous, Non-small-cell Lung Cancer Patients With CEACAM5-positive Tumors
inclusion_criteria: Histologically or cytologically confirmed non-squamous non-small cell lung cancer with metastatic disease | Progression after platinum-based chemotherapy | Progression after an immune checkpoint inhibitor | CEACAM5 expression >=2+ in >=50% of tumor cells by IHC (central lab) | At least one measurable lesion per RECIST v1.1 | ECOG performance status 0-1
exclusion_criteria: Untreated brain metastases or history of leptomeningeal disease; if previously treated brain metastases, no documented non-progressive disease on imaging >=4 weeks after CNS therapy and >=2 weeks before first dose | Significant concomitant illnesses that would impair participation or interpretation | Invasive malignancy within 3 years other than cured local tumors (e.g., resected/ablated basal or squamous cell skin cancer or cervical carcinoma in situ) | Unresolved prior treatment-related toxicity >= grade 2 (except alopecia, vitiligo, or controlled thyroiditis) | Known AIDS-related illnesses or HIV requiring antiretroviral therapy, or unresolved viral hepatitis | History of and/or unresolved corneal disorders; contact lens use not permitted | Concurrent anticancer therapy | Prior treatment with docetaxel, maytansinoid ADCs (DM1 or DM4), or any CEACAM5-targeting drug | Contraindication to corticosteroid premedication | Poor bone marrow, liver, or kidney function | Hypersensitivity to study interventions or components (including EDTA, paclitaxel, polysorbate 80)
prior_therapies: Progression after platinum-based chemotherapy; Progression after immune checkpoint inhibitor
reasoning: The trial requires progression after both platinum-based chemotherapy and an immune checkpoint inhibitor; the patient has only received osimertinib and has not had these prior therapies. Therefore the required treatment setting is not met.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 40 years; Male; Metastatic non-small cell lung cancer; De novo metastatic disease; Bone metastases; Liver metastases; Brain metastases on MRI; EGFR exon 19 deletion; On osimertinib for 2 years; ECOG 0; No significant comorbidities
judge_comment: No hard exclusions apply. The patient’s disease and age/sex fit, but there is a clear soft mismatch on the line-of-therapy/prior-exposure anchor: the trial requires progression after platinum chemotherapy and an immune checkpoint inhibitor, which the patient lacks. That warrants a D, not an F. CEACAM5 status is unknown and should not trigger F per rubric.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Medically eligible and agrees to undergo fistulotomy | Simple perianal fistula with 2 or fewer fistula tracts | Maximum fistula tract length 3 inches | No history of Crohn's disease or Ulcerative Colitis | Females of childbearing potential: negative pregnancy test at screening | Females of childbearing potential: willing to use a highly effective method of contraception during the study | Males who can father a child: willing to use a recommended method of contraception and refrain from sperm donation from the start of conditioning therapy for at least 1 year after completion

patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease; CDAI score 350; Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab; Active perianal fistula with draining seton in place; Recently completed IV antibiotics for perianal abscess
judge_comment: Hard exclusion applies: the trial requires no history of Crohn’s disease, but the patient has fistulizing Crohn’s. This alone yields F. The seton-in-place issue could be conditional, but is not needed to justify F.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. judge_comment: Patient disease, age, and sex match; stage (metastatic) matches. However, the trial requires first-line (no prior systemic therapy) and the patient has received osimertinib, creating a clear line-of-therapy/prior-exposure mismatch. Per rubric, this is a soft mismatch on a core anchor (D), not a hard exclusion (F) because it is not listed under trial_exclusion_criteria; inclusion requirements alone do not trigger F.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. question_text: What are trial options for a 66 year old male with hx hypertension, afib, T2DM and mCRPC, now progressing on enzalutamide? He has been on Lupron+Zytiga for 3 years, with new liver and bone metastases which are all PSMA PET avid. He’s tolerated therapy well overall except for grade 2 fatigue.
trial_title: Advanced ChemoHormonal Therapy for Treatment Naïve Metastatic Prostate Cancer: Apalutamide and Abiraterone Acetate With Prednisone and Androgen Deprivation Therapy After Treatment With Docetaxel and Androgen Deprivation Therapy
inclusion_criteria: Histologically or cytologically confirmed prostate cancer or strong clinical suspicion with metastatic pattern and PSA > 50 ng/mL | High-risk disease: either (a) at least 2 of visceral metastases, >=3 bone lesions, Gleason 8–10; or (b) >=4 bone lesions with >=1 outside vertebral column or pelvis and/or visceral metastases | Prior neoadjuvant or adjuvant ADT allowed if >= 24 months elapsed before restarting ADT for metastatic castration-sensitive disease | ADT-sensitive disease with no PSA progression or new metastatic deposits since starting ADT | Completed up to 6 cycles of docetaxel for metastatic castration-sensitive disease with <= 16 weeks since day 21 of the final cycle | Life expectancy > 18 months | ECOG performance status <= 2 | Hemoglobin > 9.0 g/dL | Leukocytes > 3,000/µL | Absolute neutrophil count > 1,500/µL | Platelets >= 100,000/µL | Total bilirubin <= 1.5 x ULN | AST/ALT < 2.5 x ULN | Albumin > 3 g/dL | eGFR > 30 mL/min | Potassium >= 3.5 mmol/L | Medications known to lower the seizure threshold discontinued or substituted >= 4 weeks prior to day 1
exclusion_criteria: Unwilling to stop saw palmetto, PC-SPECs, or other herbal agents known to affect PSA | Receipt of other investigational agents within 30 days prior to day 1 | Prior exposure to apalutamide, enzalutamide, abiraterone, darolutamide, or any other second-generation antiandrogen therapy | History of allergic reactions to compounds similar to apalutamide or study agents | Another active malignancy other than non-melanoma skin cancer (unless metastatic) or superficial bladder cancer | Seizure or condition predisposing to seizure (e.g., prior stroke within 1 year, brain AVM, schwannoma, meningioma, or other benign CNS/meningeal disease requiring treatment) | Severe or unstable angina, recent myocardial infarction, symptomatic congestive heart failure or LVEF < 50%, thromboembolic events, or clinically significant ventricular arrhythmias within 6 months prior to day 1 | Uncontrolled hypertension | Gastrointestinal disorder affecting absorption | Active infection (e.g., HIV or viral hepatitis) | Chronic medical condition requiring > 10 mg prednisone/prednisolone daily | Baseline moderate or severe hepatic impairment (Child-Pugh Class B or C) | Inability to stop prohibited medications: atypical antipsychotics, bupropion, lithium, meperidine/pethidine, phenothiazine antipsychotics, tricyclic antidepressants, tramadol
prior_therapies: Up to 6 cycles of docetaxel for metastatic castration-sensitive disease completed; <= 16 weeks since day 21 of final cycle; Prior neoadjuvant or adjuvant ADT allowed if >= 24 months elapsed before restarting ADT for metastatic castration-sensitive disease; Ongoing ADT with castration-sensitive disease and no PSA progression or new metastases since starting ADT

patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 66 years; Male; Castration-resistant prostate cancer; Metastatic disease; PSMA PET avid disease; Liver metastases; Bone metastases; Progression on enzalutamide; Prior abiraterone (Zytiga); Prior leuprolide (Lupron)
judge_comment: Hard exclusions apply: the trial explicitly excludes prior exposure to enzalutamide/abiraterone, which the patient has, and the trial targets metastatic castration-sensitive disease while the patient has castration-resistant disease. Therefore F is correct.

question_text: A 55-year-old female has severe, seropositive rheumatoid arthritis refractory to methotrexate and two prior biologic agents (adalimumab and tocilizumab). She has active disease with a DAS28 score of 5.5. Critically, she has a history of treated Hepatitis B (HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive) and moderate chronic kidney disease with an eGFR of 45 mL/min/1.73m². What are trial options for her?
trial_title: A Phase III, Randomized, Double-Blind, Single-Dose, Placebo-Controlled Study to Demonstrate the Efficacy and Safety of Tildrakizumab in Subjects With Active Psoriatic Arthritis I (INSPIRE 1)
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Rheumatoid factor negative | Anti-CCP antibody negative | Prior exposure to anti-TNF agent(s) for psoriasis or psoriatic arthritis
exclusion_criteria: Planned surgical intervention for a pretreatment condition between baseline and Week 24 | Active infection requiring systemic anti-infectives within 28 days before first dose | Serious infection requiring hospitalization or IV anti-infectives within 8 weeks before first dose | Recurrent or chronic infections (e.g., chronic pyelonephritis, chronic osteomyelitis, bronchiectasis) | History of hepatitis B infection | History of hepatitis C infection | History of HIV infection | Myocardial infarction, unstable angina, or ischemic stroke within 6 months before first dose | Active malignancy, including cutaneous basal or squamous cell carcinoma or melanoma | History of malignancy within 5 years except treated and cured cutaneous basal or squamous cell carcinoma, in situ cervical carcinoma, or in situ ductal breast carcinoma | History of alcohol or drug abuse within the previous 2 years | Unwilling or unable to use adequate contraception as specified | Donation or loss of >= 400 mL of blood within 8 weeks before dosing
prior_therapies: Prior anti-TNF therapy for psoriasis or psoriatic arthritis
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets psoriatic arthritis, while the patient has rheumatoid arthritis. Additionally, the trial excludes anyone with a history of hepatitis B infection, which the patient has (HBsAg-negative, anti-HBc-positive).
patient_inclusion_criteria: Seropositive rheumatoid arthritis; Active disease with DAS28 score of 5.5; History of treated Hepatitis B (HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive); Moderate chronic kidney disease (eGFR 45 mL/min/1.73 m^2)
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to methotrexate; Prior adalimumab; Prior tocilizumab; Failed two prior biologic agents
judge_comment: Correct F. There is a hard disease mismatch (trial targets psoriatic arthritis; patient has rheumatoid arthritis). Additionally, the trial explicitly excludes any history of hepatitis B infection, which the patient has (HBsAg–, anti-HBc+). Either condition independently warrants an F.

question_text: 36 female with stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma, who initially received optimal debulking and adjuvant carboplatin+paclitaxel +bevacizumab. After 5 months, she had a new pleural effusion that was cytology positive for ovarian carcinoma. She was found to be BRCA1 positive. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Phase I/Ib Trial of the CDK4/6 Antagonist Ribociclib And The HDAC Inhibitor Belinostat In Patients With Metastatic Triple Negative Breast Cancer And Recurrent Ovarian Cancer With Response Prediction By Genomics (CHARGE)
diseases_targeted: Triple-Negative Breast Cancer (metastatic); Ovarian Carcinoma (serous, recurrent)
inclusion_criteria: Dose escalation: Pathologically confirmed metastatic or unresectable triple-negative breast cancer with measurable disease by RECIST 1.1, ER and PR <= 1% by IHC, HER2 negative, not amenable to curative therapy. | Dose escalation: Pathologically confirmed recurrent, unresectable serous ovarian carcinoma. | Dose expansion: Pathologically confirmed metastatic or unresectable triple-negative breast cancer with measurable disease by RECIST 1.1, ER and PR <= 1% by IHC, HER2 negative, not amenable to curative therapy. | Age >= 18. | ECOG performance status <= 2. | Able to swallow pills. | Adequate organ function per protocol thresholds. | At least one safely accessible metastatic site for biopsy and willingness to undergo up to 3 biopsies. | Negative pregnancy test for women of childbearing potential. | Agrees to use effective contraception for at least 6 months after last dose. | Able to provide informed consent.
exclusion_criteria: Prior treatment with CDK4/6 inhibitors or HDAC inhibitors for cancer. | Major surgery, radiotherapy, anticancer therapy, or investigational agents within 4 weeks or <= 5 half-lives (whichever is shorter). | Active or progressive brain metastases or leptomeningeal disease unless CNS-specific treatment not required during first cycle per treating physician. | Requirement for valproic acid within 5 days before first belinostat dose or during study. | Active infection requiring systemic therapy. | Allergy or hypersensitivity to belinostat, ribociclib, or their binders. | Uncontrolled arrhythmia, congestive heart failure, or angina; MI, symptomatic pericarditis, or cardiac surgery within 6 months. | Left ventricular ejection fraction < 50%. | Clinically significant cardiac arrhythmias, complete left bundle branch block, or high-grade AV block. | Congenital long QT syndrome. | Baseline QTcF > 450 msec with heart rate 50–90 BPM required on qualifying ECG. | Concurrent use of UGT1A1 inhibitors within 7 days prior to day 1. | Concurrent herbal supplements unless approved; must discontinue >= 7 days prior to day 1. | Concurrent medications with known risk of Torsades de Pointes that cannot be discontinued or switched >= 7 days prior to start. | Unresolved diarrhea >= Grade 2 (CTCAE v5.0). | Use within 7 days prior to start of strong/moderate CYP3A4/5 inducers or inhibitors, certain narrow-therapeutic-index CYP3A4/5 substrates, or grapefruit/pomelo/star-fruit/Seville orange. | Current treatment with warfarin or other coumarin anticoagulants (other anticoagulants allowed). | Impaired GI function that may alter drug absorption (e.g., uncontrolled IBD, uncontrolled vomiting, major stomach or small bowel resection). | Pregnant or breastfeeding. | Women or men of childbearing potential not using highly effective contraception during treatment and for 6 months after. | Known HIV infection with detectable viral load within 6 months (controlled on ART with undetectable load eligible). | Known chronic HBV or HCV infection with detectable viral load (suppressed/undetectable viral load eligible). | Another malignancy (other than breast or ovarian in dose escalation) anticipated to need systemic treatment within 1 year.
prior_therapies: Washout >= 4 weeks (or >= 5 half-lives) from major surgery, radiotherapy, anticancer therapy, or investigational agents before day 1.
reasoning: The ovarian cancer cohort requires recurrent serous ovarian carcinoma, while the patient has recurrent clear cell ovarian carcinoma—a required histologic subtype mismatch, which is a hard exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma; BRCA1 positive; Optimal debulking surgery performed; Received adjuvant carboplatin + paclitaxel + bevacizumab; Cytology-positive malignant pleural effusion at 5 months post-adjuvant
patient_prior_therapies: Carboplatin; Paclitaxel; Bevacizumab; Optimal debulking surgery
judge_comment: The trial’s ovarian cohort requires serous histology; the patient has clear cell ovarian carcinoma. This is a required subtype mismatch, which is a hard exclusion per the rubric. Grade F is correct.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 11-year-old boy with Duchenne muscular dystrophy confirmed by a deletion of exons 49-50. He lost ambulation 8 months ago and is now dependent on a power wheelchair. He is on a stable regimen of deflazacort and lisinopril for early cardiomyopathy (LVEF 52%). His Performance of Upper Limb (PUL) score is 18. His parents are interested in trials for non-ambulatory patients.
trial_title: Randomized Clinical Evaluation of the AccuCinch® Ventricular Restoration System in Patients Who Present With Symptomatic Heart Failure With Reduced Ejection Fraction (HFrEF): The CORCINCH-HF Study
diseases_targeted: Dilated Cardiomyopathy; Heart Failure With Reduced Ejection Fraction
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Left ventricular ejection fraction >= 20% and <= 40% by transthoracic echocardiography assessed by core lab | Left ventricular end-diastolic diameter >= 55 mm by transthoracic echocardiography | NYHA class III, or ambulatory class IV, or NYHA class II with a heart failure hospitalization within the prior 12 months | Six-minute walk distance between 100 m and 450 m | Diagnosis and treatment for heart failure established >= 90 days before consent | On stable, optimally titrated guideline-directed medical therapy for >= 30 days (with documented intolerance if applicable) | When applicable, cardiac resynchronization therapy device placed > 90 days before screening | When applicable, implantable cardioverter-defibrillator placed > 30 days before screening
exclusion_criteria: Myocardial infarction within 90 days prior to consent | Percutaneous cardiovascular intervention, cardiovascular surgery, or carotid surgery within 90 days prior to consent | Untreated clinically significant coronary artery disease requiring revascularization | Severe aortic arch calcification, mobile aortic atheroma, intracardiac mass, thrombus, or vegetation by fluoroscopy or echocardiography | Suboptimal ventricular anatomy or wall thickness for device implantation by echocardiography and/or CT | Heart failure etiology other than ischemic or non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy (e.g., hypertrophic, amyloid, restrictive cardiomyopathy, uncorrected congenital heart disease, constrictive pericarditis) | Hemodynamic instability within 30 days prior to implant requiring inotropic or mechanical support | Planned cardiac surgery or interventions within 180 days post-randomization | Active bacterial endocarditis | Severe right ventricular dysfunction by right heart catheterization and/or echocardiography | Fixed pulmonary hypertension with pulmonary artery systolic pressure > 70 mmHg not responsive to vasodilator therapy | History of stroke within 90 days of consent or Modified Rankin Scale >= 2 from any prior stroke | Mitral regurgitation grade 3+ or 4+ | Untreated degenerative (primary) mitral valve disease (mild prolapse without need for intervention allowable) | Prior mitral or aortic valve replacement | Tricuspid regurgitation grade 4+ | Moderate or severe aortic stenosis (aortic valve area < 1.5 cm2 or peak velocity > 300 cm/sec) | Aortic regurgitation grade 2+, 3+, or 4+ | Anatomic constraints preventing appropriate access/implant (e.g., femoral arteries not supporting a 20F introducer sheath) | eGFR < 25 mL/min/1.73 m2 | Contraindication to anticoagulation during the procedure | Contraindication to 90 days of antiplatelet therapy | Known allergy to nitinol, polyester, or polyethylene | Prior true anaphylactic reaction to contrast agents not amenable to adequate pre-medication | Life expectancy < 1 year due to non-cardiac conditions | Currently participating in another interventional investigational study | On high dose steroids or immunosuppressant therapy | Pregnant, lactating, or of child-bearing potential without documented birth control
prior_therapies: On guideline-directed medical therapy, stable and optimally titrated for >= 30 days; If an SGLT2 inhibitor is newly added or dose change exceeds stability parameters, delay screening >= 30 days after the change; CRT device placed > 90 days before screening when applicable; ICD placed > 30 days before screening when applicable
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets HFrEF/dilated cardiomyopathy, not Duchenne muscular dystrophy. The patient is also 11 years old (min age 18), and has LVEF 52% (trial requires 20–40%).
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 11 years; Male sex; Duchenne muscular dystrophy confirmed by deletion of exons 49-50; Non-ambulatory (lost ambulation 8 months ago); Power wheelchair dependent; Stable deflazacort regimen; Early cardiomyopathy with LVEF 52%; Performance of Upper Limb (PUL) score 18
judge_comment: Hard exclusions apply: disease mismatch (trial targets HFrEF/dilated cardiomyopathy, not DMD) and age <18 vs trial minimum 18. Either alone triggers F. Grader’s reasoning and grade are correct.

question_text: What are trial options for a 66 year old male with hx hypertension, afib, T2DM and mCRPC, now progressing on enzalutamide? He has been on Lupron+Zytiga for 3 years, with new liver and bone metastases which are all PSMA PET avid. He’s tolerated therapy well overall except for grade 2 fatigue.
trial_title: A Randomized Phase II Study Comparing Sequential High Dose Testosterone and Enzalutamide to Enzalutamide Alone in Asymptomatic Men With Castration Resistant Metastatic Prostate Cancer
inclusion_criteria: ECOG performance status <=2 | Age >=18 years | Histologically confirmed prostate adenocarcinoma | On continuous androgen deprivation therapy (surgical castration or LHRH agonist/antagonist) | Castrate serum testosterone <50 ng/dL | Metastatic disease documented by CT or bone scan | Disease progression on abiraterone acetate plus ADT (PSA and/or radiographic per RECIST 1.1 or PCWG3) | Screening PSA >= 1.0 ng/mL | Biopsy required if soft tissue lesion amenable (pre-treatment and on-treatment) | No prior enzalutamide, apalutamide, darolutamide, or investigational AR-targeted therapy | Prior testosterone allowed | Prior docetaxel for hormone-sensitive disease allowed (<=6 doses) | Prior sipuleucel-T and radium-223 allowed if >4 weeks from last dose | Abiraterone discontinued >=2 weeks before starting therapy | Attempt to wean off prednisone; continue lowest achievable dose if unable to fully wean | Bilirubin < 2.5 x ULN | AST < 2.5 x ULN | ALT < 2.5 x ULN | Serum creatinine < 2.5 x ULN | Absolute neutrophil count >= 1500 /µL | Platelet count >= 100000 /µL | Hemoglobin >= 8 g/dL | At least 4 weeks since prior radiation or chemotherapy
exclusion_criteria: Pain due to metastatic prostate cancer requiring treatment intervention with pain medication | ECOG performance status >=3 | Prior enzalutamide therapy | Prior chemotherapy with docetaxel or cabazitaxel for castration-resistant prostate cancer | Requires urinary self-catheterization for voiding due to obstruction from prostate cancer or BPH (indwelling Foley or suprapubic catheter allowed) | Disease sites/extent that increase risk from testosterone therapy (e.g., femoral metastases with fracture risk, severe/extensive spinal metastases with cord compression risk, extensive liver metastases) | Serious or unstable medical, psychiatric, or other condition that could interfere with safety or consent | Active uncontrolled infection, including known HIV/AIDS, hepatitis B, or hepatitis C | Any condition or mental impairment compromising consent, safety, or compliance | Current anticoagulation with warfarin, rivaroxaban, or apixaban (unless transitioned to enoxaparin prior to treatment) | History of thromboembolic event within 12 months not on systemic anticoagulation | Hematocrit >51% | Untreated severe obstructive sleep apnea | Uncontrolled or poorly controlled heart failure | Allergy to sesame seed oil or cottonseed oil | Major surgery within 3 weeks before screening or not fully recovered from prior surgery
prior_therapies: Continuous androgen deprivation therapy required; Progression on abiraterone acetate plus ADT required; No prior enzalutamide, apalutamide, darolutamide, or investigational AR-targeted therapy; Prior testosterone allowed; Prior docetaxel for hormone-sensitive disease allowed (<=6 doses); Prior sipuleucel-T allowed (>4 weeks washout); Prior radium-223 allowed (>4 weeks washout); Abiraterone washout >=2 weeks before starting study therapy; At least 4 weeks since prior radiation or chemotherapy; Attempt to taper prednisone to lowest feasible dose before starting therapy
reasoning: Explicit exclusion applies: the trial disallows any prior enzalutamide, and the patient has previously received/en had progression on enzalutamide. Other factors (male, age 66, metastatic castration-resistant disease) align but do not override this hard exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 66 years; Male; Castration-resistant prostate cancer; Metastatic disease; PSMA PET avid disease; Liver metastases; Bone metastases; Progression on enzalutamide; Prior abiraterone (Zytiga); Prior leuprolide (Lupron)
judge_comment: The trial explicitly excludes patients with any prior enzalutamide; the patient has prior/progression on enzalutamide. This is a hard exclusion per the rubric, so F is correct. Other factors (age, sex, disease, stage) do not override the explicit exclusion.

question_text: A 55-year-old female has severe, seropositive rheumatoid arthritis refractory to methotrexate and two prior biologic agents (adalimumab and tocilizumab). She has active disease with a DAS28 score of 5.5. Critically, she has a history of treated Hepatitis B (HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive) and moderate chronic kidney disease with an eGFR of 45 mL/min/1.73m². What are trial options for her?
trial_title: A Multicenter, Open-Label Extension Study to Asses the Long-Term Safety, Tolerability, and Efficacy of Bimekizumab in the Treatment of Study Participants With Active Axial Spondyloarthritis, Ankylosing Spondylitis, and Nonradiographic Axial Spondyloarthritis
diseases_targeted: Axial Spondyloarthritis; Ankylosing Spondylitis; Nonradiographic Axial Spondyloarthritis
inclusion_criteria: Completed feeder study AS0010 (NCT03928704) or AS0011 (NCT03928743)
exclusion_criteria: Plans for pregnancy during the study or within 20 weeks after final dose (self or partner). | Meets withdrawal criteria in AS0010 or AS0011. | Ongoing serious adverse event or history of serious infections in feeder study (medical monitor approval required). | Positive or indeterminate interferon gamma release assay unless appropriately evaluated and treated.
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets axial spondyloarthritis (AS/nr-axSpA), not rheumatoid arthritis. It also requires completion of a specific feeder study, which is not documented for this patient.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Seropositive rheumatoid arthritis; Active disease with DAS28 score of 5.5; History of treated Hepatitis B (HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive); Moderate chronic kidney disease (eGFR 45 mL/min/1.73 m^2)
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to methotrexate; Prior adalimumab; Prior tocilizumab; Failed two prior biologic agents
judge_comment: Correct F: The patient has rheumatoid arthritis while the trial targets axial spondyloarthritis/AS/nr-axSpA—this is a hard disease mismatch per rubric. Mention of feeder study completion is unnecessary and, if considered alone, would be unknown (not a hard exclusion), but the disease mismatch alone justifies F.

question_text: 40 year old man with recurrent glioblastoma. Diagnosed 1 year ago, underwent gross total resection with confirmation of GBM, IDH wildtype. Completed adjuvant radiation + concurrent temozolomide and then adjuvant temozolomide. Three months after completing adjuvant therapy, MRI shows recurrence. ECOG 1 and no other medical issues. What are trial options?
trial_title: Phase I Study of Cellular Immunotherapy Using Memory Enriched T Cells Lentivirally Transduced to Express an IL13Rα2-Targeting, Hinge-Optimized, 41BB-Costimulatory Chimeric Receptor and a Truncated CD19 for Children With Recurrent/Refractory Malignant Brain Tumors
inclusion_criteria: Karnofsky Performance Status >= 60% (except loss of mobility due to disease involvement) | Life expectancy > 4 weeks | Histologically confirmed malignant brain neoplasm progressed after prior conventional therapy | Radiographic progression/recurrence > 12 weeks after completion of initial conventional therapy (including initial radiation therapy) | IL13Ralpha2-positive tumor expression by IHC (H-score >= 50) confirmed by institutional pathology | Programmable shunt present if applicable and able to tolerate being switched off for >= 2 consecutive days | Platelets >= 50,000/µL | Total bilirubin <= 2 x ULN (unless Gilbert's disease) | AST <= 2 x ULN | ALT <= 2 x ULN | Creatinine clearance >= 75 mL/min/1.73m^2 | Seronegative for HIV Ag/Ab combo, negative for active HBV (HBsAg negative), and HCV as per RNA testing if antibody positive | Women of childbearing potential: negative pregnancy test | Females and males of childbearing potential agree to effective contraception or abstinence during study and for 6 months after last dose | Dexamethasone dose <= 0.1 mg/kg/day on day of PBMC collection | Adequate venous access for PBMC collection | At least 2 weeks since last dose of prior targeted agents, chemotherapy, or radiation before PBMC collection | Serum creatinine < 1.6 mg/dL (for CNS catheter placement eligibility) | WBC >= 2,000/µL (for CNS catheter placement eligibility) | ANC >= 1,000/µL (for CNS catheter placement eligibility) | Platelets > 50,000/µL (for CNS catheter placement eligibility) | INR <= 1.3 (for CNS catheter placement eligibility) | Bilirubin < 1.5 mg/dL (for CNS catheter placement eligibility) | ALT and AST < 2 x ULN (for CNS catheter placement eligibility) | Second-line radiation therapy completed >= 4 weeks prior to surgical resection/biopsy/catheter placement | No supplemental oxygen required to keep saturation > 95% and no progressive chest radiographic abnormalities (for lymphodepletion/infusion eligibility) | No pressor support required and no symptomatic cardiac arrhythmias (for lymphodepletion/infusion eligibility) | Afebrile (<= 38.5 C) with no positive blood cultures and no indications of meningitis within 48 hours prior to infusion | Hepatic: total bilirubin or transaminases <= 2 x ULN (for lymphodepletion/infusion eligibility) | Renal: serum creatinine < 1.8 mg/dL (for lymphodepletion/infusion eligibility) | No uncontrolled seizure activity (for lymphodepletion/infusion eligibility) | For each CAR T infusion: platelet count >= 50,000/µL (transfusion permitted to achieve >= 50,000/µL) | For each CAR T infusion: dexamethasone <= 0.1 mg/kg/day
exclusion_criteria: Requires supplemental oxygen to keep saturation > 95% and not expected to resolve within 2 weeks | Requires pressor support and/or has symptomatic cardiac arrhythmias | Requires dialysis | Uncontrolled seizure activity and/or clinically evident progressive encephalopathy | Poorly controlled non-malignant intercurrent illness or illness severity deemed unsafe by investigators | Any other active malignancy | Being treated for severe infection or recovering from major surgery until recovery is complete | Uncontrolled illness including ongoing or active infection; known active hepatitis B or C infection; signs or symptoms of active infection, positive blood cultures, or radiologic evidence of infections | Confirmed HIV positivity within 4 weeks of enrollment | Pregnant or breastfeeding
prior_therapies: Progressed after prior conventional therapy; At least 2 weeks since last targeted agent, chemotherapy, or radiation before PBMC collection; At least 6 weeks since completion of nitrosourea-containing chemotherapy before study treatment; At least 23 days since completion of temozolomide before study treatment; At least 4 weeks since completion of other non-nitrosourea cytotoxic chemotherapy before study treatment; If most recent treatment was a targeted agent only and toxicities resolved, at least 2 weeks since last dose before study treatment; At least 4 weeks since last bevacizumab dose before starting study treatment; Second-line radiation therapy completed at least 4 weeks prior to surgery/biopsy/catheter placement
reasoning: The trial only enrolls patients aged 4–25, while the patient is 40 years old, which is a hard age-window exclusion. Although IL13Rα2 positivity is also required and unknown here, the age criterion alone makes the patient ineligible.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Histologically confirmed glioblastoma; IDH wildtype; Recurrent disease after standard therapy; ECOG 1; Age 40 years; Male; Prior gross total resection; Completed adjuvant radiation with concurrent temozolomide; Completed adjuvant temozolomide
patient_prior_therapies: Gross total resection; Radiation therapy with concurrent temozolomide; Adjuvant temozolomide
judge_comment: Age window is a hard exclusion: trial allows 4–25 years; patient is 40. That alone mandates grade F. Mention of IL13Rα2 being unknown is correct to ignore for hard exclusion, but age already disqualifies.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: Pivotal Study to Evaluate the Safety and Efficacy of the Insides™ System in the Treatment of Subjects With a Double Enterostomy and/or Enterocutaneous Fistula and Type 2 Intestinal Failure.
diseases_targeted: Enterocutaneous Fistula; High Output Stoma; Intestinal Failure
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 21 years | Dependent on parenteral nutrition | Double enterostomy/enterocutaneous fistula with exposed afferent and efferent limbs visible on the abdominal wall | Minimum 2 weeks after DES/ECF creation | Distal limb can be intubated by >= 24 Fr feeding tube (dilation allowable)
exclusion_criteria: Insufficient distal access channel for device insertion | Bowel obstruction proximal to the DES/ECF | Small bowel obstruction distal to the DES/ECF | Anastomotic leak distal to the DES/ECF | Perforation distal to the DES/ECF | Current Clostridioides difficile colitis | Current small intestinal bacterial overgrowth | Signs or symptoms of systemic infection | Pre-existing gastrointestinal motility disorders (e.g., slow transit constipation, outlet obstruction, fecal incontinence, gastroparesis) | Metabolic, neurogenic, or endocrine disorders causing colonic dysmotility (e.g., multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's disease, hypothyroidism) | Peritoneal metastatic disease known prior to DES/ECF closure | Liver cirrhosis | Hereditary coagulopathy (e.g., von Willebrand disease) | Severe chronic renal insufficiency (eGFR < 30 mL/min) | Active implantable medical devices (e.g., neuromodulation, cardiac systems) | Metal stents within 20 cm of intended controller use | Pregnancy or breastfeeding
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets double enterostomy or enterocutaneous fistula with intestinal failure, whereas the patient has perianal fistulizing Crohn’s disease without an enterocutaneous fistula or stoma. Additionally, required features like parenteral nutrition dependence are not indicated.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease; CDAI score 350; Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab; Active perianal fistula with draining seton in place; Recently completed IV antibiotics for perianal abscess
judge_comment: Disease mismatch is a hard exclusion: the trial targets enterocutaneous fistula/double enterostomy with intestinal failure, not perianal fistulizing Crohn’s disease. Thus F is appropriate. Mention of parenteral nutrition was extra but not needed for the F decision.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: Randomized Phase II Study of Platinum-Taxane-Cetrelimab Induction Followed by Niraparib Plus or Minus Cetrelimab Maintenance in Men With Aggressive Variant Prostate Cancers
diseases_targeted: Aggressive Variant Prostate Carcinoma; Castration-Resistant Prostate Carcinoma; Metastatic Prostate Carcinoma; Metastatic Prostate Neuroendocrine Carcinoma; Metastatic Prostate Small Cell Carcinoma; Stage IV Prostate Cancer
inclusion_criteria: Histologically or cytologically confirmed prostate carcinoma | Metastatic disease documented on imaging (bone scan, CT and/or MRI) | Meets at least one aggressive variant prostate carcinoma (AVPC) criterion | Histologically proven small cell (neuroendocrine) prostate carcinoma (AVPC criterion) | Exclusive visceral metastases (AVPC criterion) | Predominantly lytic bone metastases by x-ray or CT (AVPC criterion) | Bulky (>= 5 cm) lymphadenopathy or high-grade tumor mass in prostate/pelvis (AVPC criterion) | Low PSA (<= 10 ng/mL) at initial presentation or at symptomatic progression in the castrate-setting plus high-volume (>= 20) bone metastases (AVPC criterion) | Elevated LDH (>= 2 x ULN) or elevated CEA (>= 2 x ULN) without other etiologies (AVPC criterion) | Short interval (<= 180 days) to castration-resistant progression after initiation of hormonal therapy (AVPC criterion) | Loss or mutation in at least 2 of TP53, RB1, and PTEN by CLIA-certified testing, IHC and/or DNA sequencing (AVPC criterion) | Castration-resistant progression per RECIST without PSA rising to >= 1.0 ng/mL per PCWG3 (AVPC criterion) | Documented progressive disease by PSA progression (3 measurements >= 7 days apart with last >= 1.0 ng/mL), or new/increasing measurable disease (RECIST), or >= 2 new bone lesions (PCWG3), or increasing symptoms attributed to progression | Surgically or medically castrated with baseline testosterone <= 50 ng/dL | ECOG performance status <= 2 | Hemoglobin >= 10.0 g/dL (>= 8 g/dL if due to marrow infiltration) | Absolute neutrophil count (ANC) >= 1.5 x 10^9/L (>= 1.0 x 10^9/L if due to marrow infiltration) | White blood cells (WBC) > 3 x 10^9/L (> 2 x 10^9/L if due to marrow infiltration) | Platelet count >= 100 x 10^9/L (>= 50 x 10^9/L if due to marrow infiltration) | Total bilirubin <= 1.5 x ULN (except Gilbert syndrome) | AST and ALT <= 2.5 x ULN (<= 5 x ULN with liver metastases) | Calculated creatinine clearance (Cockcroft-Gault) >= 30 mL/min | No features suggestive of MDS/AML on peripheral blood smear | Able to swallow study drugs whole (tablet/capsule)
exclusion_criteria: Any prior treatment for CRPC with carboplatin, cisplatin, cabazitaxel, a PARP inhibitor, or an anti-PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitor | More than one prior line of chemotherapy | Unresolved toxicity from prior therapy > CTCAE grade 2 (except allowed ongoing LHRH therapy, bisphosphonates, or RANK ligand inhibitors) | Any unresolved CTCAE grade >= 2 toxicity from previous anti-cancer therapy (irreversible toxicities not expected to be exacerbated may be allowed) | History or current diagnosis of myelodysplastic syndrome or acute myeloid leukemia | Active uncontrolled infection | Active or symptomatic viral hepatitis or chronic liver disease | History of pneumonitis or extensive bilateral non-malignant lung disease | Another malignancy with >= 30% probability of recurrence within 24 months (except adequately treated non-melanoma skin cancer, curatively treated in-situ cervical cancer, or Ta urothelial carcinoma) | Serious underlying medical or psychiatric condition that would make study drug hazardous or confound adverse event interpretation (e.g., uncontrolled ventricular arrhythmia, recent myocardial infarction, superior vena cava syndrome, uncontrolled seizures, history of allogeneic transplant, primary immunodeficiency) | Unable to swallow oral medication or gastrointestinal disorders likely to interfere with absorption | Symptomatic uncontrolled brain metastases or spinal cord compression | Known hypersensitivity to niraparib, carboplatin, cabazitaxel, or anti-PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitors | Current or prior use of systemic immunosuppressive medication within 28 days before first cetrelimab dose (with specified corticosteroid exceptions) | Active or prior documented autoimmune or inflammatory disorders requiring systemic therapy (with specified exceptions such as vitiligo, alopecia, controlled hypothyroidism, certain inactive diseases, or celiac disease controlled by diet) | Receipt of live attenuated vaccine within 30 days prior to cetrelimab | Compulsory detention for treatment of psychiatric or physical illness
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial is for aggressive variant/metastatic prostate cancer, while the patient has metastatic non-small cell lung cancer with EGFR exon 19 deletion. Therefore, the patient's disease is not included in the trial.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 40 years; Male; Metastatic non-small cell lung cancer; De novo metastatic disease; Bone metastases; Liver metastases; Brain metastases on MRI; EGFR exon 19 deletion; On osimertinib for 2 years; ECOG 0; No significant comorbidities
judge_comment: Disease mismatch is a hard exclusion per rubric. Trial targets prostate cancer; patient has metastatic NSCLC. Grader correctly assigned F with appropriate reasoning.

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: Randomized Phase II Study of Platinum-Taxane-Cetrelimab Induction Followed by Niraparib Plus or Minus Cetrelimab Maintenance in Men With Aggressive Variant Prostate Cancers
diseases_targeted: Aggressive Variant Prostate Carcinoma; Castration-Resistant Prostate Carcinoma; Metastatic Prostate Carcinoma; Metastatic Prostate Neuroendocrine Carcinoma; Metastatic Prostate Small Cell Carcinoma; Stage IV Prostate Cancer
inclusion_criteria: Histologically or cytologically confirmed prostate carcinoma | Metastatic disease documented on imaging (bone scan, CT and/or MRI) | Meets at least one aggressive variant prostate carcinoma (AVPC) criterion | Histologically proven small cell (neuroendocrine) prostate carcinoma (AVPC criterion) | Exclusive visceral metastases (AVPC criterion) | Predominantly lytic bone metastases by x-ray or CT (AVPC criterion) | Bulky (>= 5 cm) lymphadenopathy or high-grade tumor mass in prostate/pelvis (AVPC criterion) | Low PSA (<= 10 ng/mL) at initial presentation or at symptomatic progression in the castrate-setting plus high-volume (>= 20) bone metastases (AVPC criterion) | Elevated LDH (>= 2 x ULN) or elevated CEA (>= 2 x ULN) without other etiologies (AVPC criterion) | Short interval (<= 180 days) to castration-resistant progression after initiation of hormonal therapy (AVPC criterion) | Loss or mutation in at least 2 of TP53, RB1, and PTEN by CLIA-certified testing, IHC and/or DNA sequencing (AVPC criterion) | Castration-resistant progression per RECIST without PSA rising to >= 1.0 ng/mL per PCWG3 (AVPC criterion) | Documented progressive disease by PSA progression (3 measurements >= 7 days apart with last >= 1.0 ng/mL), or new/increasing measurable disease (RECIST), or >= 2 new bone lesions (PCWG3), or increasing symptoms attributed to progression | Surgically or medically castrated with baseline testosterone <= 50 ng/dL | ECOG performance status <= 2 | Hemoglobin >= 10.0 g/dL (>= 8 g/dL if due to marrow infiltration) | Absolute neutrophil count (ANC) >= 1.5 x 10^9/L (>= 1.0 x 10^9/L if due to marrow infiltration) | White blood cells (WBC) > 3 x 10^9/L (> 2 x 10^9/L if due to marrow infiltration) | Platelet count >= 100 x 10^9/L (>= 50 x 10^9/L if due to marrow infiltration) | Total bilirubin <= 1.5 x ULN (except Gilbert syndrome) | AST and ALT <= 2.5 x ULN (<= 5 x ULN with liver metastases) | Calculated creatinine clearance (Cockcroft-Gault) >= 30 mL/min | No features suggestive of MDS/AML on peripheral blood smear | Able to swallow study drugs whole (tablet/capsule)
exclusion_criteria: Any prior treatment for CRPC with carboplatin, cisplatin, cabazitaxel, a PARP inhibitor, or an anti-PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitor | More than one prior line of chemotherapy | Unresolved toxicity from prior therapy > CTCAE grade 2 (except allowed ongoing LHRH therapy, bisphosphonates, or RANK ligand inhibitors) | Any unresolved CTCAE grade >= 2 toxicity from previous anti-cancer therapy (irreversible toxicities not expected to be exacerbated may be allowed) | History or current diagnosis of myelodysplastic syndrome or acute myeloid leukemia | Active uncontrolled infection | Active or symptomatic viral hepatitis or chronic liver disease | History of pneumonitis or extensive bilateral non-malignant lung disease | Another malignancy with >= 30% probability of recurrence within 24 months (except adequately treated non-melanoma skin cancer, curatively treated in-situ cervical cancer, or Ta urothelial carcinoma) | Serious underlying medical or psychiatric condition that would make study drug hazardous or confound adverse event interpretation (e.g., uncontrolled ventricular arrhythmia, recent myocardial infarction, superior vena cava syndrome, uncontrolled seizures, history of allogeneic transplant, primary immunodeficiency) | Unable to swallow oral medication or gastrointestinal disorders likely to interfere with absorption | Symptomatic uncontrolled brain metastases or spinal cord compression | Known hypersensitivity to niraparib, carboplatin, cabazitaxel, or anti-PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitors | Current or prior use of systemic immunosuppressive medication within 28 days before first cetrelimab dose (with specified corticosteroid exceptions) | Active or prior documented autoimmune or inflammatory disorders requiring systemic therapy (with specified exceptions such as vitiligo, alopecia, controlled hypothyroidism, certain inactive diseases, or celiac disease controlled by diet) | Receipt of live attenuated vaccine within 30 days prior to cetrelimab | Compulsory detention for treatment of psychiatric or physical illness
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial is for prostate cancers, while the patient has metastatic urothelial carcinoma. Additionally, the trial excludes prior anti–PD-1/PD-L1 therapy and the patient previously received pembrolizumab.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial carcinoma; Progressing after second line therapy; Prior neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Prior enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab with progression after 6 cycles; Status post cystectomy with pathologic complete response; Age 55 years; Male; Chronic kidney disease with eGFR 35 mL/min; History of type 2 diabetes mellitus; History of COPD
patient_prior_therapies: Neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin; Cystectomy; Enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab
judge_comment: Correct: There is a hard exclusion due to disease mismatch (trial is for prostate cancers; patient has metastatic urothelial carcinoma), which alone mandates F. The added note about prior PD-1 therapy is not necessary and may be contextually specific to CRPC, but the disease mismatch already justifies F.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: A Phase II/III, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Study of Tiragolumab in Combination With Atezolizumab Plus Pemetrexed and Carboplatin/Cisplatin Versus Pembrolizumab Plus Pemetrexed and Carboplatin/Cisplatin in Patients With Previously Untreated Advanced Non-Squamous Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer
diseases_targeted: Non-Squamous Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (metastatic or unresectable)
inclusion_criteria: ECOG performance status 0–1 | Histologically or cytologically documented locally advanced unresectable or metastatic non-squamous NSCLC not eligible for curative surgery and/or definitive chemoradiotherapy | No prior systemic treatment for metastatic non-squamous NSCLC | Known tumor PD-L1 status | Measurable disease per RECIST v1.1 | Life expectancy >= 12 weeks | Adequate hematologic and end-organ function | Negative HIV test at screening | Serology negative for active hepatitis B virus or active hepatitis C virus at screening
exclusion_criteria: EGFR sensitizing mutations or ALK fusion oncogene | Pulmonary lymphoepithelioma-like carcinoma subtype of NSCLC | Symptomatic, untreated, or actively progressing CNS metastases | Active or history of autoimmune disease or immune deficiency | History of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, organizing pneumonia, drug-induced pneumonitis, idiopathic pneumonitis, or evidence of active pneumonitis | History of malignancy other than NSCLC within 5 years prior to randomization, except malignancies with negligible risk of metastasis or death | Severe infection within 4 weeks prior to initiation of study treatment or any active infection that could impact patient safety | Treatment with investigational therapy within 28 days prior to initiation of study treatment | Prior treatment with CD137 agonists or immune checkpoint blockade therapies including anti-CTLA-4, anti-TIGIT, anti-PD-1, or anti-PD-L1 antibodies | Treatment with systemic immunostimulatory agents within 4 weeks or 5 half-lives (whichever is longer) prior to initiation of study treatment | Treatment with systemic immunosuppressive medication within 2 weeks prior to initiation of study treatment or anticipated need for systemic immunosuppressive medication during study treatment | Known allergy or hypersensitivity or other contraindication to any component of the chemotherapy regimen | Pregnant or breastfeeding | Known targetable ROS1 or BRAF V600E genomic aberration
prior_therapies: No prior systemic treatment for metastatic non-squamous NSCLC; Investigational therapy washout >= 28 days
reasoning: The trial explicitly excludes patients with EGFR sensitizing mutations and requires no prior systemic therapy for metastatic NSCLC; this patient has an EGFR exon 19 deletion and has been on osimertinib for 2 years.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 40 years; Male; Metastatic non-small cell lung cancer; De novo metastatic disease; Bone metastases; Liver metastases; Brain metastases on MRI; EGFR exon 19 deletion; On osimertinib for 2 years; ECOG 0; No significant comorbidities
judge_comment: Hard exclusion applies: the trial explicitly excludes EGFR-sensitizing mutations, and the patient has an EGFR exon 19 deletion. This alone yields F. Additionally, the trial requires no prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease, while the patient has received osimertinib, reinforcing ineligibility. The grader’s reasoning and grade align with the rubric.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: A Phase 2 Randomized Study of Relatlimab Plus Nivolumab in Combination With Chemotherapy vs. Nivolumab in Combination With Chemotherapy as First Line Treatment for Participants With Stage IV or Recurrent Non-small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC)
diseases_targeted: Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (metastatic or recurrent)
inclusion_criteria: Histologically confirmed non-small cell lung cancer (squamous or non-squamous) that is stage IVA/IVB or recurrent after multimodal therapy for locally advanced disease. | ECOG performance status <=1 at screening and prior to randomization. | Measurable disease by CT or MRI per RECIST 1.1. | No prior systemic anti-cancer treatment given as primary therapy for advanced or metastatic disease (including EGFR or ALK inhibitors).
exclusion_criteria: EGFR, ALK, ROS1, or BRAF V600E mutations that are sensitive to available targeted therapy. | Untreated central nervous system metastases. | Leptomeningeal metastases. | Concurrent malignancy requiring treatment or prior malignancy active within 2 years before randomization. | Prior treatment with PD-1, PD-L1, PD-L2, CTLA-4, or other T-cell co-stimulation/checkpoint pathway-targeting agents.
prior_therapies: No prior systemic therapy for advanced or metastatic disease.
reasoning: The trial explicitly excludes patients with sensitizing EGFR mutations; the patient has an EGFR exon 19 deletion. Additionally, the study requires no prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease, whereas the patient has received osimertinib.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 40 years; Male; Metastatic non-small cell lung cancer; De novo metastatic disease; Bone metastases; Liver metastases; Brain metastases on MRI; EGFR exon 19 deletion; On osimertinib for 2 years; ECOG 0; No significant comorbidities
judge_comment: The trial has explicit exclusion criteria that the patient violates: (1) exclusion of sensitizing EGFR mutations (patient has EGFR exon 19 deletion) and (2) no prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease (patient received osimertinib). Either is a hard exclusion → F. The grader’s reasoning and grade are correct.

question_text: A 55-year-old female has severe, seropositive rheumatoid arthritis refractory to methotrexate and two prior biologic agents (adalimumab and tocilizumab). She has active disease with a DAS28 score of 5.5.
