judge_comment: Correct: The patient has Duchenne muscular dystrophy, while the trial targets LGMD2E/R4—this is a disease mismatch (hard exclusion). The trial also requires pathogenic SGCB mutations, which the patient does not have (has DMD exon 49-50 deletion), another hard exclusion. Therefore F is appropriate.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: An Interventional Study to Evaluate Treating to a Target of Transmural Healing in Patients With Moderately to Severely Active Crohn's Disease
inclusion_criteria: Age 18 to 80 years | Moderately-to-severely active Crohn disease: CDAI 220 to 450 and SES-CD >= 6 (or >= 4 if isolated ileal disease) | C-reactive protein >= 5 mg/L and/or fecal calprotectin >= 250 µg/g at screening | Bowel wall thickness on intestinal ultrasound > 4.0 mm in the ileum or any colonic segment (excluding rectum) | Biologic-naive or prior exposure to no more than 1 advanced therapeutic (approved biologic or small molecule) for Crohn disease | Stable dose of 5-ASA initiated >= 4 weeks prior to screening may be continued | Persons of childbearing potential: negative serum pregnancy test prior to randomization and use of highly effective contraception during study
exclusion_criteria: Prior treatment with vedolizumab, etrolizumab, or natalizumab | Previously exposed to 2 or more advanced therapeutics (approved biologic or small molecule) for Crohn disease | Change in oral corticosteroid dose within 2 weeks prior to randomization or prednisone > 40 mg (or equivalent) at randomization | Inflammation only proximal to terminal ileum not reachable by ileocolonoscopy | Crohn disease complication requiring procedural intervention (e.g., symptomatic small bowel stricture with > 3 cm prestenotic dilatation) | Previous extensive colonic resection or missing > 2 of 5 segments; ileorectal anastomosis; proctocolectomy | Ostomy or ileoanal pouch | Short bowel syndrome | Fibrotic-only stricture in ileum or colon without active inflammation, including any impassable stenosis | Abscess > 2 cm detected by intestinal ultrasound (participants with draining fistulas are not excluded) | Serious underlying disease other than Crohn disease that may interfere with participation or compromise safety | Positive stool test for Clostridioides difficile toxin | Known HIV infection | Known hepatitis B or hepatitis C infection | Known active or latent tuberculosis | Other systemic or opportunistic infection (including cytomegalovirus), any other clinically significant extraintestinal infection, or recurring infection within 6 months of randomization | Active cerebral or meningeal disease, signs, symptoms, or any history of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy | Hypersensitivity, allergy, or intolerance to vedolizumab excipients or any contraindication to vedolizumab | Active severe infection such as sepsis, cytomegalovirus, listeriosis, or opportunistic infection | Unwilling to withhold protocol-prohibited medications during the trial | Participation in another clinical trial with investigational therapy within 30 days or 5 half-lives (whichever is longer) prior to randomization | History of alcohol or drug abuse that may interfere with compliance | Prior enrollment in the current study and received study treatment | Pregnant, lactating, or intending pregnancy; or intending to donate ova or sperm during and up to 18 weeks after last dose | Live or live-attenuated vaccine within 4 weeks prior to randomization or planned during the study
prior_therapies: Biologic-naive or <= 1 prior advanced therapeutic for Crohn disease allowed; Stable 5-ASA for >= 4 weeks prior to screening allowed; No change to oral corticosteroid dosing within 2 weeks prior to randomization
reasoning: The trial explicitly excludes patients previously exposed to 2 or more advanced therapeutics for Crohn’s disease; this patient has failed both infliximab and ustekinumab (two advanced therapies). While age and disease activity fit, the prior therapy history is a hard exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease; CDAI score 350; Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab; Active perianal fistula with draining seton in place; Recently completed IV antibiotics for perianal abscess
judge_comment: The trial excludes participants previously exposed to 2 or more advanced therapeutics; the patient has failed infliximab and ustekinumab (two advanced therapies). This is a hard exclusion, so F is correct.

question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.
trial_title: Developing a Nonpharmacological Pain Intervention for Community-dwelling Older Adults With Dementia
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 60 years | Mild or very mild dementia | Knee pain lasting >= 3 months | Average knee pain intensity >= 2/10
exclusion_criteria: Life expectancy < 1 year | Recent changes to pain or psychotropic medications within 60 days | Knee surgery within the past 1 year | Medical condition that contraindicates exercise | Currently receiving rehabilitation services
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: The trial requires mild or very mild dementia, whereas the patient has moderate-stage dementia (MMSE 19), failing a mandatory inclusion criterion. Other factors (e.g., knee pain) are unknown but do not override this explicit mismatch.
patient_biomarkers: Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 68 years; Male; Progressive cognitive decline for 2 years; MMSE score 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
judge_comment: Trial requires mild/very mild dementia; patient has moderate dementia (MMSE 19), a definitive failure of a required stage/severity criterion, which is a hard exclusion per rubric. Other criteria like knee pain are unknown and do not affect the hard exclusion. The grader’s F is correct.

question_text: A 55-year-old female has severe, seropositive rheumatoid arthritis refractory to methotrexate and two prior biologic agents (adalimumab and tocilizumab). She has active disease with a DAS28 score of 5.5. Critically, she has a history of treated Hepatitis B (HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive) and moderate chronic kidney disease with an eGFR of 45 mL/min/1.73m². What are trial options for her?
trial_title: A Pilot and Feasibility Study Focusing on Lifestyle, Environmental Modifications, and Transdisciplinary Clinical Care for Children With Chronic Illness: Protocol for the FLIGHT Study
diseases_targeted: Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis; Asthma; Eczema; Allergies; Crohn's Disease; Ulcerative Colitis; Lupus; Obesity; Type 2 Diabetes; Autism Spectrum Disorder; Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder; Depression; Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder; Anxiety Disorder
inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis in immune/autoimmune conditions (e.g., juvenile idiopathic arthritis, juvenile rheumatoid arthritis, asthma, eczema, atopic illness, allergies, Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis, lupus) | Diagnosis in conditions of metabolic dysregulation (e.g., obesity, type 2 diabetes) | Diagnosis in mood/behavioral/developmental conditions (e.g., autism spectrum disorder, ADHD/ADD, depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, anxiety)
exclusion_criteria: Condition severe enough to preclude participation in an intensive, multi-modal lifestyle intervention | Pregnancy
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: The trial targets pediatric conditions (e.g., juvenile idiopathic/juvenile rheumatoid arthritis) with an age range of 2–15, while the patient is a 55-year-old adult with rheumatoid arthritis. This creates both a disease cohort mismatch and an age window conflict.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Seropositive rheumatoid arthritis; Active disease with DAS28 score of 5.5; History of treated Hepatitis B (HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive); Moderate chronic kidney disease (eGFR 45 mL/min/1.73 m^2)
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to methotrexate; Prior adalimumab; Prior tocilizumab; Failed two prior biologic agents
judge_comment: Age window conflict (2–15 vs patient 55) and disease mismatch (trial targets juvenile arthritis, not adult RA) are hard exclusions. The grader correctly identified these and assigned F.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 11-year-old boy with Duchenne muscular dystrophy confirmed by a deletion of exons 49-50. He lost ambulation 8 months ago and is now dependent on a power wheelchair. He is on a stable regimen of deflazacort and lisinopril for early cardiomyopathy (LVEF 52%). His Performance of Upper Limb (PUL) score is 18. His parents are interested in trials for non-ambulatory patients.
trial_title: A Phase 1b, Double-Blinded, Randomized, Placebo-Controlled Study to Assess the Safety, Tolerability, Pharmacokinetics, Immunogenicity, and Efficacy of ARGX-119 in Adult Participants with DOK7-Congenital Myasthenic Syndromes
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Genetically confirmed congenital myasthenic syndrome due to DOK7 mutation | If taking oral beta agonists (e.g., albuterol, salbutamol, ephedrine), on a stable regimen for > 3 months and agree to remain on the same stable dose through the study
exclusion_criteria: Congenital myasthenic syndrome due to mutation in a gene other than DOK7 | Medical condition that would interfere with accurate assessment of CMS, confound results, or pose undue risk, per investigator | History of malignancy unless cured with no recurrence for > 5 years (basal or squamous cell skin cancer, carcinoma in situ of cervix or breast, incidental prostate cancer may be included at any time) | Received a different study drug in another clinical study within 12 weeks or 5 half-lives before screening | Current participation in another interventional clinical study | Prior participation in any gene therapy or cell therapy study | Pregnant or lactating, or intending to become pregnant during the study
prior_therapies: Stable oral beta agonist therapy >= 3 months if used
reasoning: This study enrolls adults with genetically confirmed DOK7-congenital myasthenic syndrome, whereas the patient has Duchenne muscular dystrophy with a DMD exon 49-50 deletion and is 11 years old. This fails the disease, required biomarker, and age criteria.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 11 years; Male sex; Duchenne muscular dystrophy confirmed by deletion of exons 49-50; Non-ambulatory (lost ambulation 8 months ago); Power wheelchair dependent; Stable deflazacort regimen; Early cardiomyopathy with LVEF 52%; Performance of Upper Limb (PUL) score 18
judge_comment: Clear hard exclusions: disease mismatch (trial is for DOK7 congenital myasthenic syndrome, patient has Duchenne muscular dystrophy) and age mismatch (trial >=18, patient is 11). Grader’s F and reasoning are consistent with the rubric.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: A Phase 3 Open-label, Randomized, Active-controlled, Multicenter Trial to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of Orally Administered BAY 2927088 Compared With Standard of Care as a First-line Therapy in Patients With Locally Advanced or Metastatic Non-small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) With HER2-activating Mutations
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Histologically or cytologically confirmed locally advanced non-squamous non-small cell lung cancer not suitable for definitive therapy or metastatic non-squamous non-small cell lung cancer (Stage III–IV) | Activating HER2 mutation in the tyrosine kinase domain confirmed by tissue molecular test in an accredited laboratory | No prior systemic therapy for locally advanced or metastatic disease | No prior HER2 exon 20 insertion–targeted therapy | Prior adjuvant or neoadjuvant therapy allowed if completed >= 12 months before screening | Eligible to receive platinum-pemetrexed doublet chemotherapy and pembrolizumab per product information
exclusion_criteria: Prior malignancy unless curatively treated with no recurrence for 5 years (specific in situ cancers, superficial bladder cancer, limited-stage prostate cancer, and basal or squamous skin cancers allowed if appropriately treated) | Tumors harboring other targetable alterations with approved available therapy (except HER2 mutation in the TKD) | Inability to discontinue chronic systemic corticosteroids | Pre-existing peripheral neuropathy Grade >= 2 (CTCAE v5.0) | History of severe hypersensitivity reaction to a monoclonal antibody | Radiotherapy outside of the brain within 21 days prior to start of study intervention or unresolved radiation-related toxicities or requirement for corticosteroids
prior_therapies: No prior systemic therapy for locally advanced or metastatic disease; No prior HER2 exon 20 insertion–targeted therapy; Adjuvant or neoadjuvant therapy allowed if completed >= 12 months before screening
reasoning: This first-line trial requires a HER2-activating mutation and no prior systemic therapy; the patient has an EGFR exon 19 deletion and has received osimertinib. Additionally, the trial excludes tumors with other targetable alterations (e.g., EGFR).
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 40 years; Male; Metastatic non-small cell lung cancer; De novo metastatic disease; Bone metastases; Liver metastases; Brain metastases on MRI; EGFR exon 19 deletion; On osimertinib for 2 years; ECOG 0; No significant comorbidities
judge_comment: Hard exclusion applies: the trial explicitly excludes tumors with other targetable alterations with approved therapy (e.g., EGFR), which the patient has. While lack of documented HER2 mutation alone wouldn’t trigger F under the rubric, and prior systemic therapy is an inclusion mismatch (not a hard exclusion by itself), the explicit exclusion criterion is sufficient for an F.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: An Open-Label, Single-Center, Investigator Initiated Phase 1B Trial of E-CEL UVEC Cell Therapy for the Treatment of Chronic Anal Fissure
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Anterior or posterior chronic anal fissure for >= 6 weeks | Inadequate response to medical therapy: failed vasodilator treatment for 1 month and declined or failed botulinum injection | Pain on defecation NRS >= 4 | Systolic blood pressure >= 90 and < 140 mmHg | Diastolic blood pressure >= 60 and < 90 mmHg | Respiratory rate >= 12 and <= 20 breaths per minute | Pulse >= 60 and <= 100 beats per minute | Temperature >= 97.8 F and <= 99.1 F | O2 saturation > 92%
exclusion_criteria: Lateral anal fissure | Peri-anal or rectovaginal fistula, rectal or anal stenosis, peri-anal abscess, or non-healing peri-anal post-surgical wounds | Active, untreated or medically unresponsive infection of the anal fissure or fistula | Active systemic infection (controlled HIV infection allowed) | Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis) | Currently receiving systemic chemotherapy or local pelvic radiation | Renal impairment: serum creatinine >= 1.5 x ULN | Hepatic impairment: total bilirubin >= 1.5 x ULN and AST/ALT >= 2.5 x ULN | Active alcohol or substance use that would interfere with study follow-up | Active malignant tumor (unless in remission for >= 6 months without maintenance chemotherapy and/or radiation) | Abnormal, severe, progressive, or uncontrolled hepatic, hematological, gastrointestinal, endocrine, pulmonary, cardiac, neurological, psychiatric, or cerebral diseases (ongoing or within 6 months) | Congenital immunodeficiencies | Major surgery or severe trauma within the previous 3 months | Candidates for solid organ transplantation or high likelihood of needing a solid organ transplant | Pregnant or breastfeeding, or planning pregnancy or breastfeeding during the study | Known hypersensitivity or allergy to DMSO
prior_therapies: Failed topical vasodilator therapy for >= 1 month; Declined or failed botulinum injection
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets chronic anal fissure and explicitly excludes inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's) and peri-anal fistula. The patient has fistulizing Crohn's disease with an active perianal fistula, which is a hard exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease; CDAI score 350; Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab; Active perianal fistula with draining seton in place; Recently completed IV antibiotics for perianal abscess
judge_comment: Correct: There is a hard exclusion. The trial targets chronic anal fissure and explicitly excludes inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn’s) and peri-anal fistula, both of which apply to the patient with fistulizing Crohn’s and active perianal fistula. Disease mismatch also applies.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: A Phase 2b, Multicenter, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled Study to Evaluate the Efficacy, Safety, Pharmacokinetics, and Pharmacodynamics of Obefazimod in Subjects With Moderately to Severely Active Crohn's Disease
inclusion_criteria: Age 18 to 75 years | Confirmed Crohn disease by endoscopy and histology | Moderately to severely active Crohn disease: CDAI 220–450 | SES-CD >= 6 for ileo-colonic or colonic disease, or SES-CD >= 4 for isolated ileal disease (per central reading) | Documented inadequate response, loss of response, or intolerance to at least one: corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, biologic or biosimilar therapies, or JAK inhibitors
exclusion_criteria: Ulcerative colitis or indeterminate colitis | Crohn disease without ileal and/or colonic involvement | Untreated active external or perianal fistula or abscess (recent abscess must be drained and adequately treated per protocol timelines) | Symptomatic bowel stricture or stenosis not passable on endoscopy | Current stoma or ileoanal pouch | More than two missing complete segments among terminal ileum, right colon, transverse colon, left colon, and sigmoid/rectum | Combined prior small bowel resections > 100 cm | Surgical bowel resection within 3 months prior to baseline | Any manifestation likely to require surgery during the study | Use of prohibited concomitant therapies for Crohn disease | Prior natalizumab or any other alpha4beta1 integrin agonist | Failure of more than three advanced therapies for Crohn disease, or failure of two different mechanisms of action of advanced therapies | History of or active malignancy (except subjects with >= 5-year disease-free survival) | History of colonic cancer or dysplasia adenomatous polyps, or evidence of such polyps at screening endoscopy | Primary sclerosing cholangitis, autoimmune hepatitis, or primary biliary cirrhosis | Serious illness requiring hospitalization (not related to Crohn disease) within 4 weeks prior to screening | Chronic or recurrent grade 3–4 infection within 2 months prior to screening or history of opportunistic infection while not on immunosuppressive therapy | Herpes zoster reactivation within 2 months prior to screening | Active infection at screening or major infection requiring hospitalization or IV antibiotics within 1 month prior to or during screening | Positive stool assay or culture for pathogens requiring treatment or positive Clostridioides difficile toxin at screening | HIV infection | Acute or chronic hepatitis B infection | Acute or chronic hepatitis C infection (unless successfully treated with no detectable HCV RNA for >= 1 year) | Active tuberculosis or untreated latent tuberculosis | Uncontrolled ischemic heart disease or history of congestive heart failure | Congenital or acquired long QT syndrome or marked baseline prolonged QTc | History of torsade de pointes | Clinically relevant pulmonary, hepatic, or renal abnormality; encephalopathy; neuropathy; unstable CNS pathology including seizure disorder; or other significant medical problems | Live vaccine within 3 months prior to screening or planned during the study | Acute or chronic pancreatitis | Hemoglobin <= 8.0 g/dL | Absolute neutrophil count < 750/µL | Platelets < 100,000/µL | eGFR < 60 mL/min | Total bilirubin > 1.5 x ULN (except Gilbert syndrome) | AST > 2 x ULN or ALT > 2 x ULN | Did not meet protocol-specified washout periods prior to screening endoscopy | Use of any investigational or nonregistered product within 3 months or within 5 half-lives prior to baseline, whichever is longer | Prior obefazimod exposure or known hypersensitivity to obefazimod or excipients | Illicit drug or alcohol abuse or dependence | Any condition that could compromise safety or adherence in the investigator's opinion
prior_therapies: Inadequate response, loss of response, or intolerance to at least one of: corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, biologic or biosimilar therapies, or JAK inhibitors for Crohn disease; No investigational or nonregistered product within 3 months or 5 half-lives prior to baseline; Meet protocol-specified washout periods before screening endoscopy
reasoning: Despite disease and age matching, the trial explicitly excludes patients who have failed two different mechanisms of advanced therapies; this patient failed infliximab (anti-TNF) and ustekinumab (anti–IL-12/23).
patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease; CDAI score 350; Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab; Active perianal fistula with draining seton in place; Recently completed IV antibiotics for perianal abscess
judge_comment: The trial explicitly excludes patients who have failed two different mechanisms of advanced therapies. The patient failed infliximab (anti-TNF) and ustekinumab (IL-12/23), triggering a hard exclusion. Age/sex/disease otherwise match but hard exclusion → F.

question_text: What are trial options for a 66 year old male with hx hypertension, afib, T2DM and mCRPC, now progressing on enzalutamide? He has been on Lupron+Zytiga for 3 years, with new liver and bone metastases which are all PSMA PET avid. He’s tolerated therapy well overall except for grade 2 fatigue.
trial_title: A Randomized, Controlled Trial of Magnesium Sulfate as an Adjunctive Analgesic in Prostate Surgery
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Undergoing robotic prostatectomy under general anesthesia | Able and willing to provide informed consent
exclusion_criteria: Age < 18 years | End-stage renal disease | Allergy to magnesium sulfate | Unable to comply with study procedures
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets patients undergoing robotic prostatectomy (perioperative analgesia), not metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer. Although age and sex fit, the disease/setting does not.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 66 years; Male; Castration-resistant prostate cancer; Metastatic disease; PSMA PET avid disease; Liver metastases; Bone metastases; Progression on enzalutamide; Prior abiraterone (Zytiga); Prior leuprolide (Lupron)
judge_comment: The trial targets patients undergoing robotic prostatectomy (perioperative analgesia) and lists “Prostatectomy” as the disease context, which does not include metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer. This is a disease mismatch, a hard exclusion per the rubric, so F is correct. The grader’s reasoning correctly identified this.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 11-year-old boy with Duchenne muscular dystrophy confirmed by a deletion of exons 49-50. He lost ambulation 8 months ago and is now dependent on a power wheelchair. He is on a stable regimen of deflazacort and lisinopril for early cardiomyopathy (LVEF 52%). His Performance of Upper Limb (PUL) score is 18. His parents are interested in trials for non-ambulatory patients.
trial_title: A Phase 2a, Randomised, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Study to Evaluate the Efficacy, Safety, and Tolerability of NMD670 Over 21 Days in Ambulatory Adult Patients With Type 1 and Type 2 Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease
inclusion_criteria: Age 18 to 70 years | Diagnosis of Charcot-Marie-Tooth type 1 or type 2 confirmed by genetic testing | Body mass index 18 to 35 kg/m2 and weight >= 40 kg
exclusion_criteria: Other significant disease that may interfere with study assessments, including other neuromuscular diseases | Clinically significant laboratory abnormalities at screening | Received another investigational medicinal product within 30 days or 5 half-lives prior to Day 1 | Pregnant or breastfeeding
prior_therapies: No investigational product within 30 days or 5 half-lives prior to Day 1
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (CMT1/2), not Duchenne muscular dystrophy. The patient is also 11 years old (trial requires 18–70) and non-ambulatory, while the study enrolls ambulatory adults.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 11 years; Male sex; Duchenne muscular dystrophy confirmed by deletion of exons 49-50; Non-ambulatory (lost ambulation 8 months ago); Power wheelchair dependent; Stable deflazacort regimen; Early cardiomyopathy with LVEF 52%; Performance of Upper Limb (PUL) score 18
judge_comment: There is a clear hard exclusion: disease mismatch (trial targets Charcot-Marie-Tooth, patient has Duchenne muscular dystrophy). Additionally, the patient is 11 years old vs trial minimum age 18. Either hard exclusion mandates grade F. The grader’s reasoning correctly identified these factors.

question_text: I have a 62-year-old male patient diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) 14 months ago. He has limb-onset disease and an ALSFRS-R score of 38. His forced vital capacity (FVC) is stable at 85% of predicted. He is currently taking riluzole. What trial options are available?
trial_title: A Phase 2a, Randomised, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Study to Evaluate the Efficacy, Safety, and Tolerability of NMD670 Over 21 Days in Ambulatory Adult Patients With Type 1 and Type 2 Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease
inclusion_criteria: Age 18 to 70 years | Diagnosis of Charcot-Marie-Tooth type 1 or type 2 confirmed by genetic testing | Body mass index 18 to 35 kg/m2 and weight >= 40 kg
exclusion_criteria: Other significant disease that may interfere with study assessments, including other neuromuscular diseases | Clinically significant laboratory abnormalities at screening | Received another investigational medicinal product within 30 days or 5 half-lives prior to Day 1 | Pregnant or breastfeeding
prior_therapies: No investigational product within 30 days or 5 half-lives prior to Day 1
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease (type 1 or 2), while the patient has ALS. Additionally, the trial excludes other neuromuscular diseases, which would include ALS.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS); Limb-onset disease; ALSFRS-R score 38; Forced vital capacity (FVC) 85% of predicted; Currently taking riluzole; Time since diagnosis 14 months; Age 62 years; Male sex
judge_comment: Correct: There is a hard exclusion due to disease mismatch (trial is for Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease; patient has ALS). The grader’s added note about excluding other neuromuscular diseases further supports ineligibility but isn’t necessary. Grade F is appropriate.

question_text: 40 year old man with recurrent glioblastoma. Diagnosed 1 year ago, underwent gross total resection with confirmation of GBM, IDH wildtype. Completed adjuvant radiation + concurrent temozolomide and then adjuvant temozolomide. Three months after completing adjuvant therapy, MRI shows recurrence. ECOG 1 and no other medical issues. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Pilot Trial of Adjuvant Hypofractionated Stereotactic Radiosurgery for Intermediate-risk Meningioma (SRS-AIM)
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Histologic diagnosis of newly diagnosed WHO grade 2 meningioma or recurrent WHO grade 1 meningioma with radiographic evidence of recurrence and WHO grade 1 histology at most recent resection | Gross-total surgical resection (Simpson grade I–III) within 180 days of enrollment | ECOG 0–1 (Karnofsky >= 70%) | Post-operative MRI indicating anatomy suitable for hypofractionated stereotactic radiosurgery
exclusion_criteria: Extensive multifocal meningiomas (>= 3) or metastatic disease | Tumor within 2 mm of the optic apparatus or brainstem | Another active primary malignancy unless complete remission achieved >= 2 years prior and no additional therapy required during the study period | Pregnancy | Underlying medical or psychiatric condition that would interfere with evaluation of study treatment or interpretation of safety/results | Uncontrolled seizures (>3 disabling seizures per day while on anti-epileptic drugs) | Prior intracranial radiotherapy overlapping the planned stereotactic radiosurgery target
prior_therapies: Gross-total surgical resection (Simpson grade I–III) required within 180 days prior to enrollment
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets WHO grade 2 or recurrent grade 1 meningioma, while the patient has recurrent glioblastoma (IDH-wildtype). This triggers a hard exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Histologically confirmed glioblastoma; IDH wildtype; Recurrent disease after standard therapy; ECOG 1; Age 40 years; Male; Prior gross total resection; Completed adjuvant radiation with concurrent temozolomide; Completed adjuvant temozolomide
patient_prior_therapies: Gross total resection; Radiation therapy with concurrent temozolomide; Adjuvant temozolomide
judge_comment: Disease mismatch is a hard exclusion: the trial is for meningioma while the patient has recurrent glioblastoma. The grader correctly assigned F based on this.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 11-year-old boy with Duchenne muscular dystrophy confirmed by a deletion of exons 49-50. He lost ambulation 8 months ago and is now dependent on a power wheelchair. He is on a stable regimen of deflazacort and lisinopril for early cardiomyopathy (LVEF 52%). His Performance of Upper Limb (PUL) score is 18. His parents are interested in trials for non-ambulatory patients.
trial_title: Evaluation of Automatic Expiratory Positive Airway Pressure (Auto-EPAP) for Management of Upper Airway Obstruction During Non-Invasive Ventilation With Vivo 45 LS
diseases_targeted: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease; Neuromuscular Disease; Obesity Hypoventilation Syndrome; Obstructive Sleep Apnea
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Documented respiratory failure with sleep hypoventilation and historical transcutaneous CO2 (PtCO2) increase >= 10 mmHg and/or daytime hypercapnia > 45 mmHg | Currently using non-invasive positive pressure ventilation for 1 month | Apnea-hypopnea index >= 5/hr | EPAP settings reviewed within <= 12 months
exclusion_criteria: Non-compliance with NIV (use < 4 hours/night) | Pregnant | On oxygen therapy >= 5 L/min | Invasive interface (e.g., tracheostomy) | Acute exacerbation within the last 3 months resulting in hospitalization | Acutely ill, medically complicated, or medically unstable | NIV therapy medically contraindicated | Surgery of the upper airway, nose, sinus, or middle ear within the previous 90 days | Untreated non-obstructive sleep disorders (e.g., insomnia, periodic limb movement syndrome, restless legs syndrome) | Severe bullous lung disease | Recurrent pneumothorax or pneumomediastinum | Cerebrospinal fluid leak | Recent cranial surgery or trauma
prior_therapies: Currently using non-invasive ventilation for 1 month
reasoning: The trial requires participants to be at least 18 years old, while the patient is 11, which is a hard age-window exclusion. Other criteria are irrelevant once this exclusion applies.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 11 years; Male sex; Duchenne muscular dystrophy confirmed by deletion of exons 49-50; Non-ambulatory (lost ambulation 8 months ago); Power wheelchair dependent; Stable deflazacort regimen; Early cardiomyopathy with LVEF 52%; Performance of Upper Limb (PUL) score 18
judge_comment: Patient is 11 years old while the trial minimum age is 18, which is a hard age-window exclusion. Therefore F is correct; no need to assess other anchors.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: A Phase III, Multicenter, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Study to Assess the Efficacy and Safety of Induction Therapy With RO7790121 in Patients With Moderately to Severely Active Ulcerative Colitis
inclusion_criteria: Confirmed diagnosis of ulcerative colitis | Moderately to severely active ulcerative colitis assessed by modified Mayo Score | Body weight >= 40 kg | Up to date colorectal cancer screening per local standards | Inadequate response, loss of response, or intolerance to at least one conventional or advanced ulcerative colitis therapy
exclusion_criteria: Complications of ulcerative colitis (e.g., fulminant colitis, toxic megacolon) | Crohn's disease, indeterminate colitis, microscopic colitis, ischemic colitis, infectious colitis, or radiation colitis | Presence of an ostomy or ileoanal pouch | Primary sclerosing cholangitis | Pregnancy or breastfeeding | Past or current colonic dysplasia, adenomas, or neoplasia not completely removed | Malignancy within 5 years except adequately treated non-metastatic basal cell or squamous cell skin cancer or in situ cervical cancer | Infection with Clostridioides difficile, cytomegalovirus, HIV, hepatitis B, or hepatitis C | Active tuberculosis or latent/inadequately treated tuberculosis | Prior exposure to anti-TL1A therapy or other protocol-prohibited medicines
prior_therapies: Inadequate response, loss of response, or intolerance to at least one conventional or advanced ulcerative colitis therapy
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial is for ulcerative colitis and explicitly excludes Crohn's disease, which the patient has.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease; CDAI score 350; Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab; Active perianal fistula with draining seton in place; Recently completed IV antibiotics for perianal abscess
judge_comment: Disease mismatch is a hard exclusion. The trial is for ulcerative colitis and explicitly excludes Crohn’s disease, while the patient has Crohn’s disease. Grade F is correct.

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Phase 1 Study of ALN-BCAT as Monotherapy and in Combination With Pembrolizumab in Patients With Advanced or Metastatic Hepatocellular Carcinoma
diseases_targeted: Advanced Hepatocellular Carcinoma; Metastatic Hepatocellular Carcinoma
inclusion_criteria: Histologic, cytologic, or AASLD clinical diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma | At least one prior line of systemic therapy for unresectable advanced or metastatic disease | At least one WNT-pathway activating mutation | Child-Pugh class A or B7
exclusion_criteria: Fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma | Sarcomatoid hepatocellular carcinoma | Mixed cholangiohepatocellular carcinoma | Symptomatic extrahepatic disease | Received anti-cancer therapy or investigational drugs <= 3 weeks prior to first dose
prior_therapies: At least one prior line of systemic therapy for unresectable advanced or metastatic disease; Washout >= 3 weeks from prior anti-cancer therapy or investigational drugs
reasoning: Hard exclusion: the trial is for advanced/metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma, while the patient has metastatic urothelial carcinoma. Therefore, the disease does not match the trial’s targeted population.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial carcinoma; Progressing after second line therapy; Prior neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin (4 cycles); Prior enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab with progression after 6 cycles; Status post cystectomy with pathologic complete response; Age 55 years; Male; Chronic kidney disease with eGFR 35 mL/min; History of type 2 diabetes mellitus; History of COPD
patient_prior_therapies: Neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin; Cystectomy; Enfortumab vedotin plus pembrolizumab
judge_comment: Disease mismatch is a hard exclusion: trial targets hepatocellular carcinoma, while the patient has metastatic urothelial carcinoma. The grader correctly assigned F based on this.

question_text: A 55-year-old female has severe, seropositive rheumatoid arthritis refractory to methotrexate and two prior biologic agents (adalimumab and tocilizumab). She has active disease with a DAS28 score of 5.5. Critically, she has a history of treated Hepatitis B (HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive) and moderate chronic kidney disease with an eGFR of 45 mL/min/1.73m². What are trial options for her?
trial_title: A Randomized, Double-Blind, Phase 2, Efficacy and Safety Cross-Over Study of Allogeneic HB-adMSCs vs Placebo for the Treatment of Oligoarticular and Polyarticular Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis
diseases_targeted: Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (oligoarticular); Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (polyarticular)
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 2 years and < 17 years | Diagnosed with oligoarticular or polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis by a pediatric rheumatologist | Rheumatoid factor test result documented | >= 3 affected joints at screening | Body weight > 10 kg | Either not on current JIA treatment due to failure of at least 2 approved medications, or on a stable arthritis therapy regimen for >= 3 months prior to screening | Abnormal CRP > 1 mg/dL and/or abnormal ESR at screening
exclusion_criteria: WBC < 3000/µL or > 15000/µL | Hemoglobin < 8 g/dL | Absolute neutrophil count < 1500/µL | Platelets < 150000/µL | Sodium < 120 mEq/L or > 150 mEq/L | Glucose > 150 mg/dL | Potassium < 3.5 mEq/L or > 6 mEq/L | BUN > 25 mg/dL | Creatinine > 2 mg/dL | BUN/Creatinine ratio > 50 | AST > 100 U/L | ALT > 100 U/L | Vital sign abnormalities at screening as determined by investigator | Significant uncontrolled concurrent medical conditions (e.g., diabetes mellitus, Crohn's disease, lupus, multiple sclerosis) | Active malignancy including cutaneous basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, or melanoma | Alcohol addiction/dependency or current substance use/abuse | Received any stem cell treatment within 1 year before first dose other than Hope Biosciences stem cells | Receiving any investigational therapy or any approved therapy for investigational use within 1 year prior to first dose (except COVID-19 vaccines) | Other laboratory abnormality or medical condition posing safety risk or preventing study completion in investigator's opinion | Known hepatitis B, hepatitis C, or HIV infection | Systemic infection requiring treatment with antibiotics, antivirals, or antifungals within 30 days prior to first dose
prior_therapies: Failed at least 2 approved therapies for JIA; Stable arthritis therapy for >= 3 months prior to screening permitted
reasoning: Hard exclusions apply: the trial targets juvenile idiopathic arthritis (not rheumatoid arthritis) and requires age 2–16, while the patient is 55. Therefore, the patient does not meet the trial’s disease and age criteria.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Seropositive rheumatoid arthritis; Active disease with DAS28 score of 5.5; History of treated Hepatitis B (HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive); Moderate chronic kidney disease (eGFR 45 mL/min/1.73 m^2)
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to methotrexate; Prior adalimumab; Prior tocilizumab; Failed two prior biologic agents
judge_comment: Correct: There is a disease mismatch (JIA vs adult RA) and an age conflict (trial 2–16, patient 55), both hard exclusions per rubric, so F is warranted.

question_text: 40 year old man with recurrent glioblastoma. Diagnosed 1 year ago, underwent gross total resection with confirmation of GBM, IDH wildtype. Completed adjuvant radiation + concurrent temozolomide and then adjuvant temozolomide. Three months after completing adjuvant therapy, MRI shows recurrence. ECOG 1 and no other medical issues. What are trial options?
trial_title: Chronic Convection Enhanced Delivery of Topotecan for Recurrent Malignant Glioma
inclusion_criteria: Recurrent malignant glioma, IDH-mutant, WHO grade 3–4; progression on imaging with suspicion of histologic recurrence | Patients with prior WHO grade 2 IDH-mutant glioma now demonstrating high-grade (WHO grade 3–4) features | Failed standard-of-care treatment | MRI within 30 days showing an enhancing mass without significant mass effect | Tumor volume <32 cc and stereotactically accessible | Karnofsky performance status >=70% | Age >=18 years | Adequate organ and marrow function per protocol thresholds | Women of childbearing potential: negative pregnancy test within 7 days of entry and use of birth control; men and women must use contraception per protocol timelines
exclusion_criteria: Diffuse subependymal or cerebrospinal fluid disease | Tumors involving the cerebellum or both cerebral hemispheres | Active infection requiring treatment or unexplained febrile illness | Known HIV, hepatitis B, or hepatitis C positivity | Systemic diseases conferring unacceptable anesthetic/operative risk | Prior systemic topotecan for the tumor | Inability to undergo MRI or PET imaging | Allergy to topotecan, other topoisomerase inhibitors, or gadolinium compounds | Concomitant use of drugs metabolized solely by CYP3A4/5 with a narrow therapeutic index or strong CYP2C8 inhibitors, or agents with QT prolongation risk that are CYP3A substrates (must discontinue >=2 weeks before treatment) | Uncontrolled intercurrent illness (e.g., congestive heart failure, unstable angina, cardiac arrhythmia, significant psychiatric illness) | Positive pregnancy test within 7 days of registration | Breastfeeding
prior_therapies: Failed standard-of-care therapy for malignant glioma
reasoning: The trial requires IDH-mutant malignant glioma (WHO grade 3–4), but the patient’s glioblastoma is IDH-wildtype. This required biomarker mismatch is a hard exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Histologically confirmed glioblastoma; IDH wildtype; Recurrent disease after standard therapy; ECOG 1; Age 40 years; Male; Prior gross total resection; Completed adjuvant radiation with concurrent temozolomide; Completed adjuvant temozolomide
patient_prior_therapies: Gross total resection; Radiation therapy with concurrent temozolomide; Adjuvant temozolomide
judge_comment: Trial requires IDH-mutant malignant glioma; patient is IDH-wildtype. This is a required biomarker mismatch and a hard exclusion per rubric, so F is correct.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: A Phase III, Randomized, Double-blind, Multicenter, Global Study of Rilvegostomig or Pembrolizumab in Combination With Platinum-based Chemotherapy for the First-line Treatment of Patients With Metastatic Squamous Non-small Cell Lung Cancer Whose Tumors Express PD-L1 (ARTEMIDE-Lung02)
inclusion_criteria: Histologically or cytologically confirmed squamous non-small cell lung cancer. | Stage IV metastatic NSCLC not amenable to curative treatment. | No actionable driver oncogenes with approved first-line targeted therapies per local testing. | Tumor PD-L1 expression on tumor cells (TC) >= 1%. | At least one measurable lesion by RECIST 1.1 not previously irradiated (>= 10 mm longest diameter; lymph nodes short axis >= 15 mm) suitable for repeated measurements by CT or MRI. | Adequate organ and bone marrow function.
exclusion_criteria: Presence of small cell or neuroendocrine histology components. | Active or uncontrolled brain metastases; allowed only if asymptomatic, stable, off steroids and anticonvulsants >= 7 days; >= 2 weeks since local therapy with recovery from acute effects. | Any prior systemic therapy for advanced or metastatic NSCLC. | Any prior treatment with an anti-PD-1 or anti-PD-L1 agent. | Any prior exposure to anti-TIGIT therapy or other anticancer therapy targeting immune-regulatory receptors or mechanisms. | History of another primary malignancy unless treated with curative intent with no active disease for >= 2 years and low risk of recurrence. | Active or prior autoimmune or inflammatory disorders requiring chronic steroids or other immunosuppressive treatment. | Active primary immunodeficiency or active infectious disease(s). | Active tuberculosis infection.
prior_therapies: No prior systemic therapy for advanced/metastatic NSCLC
reasoning: Explicit exclusions apply: the trial requires no prior systemic therapy for metastatic NSCLC and no actionable driver oncogenes, while the patient has an EGFR exon 19 deletion and has been on osimertinib for 2 years for metastatic disease.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 40 years; Male; Metastatic non-small cell lung cancer; De novo metastatic disease; Bone metastases; Liver metastases; Brain metastases on MRI; EGFR exon 19 deletion; On osimertinib for 2 years; ECOG 0; No significant comorbidities
judge_comment: Hard exclusions apply: the trial excludes any prior systemic therapy for advanced/metastatic NSCLC, and requires no actionable driver oncogenes. The patient has received osimertinib for metastatic disease and harbors an EGFR exon 19 deletion. Thus F is correct.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 11-year-old boy with Duchenne muscular dystrophy confirmed by a deletion of exons 49-50. He lost ambulation 8 months ago and is now dependent on a power wheelchair. He is on a stable regimen of deflazacort and lisinopril for early cardiomyopathy (LVEF 52%). His Performance of Upper Limb (PUL) score is 18. His parents are interested in trials for non-ambulatory patients.
trial_title: Investigating Benefits of a Physical Therapist (PT)-Guided Exercise Program in Myotonic Dystrophy Type 2 (DM2)
inclusion_criteria: Genetically confirmed myotonic dystrophy type 2 | Age >= 18 and <= 70 years | Ambulatory without assistance or device | Normal ECG within 3 months prior to screening | Body mass index >= 20 and <= 30
exclusion_criteria: Younger than 18 years or older than 70 years | Pacemaker | Blood pressure < 90/50 mmHg or > 160/90 mmHg at screening | Resting heart rate < 60 or > 100 beats/minute at screening | Any fall within the last 6 months | History of syncope or family history of sudden death | Pregnant or planning to become pregnant | Positive urine pregnancy test
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial is for myotonic dystrophy type 2, while the patient has Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Additionally, the patient is 11 years old and non-ambulatory, conflicting with the trial’s age (18–70) and ambulatory requirements.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 11 years; Male sex; Duchenne muscular dystrophy confirmed by deletion of exons 49-50; Non-ambulatory (lost ambulation 8 months ago); Power wheelchair dependent; Stable deflazacort regimen; Early cardiomyopathy with LVEF 52%; Performance of Upper Limb (PUL) score 18
judge_comment: Correct: There is a hard disease mismatch (DM2 trial vs DMD patient), which mandates F. Additionally, the patient is below the trial’s minimum age (11 vs ≥18), another hard exclusion. The grader’s reasoning and grade align with the rubric.

question_text: I have a 62-year-old male patient diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) 14 months ago. He has limb-onset disease and an ALSFRS-R score of 38. His forced vital capacity (FVC) is stable at 85% of predicted. He is currently taking riluzole. What trial options are available?
trial_title: Investigating Benefits of a Physical Therapist (PT)-Guided Exercise Program in Myotonic Dystrophy Type 2 (DM2)
inclusion_criteria: Genetically confirmed myotonic dystrophy type 2 | Age >= 18 and <= 70 years | Ambulatory without assistance or device | Normal ECG within 3 months prior to screening | Body mass index >= 20 and <= 30
exclusion_criteria: Younger than 18 years or older than 70 years | Pacemaker | Blood pressure < 90/50 mmHg or > 160/90 mmHg at screening | Resting heart rate < 60 or > 100 beats/minute at screening | Any fall within the last 6 months | History of syncope or family history of sudden death | Pregnant or planning to become pregnant | Positive urine pregnancy test
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets genetically confirmed myotonic dystrophy type 2, while the patient has amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. This constitutes a hard exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS); Limb-onset disease; ALSFRS-R score 38; Forced vital capacity (FVC) 85% of predicted; Currently taking riluzole; Time since diagnosis 14 months; Age 62 years; Male sex
judge_comment: Correct: The patient has ALS, while the trial targets genetically confirmed myotonic dystrophy type 2. This is a disease mismatch, a hard exclusion per the rubric, so grade F is appropriate.

question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.
trial_title: A Phase 1b, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled, Multiple Ascending Dose Study of the Safety, Tolerability, Pharmacokinetics, Pharmacodynamics, and Preliminary Efficacy of PMN310 in Patients With Early Alzheimer's Disease
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 50 years | Ambulatory with adequate vision and hearing for assessments | MCI due to Alzheimer’s disease or mild AD dementia per NIA-AA (Stage 3–4) | Global CDR 0.5–1.0 and memory box score >= 0.5 at Screening and Baseline | Objective episodic memory impairment (>= 1 SD below age-adjusted mean on WMS-IV Logical Memory II) | MMSE 20–28 inclusive at Screening | Positive amyloid PET scan within 6 months of Screening or during Screening | Body mass index 18.5–35 kg/m2 inclusive | Patients of reproductive potential agree to use effective contraception during treatment and for 120 days after last dose | Females of childbearing potential: negative pregnancy tests; not breastfeeding | Postmenopausal or surgically sterile patients are eligible | Reliable caregiver available for study visits and assessments | Adequate venous access for IV infusions and blood collection | Stable dose (>= 3 months) of acetylcholinesterase inhibitors or memantine allowed
exclusion_criteria: Residing in a continuous care or long-term care nursing facility | Other neurodegenerative or neurological disorders contributing to cognitive impairment (e.g., Parkinson’s disease, Huntington’s disease, frontotemporal dementia, dementia with Lewy bodies) | QTcF > 450 msec (males) or > 470 msec (females) | ALT >= 2 x ULN, AST >= 2 x ULN, or total bilirubin >= 1.5 x ULN | Creatinine clearance < 30 mL/min | Clinically significant physical or psychiatric illness posing risk or affecting study completion (including suicidal risk/behavior) | Unstable or clinically significant cardiovascular disease within 1 year (e.g., unstable angina, myocardial infarction, chronic heart failure, significant conduction abnormalities) | Clinically significant hepatic or renal impairment; positive hepatitis B surface antigen or hepatitis C antibody | Poorly managed hypertension (systolic > 160 mmHg and/or diastolic > 95 mmHg) or hypotension (systolic < 90 mmHg and/or diastolic < 60 mmHg) | Uncontrolled diabetes (HbA1c > 7.5%) or insulin-dependent diabetes | Significant systemic illness within 30 days before first dose | Seizure within 3 years prior to Screening | Prior malignancy (except adequately treated non-melanoma skin cancer or cervical carcinoma in situ) | Brain MRI findings: > 4 microhemorrhages; > 1 lobar microhemorrhage; superficial siderosis; subarachnoid hemorrhage; any other hemorrhage > 10 mm; > 2 lacunar infarcts or cortical infarct; severe perivascular spaces or multisport-pattern white matter hyperintensities (PI review required) | History of stroke or TIA within 12 months | Contraindication to PET or brain MRI | Negative amyloid PET scan within 6 months of Screening or during Screening | Pregnant or breastfeeding | Alcohol or substance abuse within 12 months prior to dosing | Positive alcohol breath test or positive illicit drug screen at Screening | HIV antibody positive | COVID-19 infection within 2 weeks of Screening or ongoing symptoms at Screening | Currently receiving anti-amyloid treatment or received within 9 months prior to Screening (marketed or investigational); investigational placebo recipients are not excluded | Contraindication to lumbar puncture (e.g., INR > 1.4, platelet count < 120,000/µL, local infection, anticoagulant use except low-dose aspirin, significant spinal abnormalities) | Blood or blood product donation within 56 days prior to first dose | Received an investigational active agent within 30 days or 5 half-lives (whichever is longer) | History of severe hypersensitivity to PMN310 components
prior_therapies: Stable dose of acetylcholinesterase inhibitors or memantine for >= 3 months allowed; Washout from anti-amyloid therapy >= 9 months prior to Screening; Washout from investigational active agents >= 30 days or 5 half-lives (whichever is longer)
reasoning: The trial requires early Alzheimer’s disease with a positive amyloid PET. This patient is amyloid PET negative/CSF amyloid negative (definitively missing the required biomarker) and has MMSE 19 consistent with moderate dementia, outside the trial’s early-stage criteria.
patient_biomarkers: Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 68 years; Male; Progressive cognitive decline for 2 years; MMSE score 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
judge_comment: Correct: The trial requires early AD with positive amyloid PET (and explicitly excludes negative amyloid PET). The patient has negative amyloid PET and MMSE 19 (moderate), so there is a hard biomarker requirement mismatch → F.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 11-year-old boy with Duchenne muscular dystrophy confirmed by a deletion of exons 49-50. exclusion_criteria: Any condition that, in the opinion of the investigator, would prevent completion of study procedures

patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 11 years; Male sex; Duchenne muscular dystrophy confirmed by deletion of exons 49-50; Non-ambulatory (lost ambulation 8 months ago); Power wheelchair dependent; Stable deflazacort regimen; Early cardiomyopathy with LVEF 52%; Performance of Upper Limb (PUL) score 18

The grader’s F is correct. Mention of LMNB1 biomarker absence is not necessary but does not affect the correct F.

question_text: A 55-year-old female has severe, seropositive rheumatoid arthritis refractory to methotrexate and two prior biologic agents (adalimumab and tocilizumab). question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.
trial_title: Long-term Home-based Transcranial Electrical Stimulation for Cognitive and Motor Function in Older Adults With an Increased Risk of Dementia: a Randomized Controlled Trial
diseases_targeted: Alzheimer Disease and Related Dementias; Cognition; Mobility Disability
inclusion_criteria: Age 65-90 years | Subjective cognitive complaints per screening questions | Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) score >=21 | Slow gait speed defined as usual walking speed >=1 SD below age- and sex-adjusted means on 4-Meter walk | Able to walk unassisted for at least 2 minutes and Functional Activities Questionnaire (FAQ) score <9
exclusion_criteria: Formal education less than 8th grade | Previous physician diagnosis of dementia | Current diagnosis of a major psychiatric disorder (e.g., schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, major depressive disorder) | Moderate-to-severe depressive symptoms (Geriatric Depression Scale-15 score >=9) | History of head trauma with prolonged loss of consciousness | History of fainting spells of unknown etiology that might constitute seizures | History of seizures, epilepsy, or first-degree family history of epilepsy (except a single benign seizure per neurologist judgment) | Hospitalization within the past 3 months due to acute illness or musculoskeletal injury significantly affecting gait or balance | Unstable or uncontrolled medical conditions that may pose risk with potential provoked seizure (e.g., cardiac malformation, dysrhythmia, asthma) | Substance use disorder within the past 6 months | Hairstyle or headdress preventing electrode contact with the scalp or interfering with stimulation (e.g., thick braids, hair weave, afro, wig) | Chronic vertigo | Myocardial infarction within the past 6 months | Active cancer receiving chemotherapy or radiation therapy | Legal blindness | Visual hallucinations (history or self-report) | Pacemaker | Contraindications to MRI or tDCS (e.g., unprovoked seizure within past 2 years, risk of ferromagnetic objects, implanted medical devices such as deep brain stimulator, infusion pump, cochlear implant, pacemaker; active dermatological condition on the scalp) | History of REM sleep behavior disorder | Medical history and CNS-active medications deemed unsafe by study physician based on dose, recent changes, duration, or combinations

reasoning: The trial explicitly excludes participants with a previous physician diagnosis of dementia, while the patient has documented moderate-stage dementia. Other key inclusions (e.g., MoCA ≥21, slow gait criteria) are not met or unknown.
patient_biomarkers: Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 68 years; Male; Progressive cognitive decline for 2 years; MMSE score 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
judge_comment: Explicit exclusion applies: trial excludes anyone with a previous physician diagnosis of dementia, and the patient has moderate-stage dementia. Under the rubric, that is a hard exclusion → F. Other inclusion details are irrelevant once a hard exclusion is triggered.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: Mirikizumab in the Treatment of Chronic Inflammatory Conditions of the Pouch
diseases_targeted: Chronic Pouchitis; Crohn's-like Disease of the Pouch
inclusion_criteria: Age >=18 and <=80 years | Diagnosis of chronic pouchitis or Crohn's-like disease of the pouch | Chronic antibiotic-dependent pouchitis: symptoms responsive to antibiotics but relapse after stopping, requiring continuous antibiotics | Chronic antibiotic-refractory pouchitis: lack of response or minimal improvement with standard antibiotics | Crohn's-like disease of the pouch: fistula >=12 months post-IPAA, stricture of pouch body or pre-pouch ileum, or pre-pouch ileitis (pouchitis may coexist) | History of ulcerative colitis and prior IPAA (1, 2, modified -2, or 3 stage) with ileostomy takedown | Provider is considering initiating mirikizumab for treatment
exclusion_criteria: Prior exposure to mirikizumab | Known hypersensitivity to mirikizumab or its metabolites | Current Clostridioides difficile infection | Known HIV infection or active hepatitis B or C | Clinically significant liver disease (PSC allowed if liver function tests <1.5 x ULN) | Severe hepatic impairment (Child-Pugh class C) | Decreased kidney function with eGFR <45 mL/min/1.73 m^2 | History of malignancy except basal cell carcinoma, non-metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the skin, or prior malignancy cured >=5 years before screening without recurrence | Clinically significant laboratory abnormalities at screening or baseline per investigator | Pregnant or breastfeeding, or of childbearing potential without highly effective contraception | Participation in another interventional clinical trial within 30 days before screening | Any disorder that may jeopardize safety or protocol compliance per investigator
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets chronic pouchitis or Crohn’s-like disease of the pouch (post-IPAA), whereas the patient has fistulizing Crohn’s disease with no evidence of a pouch history.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease; CDAI score 350; Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab; Active perianal fistula with draining seton in place; Recently completed IV antibiotics for perianal abscess
judge_comment: Correct F due to disease mismatch. The trial targets chronic pouchitis or Crohn’s-like disease of the pouch (post-IPAA), not general fistulizing Crohn’s disease. Patient’s disease is not among the trial’s listed diseases/cohorts, triggering a hard exclusion. Age/sex are fine, but disease mismatch alone warrants F.

trial_title: A Phase 1 Study of a Combined Cytotoxic and Immune-Stimulatory Therapy in Pediatric and Young Adult Patients With Recurrent, Primary Malignant Brain Tumors
diseases_targeted: Malignant Brain Tumor (recurrent); Diffuse Hemispheric Glioma (H3 G34-mutant)
inclusion_criteria: Age 3-25 years with malignant primary brain tumor at recurrence/relapse/progression after completion of up-front standard therapy | Age 26-39 years with diffuse hemispheric glioma, H3 G34-mutant, at recurrence/relapse/progression after completion of up-front standard therapy | Weight >= 10 kg and BSA > 0.5 m^2 | On stable or decreasing corticosteroid dose for >= 3 days prior to baseline MRI | Surgical resection of recurrence/relapse/progression is clinically indicated | Willing to provide archival FFPE and/or frozen tissue specimens, if available | Recovered from acute side effects of prior therapy | Therapy washouts from start of study treatment: >= 7 days after last biologic agent or beyond known AE window; 5 half-lives from any investigational agent; 4 weeks from cytotoxic therapy (23 days for temozolomide; 6 weeks for nitrosoureas); 6 weeks from antibody therapy (21 days for bevacizumab); 6 weeks from cellular therapy; 4 weeks or 5 half-lives (whichever shorter) from other antitumor therapies | Prior radiotherapy: >= 28 days from focal RT; >= 150 days from craniospinal irradiation | Bevacizumab for RT-induced edema allowed (up to 5 doses; no washout required) | Prior temozolomide during radiation at standard pediatric dosing allowed; prior dexamethasone allowed | ANC >= 1000/µL | Platelets >= 100000/µL (transfusion independent) | Creatinine clearance or GFR >= 70 mL/min/1.73 m^2 or serum creatinine within normal limits for age | Bilirubin <= 2 x ULN | ALT <= 3 x ULN | Serum albumin <= 2 g/dL | Performance score >= 60 (Karnofsky if >16 years; Lansky if <=16 years) | Females of child-bearing potential and males agree to use adequate contraception during treatment and for 30 days after last dose
exclusion_criteria: Not clinically appropriate for tumor resection per neurosurgeon | Disseminated disease including diffuse leptomeningeal disease or CSF dissemination | Primary brainstem or primary spinal tumors | History of prior gene therapy | Ongoing valacyclovir therapy that cannot be stopped due to a medical condition | Known allergy to valacyclovir | Concurrent use of other investigational agents (non-diagnostic) | Currently receiving anti-cancer agents | Known disorders affecting immune system (e.g., HIV, hepatitis B or C) or autoimmune disorder requiring systemic cytotoxic or immunosuppressive therapy | Uncontrolled infection or other uncontrolled systemic illness | Current diagnosis of bipolar disorder or major depressive disorder | Congenital immune deficiency syndrome or acquired autoimmune disease | Pregnant or breastfeeding; FOCBP must have negative pregnancy test prior to therapy | Active illicit drug use or diagnosis of alcoholism | History of kidney transplant | History of allogeneic stem cell transplantation | Another malignancy that is progressing or requires active treatment within 3 years
prior_therapies: Completed up-front standard-of-care therapy required; Washout: >= 7 days since last biologic agent or beyond known AE window; Washout: 5 half-lives from any investigational agent; Washout: 4 weeks from cytotoxic therapy (23 days for temozolomide; 6 weeks for nitrosoureas); Washout: 6 weeks from antibody therapy (21 days for bevacizumab); Washout: 6 weeks from cellular therapy (e.g., modified T cells, NK cells, dendritic cells); Washout: 4 weeks or 5 half-lives (whichever is shorter) from other antitumor therapies; Prior radiotherapy: >= 28 days from focal RT; >= 150 days from craniospinal irradiation; Bevacizumab for RT-induced edema allowed (<= 5 doses; no washout required); Prior temozolomide during radiation at standard pediatric dosing allowed; Prior dexamethasone allowed
reasoning: The patient is 40 years old, which is outside the trial's age range (3-39), constituting a hard exclusion. Additionally, the older cohort (26-39) requires H3 G34-mutant disease, which does not match the patient's IDH-wildtype glioblastoma.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Histologically confirmed glioblastoma; IDH wildtype; Recurrent disease after standard therapy; ECOG 1; Age 40 years; Male; Prior gross total resection; Completed adjuvant radiation with concurrent temozolomide; Completed adjuvant temozolomide
patient_prior_therapies: Gross total resection; Radiation therapy with concurrent temozolomide; Adjuvant temozolomide
judge_comment: Hard exclusion applies: patient age 40 exceeds trial maximum age 39. This alone mandates F per rubric. The grader’s additional note about the 26–39 H3 G34-mutant cohort is accurate but unnecessary; age exclusion is sufficient.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: Phase 1b/2a Trial of Allogeneic Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation (HSCT) From an HLA-partially Matched Related or Unrelated Donor After TCRab+ T-cell/CD19+ B-cell Depletion for Patients With Monogenic and/or Early-onset (EO), Medically Refractory (MR) Crohn Disease (CD)
diseases_targeted: Crohn Disease (medically refractory, early-onset or monogenic)
inclusion_criteria: Monogenic cause of inflammatory bowel disease with a causative mutation for which HSCT is known to be curative (e.g., IL10/IL10RA/IL10RB, XIAP, IPEX, WAS, CD40L, CGD, LRBA, CTLA4, DOCK8, SCID syndromes) | Known monogenic cause of Crohn disease expressed in lymphohematopoietic cells where HSCT has not been previously performed, with moderate disease activity and failure/toxicity to at least two treatment pathways | Suspected monogenic cause of Crohn disease with a rare deleterious variant in a lymphohematopoietic-expressed gene and moderate disease activity or corticosteroid-dependence despite trials of at least two biologic/small molecule therapies of different mechanisms or significant toxicity | Medically refractory Crohn disease with suspected strong genetic component, with moderate or severe activity and corticosteroid-dependence despite trials of at least two biologic/small molecule therapies or significant toxicity | Disease severity unlikely to be tolerable long-term (e.g., not amenable to surgery without risk of short bowel syndrome or permanent ileostomy; requirement for long-term parenteral nutrition; intolerable extraintestinal symptoms) | Features suggesting high genetic contribution (e.g., parental consanguinity, strong family history in first-degree relatives, diagnosis <6 years, extraintestinal manifestations, family history of IBD or autoimmune disease) | Age >2 years and <30 years | Donor and recipient identical at least one allele at HLA-A, HLA-B, HLA-C, HLA-DQB1, and HLA-DRB1 by high-resolution typing | Karnofsky/Lansky performance status >=50%
exclusion_criteria: Ulcerative colitis | Crohn disease responsive to medical therapy without corticosteroid-dependence or significant toxicity | Deleterious mutation in a gene expressed in epithelial or stromal cells but not in lymphohematopoietic cells (e.g., TTC7A), or mutation expected to be more deleterious outside lymphohematopoietic cells | Active hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis | Hepatic dysfunction: ALT >5 x ULN, AST >5 x ULN, or direct bilirubin >3 x ULN | Cirrhosis with bridging fibrosis (grade F3 or greater) or sclerosing cholangitis | Severe cardiovascular disease (e.g., left ventricular ejection fraction <40% or severe diastolic dysfunction) | Severe renal dysfunction: serum creatinine >1.5 x ULN or 24-hour creatinine clearance <50 mL/min/m2 | HIV infection or chronic hepatitis B or hepatitis C infection | Past exposure to therapeutic radiation | Previous allogeneic HSCT | Active malignancy or history of malignancy within 2 years (except nonmelanoma skin cancer or carcinoma in situ) | Pregnant or lactating | Severe concurrent uncontrolled disease increasing risk from study participation
prior_therapies: Failure or significant toxicity after at least two biologic or small-molecule therapies with different mechanisms (e.g., TNF inhibitors, anti-IL12/23 antibodies, JAK inhibitors, anti-integrin); Corticosteroid dependence despite prior biologic/small-molecule therapies
reasoning: Disease matches, but the patient is 32 years old, which is outside the trial’s age window (>2 and <30; max_age 30). This constitutes a hard age exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease; CDAI score 350; Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab; Active perianal fistula with draining seton in place; Recently completed IV antibiotics for perianal abscess
judge_comment: Patient age 32 exceeds the trial’s maximum age (30), which is a hard exclusion per rubric. Disease category (Crohn’s) matches, but the age window conflict mandates grade F. Grader’s reasoning aligns with the rubric.

question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.
trial_title: Web-based Technology and Cognitive Training: Improving Executive Control in Cognitively Healthy Older Adults: the MUltitasking STrategy (MUST) Study
inclusion_criteria: Age 60-75 | Adequate English proficiency | Willingness to attend 2 in-person assessments | Willingness to attend a blood test | Willingness to attend online intervention sessions | Willingness to attend an online follow-up assessment
exclusion_criteria: Montreal Cognitive Assessment score < 26 | History of cognitive impairment, dementia, stroke, seizure disorder, or other neuropsychiatric condition judged to impact cognitive performance | Taking medications known to influence cognitive performance | Sensory impairment (e.g., visual, auditory) incompatible with use of a standard computer workstation | Physical impairment (e.g., severe arthritic, orthopedic, neurologic) incompatible with use of a standard computer workstation | Enrollment in a concurrent study that could affect the outcome of this study
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: The trial explicitly excludes participants with a history of cognitive impairment or dementia, and the patient has moderate-stage dementia. Although age fits, this explicit exclusion makes the patient ineligible.
patient_biomarkers: Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 68 years; Male; Progressive cognitive decline for 2 years; MMSE score 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
judge_comment: The trial explicitly excludes participants with a history of cognitive impairment or dementia, and the patient has moderate-stage dementia. This is a hard exclusion per the rubric, so F is correct. Age and sex eligibility do not override this.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: Closure Of Cryptoglandular Fistula-in-ano And Associated Non-healing Draining Wounds With Kerecis SurgiClose
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Cryptoglandular fistula-in-ano
exclusion_criteria: Age < 18 years | Pregnant | Allergy or sensitivity to fish material | Inflammatory bowel disease | Fistula-in-ano associated with anal cancer | Fistula-in-ano associated with rectal cancer | Fistula-in-ano associated with extramammary Paget's disease | Fistula-in-ano associated with hidradenitis suppurativa | Fistula-in-ano associated with anal condyloma | Active infection or abscess
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: The trial explicitly excludes patients with inflammatory bowel disease, and the patient has Crohn's disease; moreover, the trial targets cryptoglandular (non-IBD) fistula-in-ano.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease; CDAI score 350; Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab; Active perianal fistula with draining seton in place; Recently completed IV antibiotics for perianal abscess
judge_comment: Explicit hard exclusion: trial excludes inflammatory bowel disease, and the patient has Crohn’s disease (IBD). Therefore F is correct. The grader’s reasoning correctly identified this.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 11-year-old boy with Duchenne muscular dystrophy confirmed by a deletion of exons 49-50. He lost ambulation 8 months ago and is now dependent on a power wheelchair. He is on a stable regimen of deflazacort and lisinopril for early cardiomyopathy (LVEF 52%). His Performance of Upper Limb (PUL) score is 18. His parents are interested in trials for non-ambulatory patients.
trial_title: Evaluation of the Safety and Efficacy of a Full-Body Electrostimulation Garment for Individuals With Neurological and Neuromuscular Conditions That Cause Spasticity, Hyperreflexia, and Pain
diseases_targeted: Multiple Sclerosis; Fibromyalgia; Neurological Disorder; Neuromuscular Disorder
inclusion_criteria: Age 18 to 75 years | Medical clearance from physician | Spasticity, pain, or hyperreflexia due to neurological or neuromuscular conditions, or a diagnosis of Multiple Sclerosis or Fibromyalgia | Multiple Sclerosis: definite diagnosis for at least 1 month | Multiple Sclerosis: ability to walk independently or with support (EDSS < 7) | Multiple Sclerosis: absence of relapses in the last 3 months | Multiple Sclerosis: spasticity with Modified Ashworth Scale (MAS) >= 1+ | Multiple Sclerosis: Berg Balance Scale (BBS) score < 46 | Fibromyalgia: definite diagnosis for at least 3 months | Able to follow instructions and report pain and/or discomfort | Able to ambulate 10 meters without body weight support with or without assistive devices and/or caregiver assistance
exclusion_criteria: Implanted medical devices or equipment that can be disrupted by magnets (e.g., shunts) | Swollen, infected, or inflamed areas or skin eruptions (e.g., phlebitis, thrombophlebitis, varicose veins) in areas where the suit will be used | No established somatic or neuropsychiatric diagnosis prior to enrollment | Pregnant or nursing
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Patient is 11 years old, but the trial requires age 18–75, which is a hard exclusion. The trial also requires ability to ambulate 10 meters, whereas the patient is non-ambulatory.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 11 years; Male sex; Duchenne muscular dystrophy confirmed by deletion of exons 49-50; Non-ambulatory (lost ambulation 8 months ago); Power wheelchair dependent; Stable deflazacort regimen; Early cardiomyopathy with LVEF 52%; Performance of Upper Limb (PUL) score 18
judge_comment: Age 11 is below trial minimum 18, which is a hard exclusion per rubric, so F is correct. The noted ambulation requirement is an additional mismatch but not needed to justify F.
